story:
A scholarship for a future

Founded in 1974, the Contra Costa Ballet Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to bringing the classical-ballet tradition to the East Bay. Our mission is to provide professionally-staged, ballet performances to the community and scholarships to talented, young dancers.

Scholarships in the Arts

  • The Foundation seeks to provide full or half scholarships for 12 or more promising young dancers each year.

  • Scholarships are offered to dancers with financial needs, who have demonstrated the commitment and talent to advance their technical and performance skills.

  • The individual scholarships underwrite the year-round classes, up to five days a week, and participation in a summer intensive program.

We need your help

  • The Contra Costa Ballet Foundation needs your help today!  In order to continue our scholarships, we must raise $20,000.

  • Due to decreased funding of the arts by corporate donors and federal funding, scholarship students are in jeopardy of losing funding as early as Spring 2016 semester.  With your support, these young dancers from the East Bay will be able to continue their training.


The Impact

  • Your contribution will make a difference.  A full scholarship for a dancer with the Contra Costa Ballet Youth Company is $4,750 and half the amount for young men pursuing classical ballet. 

  • The goal of $20,000 will support 8 young men and 6 young women through June 2016.  Every $350 supports a scholarship student for one month.  For every $1,100, the entire young men’s class is underwritten for a month. 

  • The Foundation has provided scholarships to dozens of students who have found their love of dance in the East Bay and moved on to pre-professional ballet companies, professional careers in dance, and college and community performance groups. 

    "As a former CCB Scholarship student and professional dancer, I’m in full support of helping young dancers reach their full potential, through special scholarship programs. My days spent training at Contra Costa Ballet were very special and helped to achieve my dream of dancing with a professional ballet company."

    Best,
    Karen Nepacena
    CCB Alumni, 1990s


Our challenge

    The Contra Costa Ballet Foundation is focused each year on supporting the arts, specifically classical ballet in the East Bay.  Historically, our major fundraiser has been our annual production of The Nutcracker and corporate donors.  As the costs of production increases and the corporate donors reduce their support of arts, the Foundation is seeking greater support from individual donors.  The challenge is to maintain our current scholarship awards with many more individual donors, new fundraising events and social media campaigns like this one.  Please contribute your tax deductable donation today. 


Other Ways You Can Help

     

  • Joining us at our annual performance of The Nutcracker

    https://lesherartscenter.showare.com/eventperformances.asp?evt=470

  • Like us on Facebook, and follow us on Instagram,Twitter, and review us on Yelp.
  • Use our Indiegogo share tools!

story:
• My name is Justin Titus aka Titus Mime! I was born and raised in Dallas, TX. I currently live in Chicago, IL and began mime dancing at the age of 15. Mime shaped who I am today and provided a unique platform for me to give back to the community.
  • This campaign is to share the story of "Me, Myself and Mime" in major performance art theaters across the country and create film to:  
  • 1) Spread the gospel through mime, 2) Inspire people to follow their passion and live out their dreams. 3) Showcase awesome mime talent from around the country. 4) Present a unique artform that can expose the youth in this country to positive forms of expression.
  • Mime teams that will be featured in the show are all a part of Titus Mime's journey in one way or another. Every team is extremely talented and have years of experience in the field of mime and are also leaving their own legacy and shaping communities for the better. Featured teams are:

 

  1. The Wandering Mimes (Dallas, TX)
  2. Second Coming (Dallas, TX)
  3. Mike n' Ike Mime (Houston, TX)
  4. The Prairie View A&M University Mime Ministry aka P.V. Mime (Prairie View, TX)
  5. Interpretive Praise (Chicago, IL) a unique mix of high school students representing different schools and different church organization around the city of Chicago I.E (Trinity United Church of Christ, Fellowship Missionary Baptist Church aka "The Ship," and Lincoln Memorial United Church of Christ).
  • Contributors will help us to get this show in major theaters across the country, help cover the cost of travel and lodging in order to spread hope to the world and motivate an entire generation. 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • We need $30,000 to cover the cost of theater rental, travel and lodging
  • 1) Dallas City Performance Hall, Dallas, TX, Sunday, August 6th, rental price= $4,339.00,
  • 2) Harris Theater, Saturday, September 30th, Chicago, Illinois, rental price= $8750,
  • 3) Hobby Center for the Performing Arts (Zilka Hall), October 14th, Houston, TX, rental price= $4,000
  • 4) other potential venues tbd for Novemeber and December

Travel

Chicago mime team flights leave August 5 return August 7th estimate from Southwest Airlines ($257.40/per person round trip) group rate for 12 passengers= $3,088.80 prices fluctuate 

we will need cost of travel from Dallas/Houston to Chicago in September  

Chicago/Dallas to Houston in October

Hotels

 Dallas (Marriott city center 650 n pearl st Dallas, TX 75201 estimate $225/per room for 10 rooms= $2,250), prices may change

Chicago, (Hyatt Regency chicago estimate: $229/per room for 10 rooms ($2,229.00) prices may change

Houston ( estimate: Doubletree by Hilton $119/per room for 10 rooms $1,119) prices may change

 

  • Those that contribute $50 or more will have their name appear as a sponsor on the program to be recognized for your support
  • other perks will be rolling out soon!

The Impact

 

  • This project can impact the world, because in times of uncertainty, violence and conflict people are in need of something inspirational.  
  • The youth need a positive outlet to utilize when they are frustrated or are trying to get away from negative outside influences.
  • "Me, Myself and Mime" offers both spiritual entertainment and inspiration, sharing a unique way of expression to the next generation in hopes to shape the world for the better.

Risks & Challenges

 

  • If funds are not raised we run the risk of other theater companies taking the time slots that are already on hold. which would force dates to change and/or the tour to be potentially put on hold. 
  • We chose a flexible option on Indiegogo, because any little bit will help and if we don't raise all the funds, the funds that we do raise will go toward the production.
  • if the funds are not raised, "Me, Myself and Mime" could potentially only be seen in one city or none at all, which would defeat the purpose of the mission: "Inspiring the world and sharing the gospel through mime!"
  • We could also risk missing out on an entire generation of youth that may not see the potential that is possible if only they had been exposed to something like mime dancing  that could appeal to their unique interests and talents. Mime could also allow them to grow and develop the skills and character traits they need to contribute to society in a positive way.
  • You also risk missing out on witnessing very talented and gifted people who put their heart, mind, body and soul into this craft and deserve a chance to show the world their gift and for you to be ispired as a result.

 

  • The plan on solving these challenges is to continue to save as much money out of pocket as possible to cover the expenses. 
  • The first show is set for August 6th in Dallas, TX at the Dallas Performance Arts Hall. If we can make Dallas happen, the next phase would be the snowball effect. Based off of the suceess from Dallas we should be able to cover the expenses for the coming shows until the tour is over. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • If you aren't able or willing to contribute you can help us by spreading the word in your area to all of your friends, family, loved ones, or organizations you are a part of.

share via Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, email, or any other form of social media possible.

  • you can also help by purchasing tickets when they become available in your area, for you, your family, or for someone that might be interested when the show comes to your city.
  • use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you very much for your support

Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you aren't able or willing to contribute you can help us by spreading the word in your area to all of your friends, family, loved ones, or organizations you are a part of.

story:
My name is Sarah Blanc and I am a choreographer, performer and teacher. I am Irish and have been living in the UK for 13 years now. 

About Sarah Blanc/Moxie Brawl

I am a choreographer, performer and teacher working within contemporary dance. I currently create work on my company Moxie Brawl and solo work on myself, in addition to accepting commissions and work with other people as an Assistant Choreographer and Movement Director.

Moxie Brawl is a fresh all female inclusive dance theatre company that creates work for outdoors, indoors and places where dance shouldn't be. We are currently supported by Candoco Dance Company, DanceEast, South East Dance, GLYPT and Trinity Laban.

The work I make sits on the perimeter of both theatre and dance. I want to continue to explore both art-forms but be able to push the theatricality of my work much further.  My work has been described as dance meets stand up meets theatre that is able to interact with and draw an audience in without alienating and terrifying them. I enjoy talking about real events but filtering them through an unexpected form. I enjoy combining diverse bodies, a movement language and honest stories. As an artist I am passionate about working with diverse casts. Both my solo practice and my work with Moxie Brawl, reflect my desire to create work that connects with people, that people can experience and engage with.

I have always experimented with British Sign Language (BSL) within my choreography. Working with Mark Smith on my outdoor work Sit Back, Nadia Nadarajah on family show Windibops and now Jemima Hoadley on new group work History Of Ireland. 

The Project and Why It's Important to Me

Over the coming months, I want to explore how I can make my company’s new and existing work accessible to Deaf audiences. My key question to explore is how do I do this in an artistic way that also ensures access? I want to see how I can embed interpretation into my work so its not an ‘add on’ but an exciting artistic possibility.  

I'm currently creating a new group show, History of Ireland, that is fully accessible to deaf audiences. Unlike in previous processes, we have had a Sign Language Interpreter in the rehearsal process from the outset. I am also wanting to make my solo work accessible; It Started with Jason Donovan which already exists without interpretation and a new solo show, My Feminist Boner which I want to experiment with sign language from the outset.  

This process will not only impact on my own artistic practice but will also enhance the knowledge on how to enhance accessibility within the creative team, which they can take with them to future employment, promoting inclusive practice across the sector.  From previous experience, I believe that building in accessibility enhancing elements to my work will strengthen my inclusive practice as I continue to grow as an artist. I feel both things come hand in hand and essentially it is all part of my artistic practice.

I currently have Jeni Draper working with me on the development of History of Ireland and both solo works as an Access Adviser and Mentor. I also plan to work with deaf and disabled artists, either performing within the work or as Access Advisers.

I'm doing my best to make sure that I am doing what what I set out to do and this is where you can help.....

What we need

We have been very lucky to receive £26,000 from Arts Council England to support the next development of my company, Moxie Brawl. The money received from the grant does a number of things:
- Take some time to develop my company and our messaging
-  To FINALLY create and premiere a new show for Moxie Brawl, History of Ireland 
- Continue touring existing work Windibops and It Started with Jason Donovan 
- Develop a new solo show, My Feminist Boner
- Develop my company

And finally, I want to ensure that across these key areas, I continue to explore access for Deaf audiences and performers which has always been a priority for me as an artist. 

We need to raise just £3,000 to meet our overall target of £29,000 to make this all happen. That's where you can help us...

How you can help

We would really appreciate any support you can give to help us reach out target.

To reassure you - I have managed budgets for Moxie Brawl for amounts of up to £30,000. I'm also working with Producer Hannah Dye who will make sure I don't spend your money on shoes!!

Our newest female characters from History of Ireland would like to offer you a perk for your kind donation - see list to the right!

If you like what you are reading but you are unable to help us at this moment by pledging, please do share and tell people about it.  You can also contact us to find out more and stay updated.

Both my solo practice and my work with Moxie Brawl, reflect my desire to create work that connects with people, that people can experience and engage with.
I have always experimented with British Sign Language (BSL) within my choreography. Working with Mark Smith on my outdoor work Sit Back, Nadia Nadarajah on family show Windibops and now Jemima Hoadley on new group work History Of Ireland. 

The Project and Why It's Important to Me
Over the coming months, I want to explore how I can make my company’s new and existing work accessible to Deaf audiences. My key question to explore is how do I do this in an artistic way that also ensures access? I want to see how I can embed interpretation into my work so its not an ‘add on’ but an exciting artistic possibility.  
I'm currently creating a new group show, History of Ireland, that is fully accessible to deaf audiences. Unlike in previous processes, we have had a Sign Language Interpreter in the rehearsal process from the outset. I am also wanting to make my solo work accessible; It Started with Jason Donovan which already exists without interpretation and a new solo show, My Feminist Boner which I want to experiment with sign language from the outset.  
This process will not only impact on my own artistic practice but will also enhance the knowledge on how to enhance accessibility within the creative team, which they can take with them to future employment, promoting inclusive practice across the sector.  From previous experience, I believe that building in accessibility enhancing elements to my work will strengthen my inclusive practice as I continue to grow as an artist. I feel both things come hand in hand and essentially it is all part of my artistic practice.
I currently have Jeni Draper working with me on the development of History of Ireland and both solo works as an Access Adviser and Mentor. I also plan to work with deaf and disabled artists, either performing within the work or as Access Advisers.
I'm doing my best to make sure that I am doing what what I set out to do and this is where you can help.....

What we need
We have been very lucky to receive £26,000 from Arts Council England to support the next development of my company, Moxie Brawl. The money received from the grant does a number of things:- Take some time to develop my company and our messaging-  To FINALLY create and premiere a new show for Moxie Brawl, History of Ireland - Continue touring existing work Windibops and It Started with Jason Donovan - Develop a new solo show, My Feminist Boner- Develop my company
And finally, I want to ensure that across these key areas, I continue to explore access for Deaf audiences and performers which has always been a priority for me as an artist. 
We need to raise just £3,000 to meet our overall target of £29,000 to make this all happen. That's where you can help us...
How you can help
We would really appreciate any support you can give to help us reach out target.
To reassure you - I have managed budgets for Moxie Brawl for amounts of up to £30,000. I'm also working with Producer Hannah Dye who will make sure I don't spend your money on shoes!!
Our newest female characters from History of Ireland would like to offer you a perk for your kind donation - see list to the right!If you like what you are reading but you are unable to help us at this moment by pledging, please do share and tell people about it.  You can also contact us to find out more and stay updated.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Nikoo Mamdoohi, a graduating Directing MFA from UMass Amherst. I'm from Iran and for my thesis I directed a play named Ta'zieh - Between Two Rivers. Ifa Bayeza, award-winning African-American playwright, wrote the play from an English translation into a versed version based on Persian poetic meters.Ta'zieh is a traditional Iranian performance. The theme of all Ta'zieh plays is standing up for what you believe in and speaking truth to power. The story of Ta'zieh performances rotates around the death of Imam Hussein, an iconic Islamic Imam and martyr who died because he did not want to pledge allegiance to the elected governor at the time, early after the prophet’s death in 680 CE. A story that is historic, yet contemporary.

Our production is not a traditional Ta'zieh performance, it is an intercultural performance for today. Between Two Rivers as between the Euphrates and Mississippi. We have created our version, with a woman director, woman playwright and women characters played by women actor, all in a tradition that is solely performed by men. And it is intercultural as we have echoed the African-American cry for justice and invited the contribution of a diverse ensemble as this production has been created through a devised theater process. Our play is comprised of two one hour acts, the first act showing the story of Hurr a soldier who is sent to kill Imam Hussein but upon meeting him, joins on his side and dies defending him. In the second act we see Zeynab, Hussein's sister who has witnessed the unjust death of her brother and his soldiers and when took as a captive to the new governors court, she stands up and speaks to everyone, shedding light on what the truth of the killings were, and by doing this, changing the course of the history to how we know it today. Both of these acts showing activism in face of the governing power, with courage.

After performing this play at UMass, and seeing how this play resonated with the audience -people from very diverse backgrounds, ethnicities, races and religions- I felt strongly that this play should be performed for a larger audience. BU professor Shahla Haeri was our invited guest at our talkback session in UMass. After seeing the play, she was greatly moved and introduced me to the Boston University Iranian Student Organization (BUISO) who then invited us to perform in BU.

The Impact

This remount, and your contribution in making this happen is extremely important for us, for a multitude of reasons. It gives the students of UMass a rare opportunity to perform what they have passionately created, outside of UMass and for a bigger audience. It is a great opportunity for the students of BU to see a play, be exposed and get immersed in stories and arts of another culture, in an intercultural experience. Apart from these, this performance is doubly special because it is done on the actual Ashura day, the 10th day of Muharram, on the day of the martyrdom of Hossein. All around the world, muslims commemorate his death on this day, and in Iran many Ta’zieh performances will happen. We are joining all on this day, and bringing the Muslim and Iranian community of Boston a rare chance of attending a Ta’zieh performance on Ashura.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we raise will help us to:

  • Pay for an accessible venue that will allow us to bring our message of peace to Boston
  • Transport and accommodate our hard-working cast and crew, as well as our set and props
  • Ensure Vaahe is able to continue to create important and meaningful stories that promote unity and love. As a contributor, you become a part of the spreading of that message

Risks & Challenges

We are a Tehran-based collective, and recently started working internationally. Expansion over borders is a complicated and challenging process

Thanks to the hard work of our team, and the financial help of donors like you, we will be able to continue expanding into as many places as possible and help to create an inclusive and peaceful world for all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider attending our show! Tickets can be purchased here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/tazieh-between-two...

Invite your friends and family!

story:
About "La Dottoressa" 

"La Dottoressa" is a new musical about the legendary educator, feminist and advocate for World Peace, Maria Montessori, one of the first woman doctors in Italy whose teaching methods changed the world.

The musical, set at the end of the 19th century, begins with Montessori's seemingly insurmountable challenges in becoming a woman doctor in Italy at a time when most professions, especially medicine, were exclusively male-dominated. This did not phase Maria, who took her plight directly to Pope Leo XIII and persuaded him to write a letter on her behalf, to open those tightly shut doors.

The emotional heart of "La Dottoressa" centers around Maria's relationship with her young son, Mario, whom she gave birth to out of wedlock. Faced with the impossible choice to either send her newborn child to distant relatives or be forced to give up her career and destiny amid scandal, Maria chose to remain as a "special aunt" to  her young Mario.  As he grew older, he instinctively knew who this special visitor was... and yearned to be with her.  Their ultimate reunion is tender and profound... echoing the painful decisions we all  make in our lives.

How Your Gift Will Be Used

This campaign is to raise the funds needed to develop the script and score for "La Dottoressa" and prepare it for presentation to producers. The funds raised will be purposed for the writing of the script, composing the music  and the hiring of a music director and actors to render recordings of the songs, to then rehearse the show through staged readings and concert presentations.  Matty Selman, our composer/lyricist and librettist is an Emmy Award winning composer and produced playwright who has worked with such celebrated artists as Galt MacDermot (HAIR) and John Pielmeier (Agnes of God).  For more information on Matty, please visit his website: www.mattyselman.com

Montessori was a citizen of the world and our intention is to make this musical accessible to children of all ages. To that view, no donation is too small.  Our wish for this campaign is to have it reach out to all corners of the earth and and be, in some small way, a link to the global spirit of Maria.

More About Maria Montessori

Many of us have heard the name Montessori, but may not be aware of her teaching method that focused on the careful nurturing of the child to reach his full potential.  

As an advocate for World Peace, Montessori saw a recurrent grain of hope in children... for... "within the child lies the fate of the future..." 

Her championing the cause of the child was at the core of her teaching method... "Our care of the children should be governed not by the desire to make them learn things, but by the endeavor always to keep burning within them the light which is called intelligence..."

Learning through our senses, at an early age when our hearts and minds and spirits are like little sponges, was the revolutionary insight that, during the height of her career in the early years of  the 20th century, drew an audience of great minds such as Thomas Edison, Alexander Graham Bell and Gandhi.   It is no surprise that such celebrated figures of today attribute their success in life to having had a Montessori  education.

Famous Montessori Students

Larry Page and Sergey Brin, founders of Google 

Taylor Swift, recording artist

Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon.com

Gabriel Garcia Marquez, author 

Anne Frank, World War II child diarist

Sean Diddy Combs,  rapper and entrepreneur

Julia Childs, celebrated chef

Helen Hunt, actress

In Conclusion... 

We believe that now is the time to tell the musical story of Maria Montessori.  Thank you for your donation to help bring "La Dottoressa" a new musical, to life.

The Story Behind the Musical

(See the Gallery Section for the video, "The Story Behind the Musical")

Created in Cooperation with American Montessori Society

story: “Dragula” A new musical in two acts Book by Mark Mc Quown Music and Lyrics by Buddy Mix In the city of Transylvania, Romania, is the tourist attraction of Bran Castle which is rumored and reported to be Dracula’s Castle. Living in the castle today is a coven of vampires whose head is called Dragula and they live off of the stray tourist who gets lost now and then in the castle walls. Jordan and Melissa are a young to middle age couple, about to be married and on their pre honey moon visiting Bran Castle but what they really want to do is spend the night in Dracula’s bed. The couple hides from the tour and before the tour leaves for the day they find themselves in Dracula’s Bedroom facing Dragula, dressed as a Security Guard. Dragula discovers that Jordan studies bats for a living and tells Jordan and Melissa that they may return that evening and be part of a dinner party for other members of a society who also study bats. Jordan and Melissa leave with the tour but return that evening by taxi and are ushered into the bedroom, now a dining room, and unbeknownst to them – they are on the menu. At the end of act one, Jordan and Melissa have discovered that they are in a coven of vampires and try everything to escape but Dragula, unwittingly falls in love with Jordan and spares their lives until Dragula is forced to bite Melissa who then, for a brief period, turns into the Queen of the coven and Dragula loses his powers and is restored to human form. Act two brings Jordan and Dragula together to fight the menacing Melissa and Jordan slowly feeling like he is falling in love with a man. In that moment, Melissa is struck by a silver arrow from a bow gun and returns to her human form and now Dragula, Melissa and Jordan are all running from the coven. The coven finally corners them all and one of them bites Dragula who immediately returns to his former stature and the ruler of this coven and this castle. Dragula realizes how impossible it is for him to fall in love with a human and also how much he misses his lost humanity. He hypnotizes Jordan and Melissa so they won’t remember what happened and he sends them back to America to enjoy their lives and American television. He then sends coven members out seeking fresh blood but only gets an apple in return as he retires again for a long night’s sleep in Bran Castle, Transylvania, Romania. This is an incredible story with great music and we are undertaking a staged reading, dance and singing presentation of this new show in order to find a home and a continuing life for the production. Any donation you make will go directly to the production of "Dragula" on October 2, 3, at 7:30 pm to 9:15 pm in The Complex Theaters on Santa Monica Blvd, in Hollywood in The Ruby Theater. Tickets are $20.00 and the Ruby Theatre only holds 55 people so if you also wanted to see it, buy your tickets early, they go on sale in mid August according to the Los Angeles Theater Festival. Please join us.

story:
Short Summary

New Street Dance Group has been working to bring modern dance to the masses for over 5 years. We are committed to creating accessible, thought-provoking, and fun performance experiences that general audiences will  enjoy as much as dance enthusiasts. Inspired by modern dance icons-and-sometimes-social-activists like Isadora Duncan, Martha Graham, Katherine Dunham, Jose Limon, Alvin Ailey, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp and Doug Varone, we  believe in the power of dance to move, to motivate, to challenge, and to spark charge. We have been  mentioned in Philadelphia Weekly for our “dynamism and trademark accessibility” and “provocative staging,” and our work has been described in Campus Philly as “sure to provoke an emotional response.” We are ready to keep modern dance relevant in today's society - but we need your help to do so! 

We are in the process of creating our third Philaldephia FringeArts concert - a follow up to last year's SOLD OUT performance. Structurally Sound is a collaborative evening length work set to 100% live music by The Radical Sound, including a world-premiere commission by composer Tomek Regulski. Original movement created by choreographers Krista Armbruster and Shannon Dooling in collaboration with a cast of ten dancers will take place in a custom-built set piece. This dynamic performance experience begs the question  "Just what are we made of - and how stable is, anyway?"

We are ready to make you think, laugh, cry, breathe, question, imagine, explore, connect, and move  as we explore physical and social structures, family legacies (wanted and unwanted), cultural inheritances, and the stuff that makes us who we are (or at least who we seem to be). Are you ready to help us make it happen?

What We Need & What You Get

We are in need of financial support to help round out our budget, which cannot be met by ticket sales alone. Our expenses include:

  • Venue Rental for Performance: $1000 (This is the going rate in the area for venues that include use of a piano.)
  • Set: $150 (We are reusing and recycling as much as we can, but need some basic hardware and materials to bring it all together.)
  • Rehearsal Space Rental: $300 (We are grateful for an generous in-kind donation of rehearsal space from The Dance Centre in Skippack, PA. This additional rental expense covers additional rehearsals for our dances in the Washington, DC metro area and a workshop rehearsal in Philadelphia.)
  • Costumes: $100 (We are reusing and recycling as much as we can, but will need some additional items to create a cohesive look.)
  • Festival Fees: $375 (These are mandatory fees for participation in the festival that go toward the publication of the festival guide, marketing, and special events like preview performances that we will be participating in!)
  • Required Special Event Insurance: $150
  • Marketing: $100 (This includes a banner for the venue, postcards, and social media boosts to help us spread the word about our show.)
All collaborators on this project - musicians, composers, choreographers, and dancers - have generously donated their time and talent to rehearsals and performances. If we are able to raise enough money through our fundraising efforts, we would be thrilled to provide stipends to our artists! 
In addition to this campaign, we are trying to raise funds through community performances and workshops. However, at this time we do not anticipate these other efforts to meet our fundraising needs. We need your support to make this show happen!

The Impact

Is modern dance still relevant? The prevalent cultural stereotype is that its weird, inaccessible, self-indulgent, old-fashioned, and irrelevant. We have been working to change this perception. We believe that when it is done well, modern dance can be meaningful, accessible, community-building, exciting, engaging, and moving. Throughout the last century, modern dance has been used to tell stories, expose internal emotional landscapes, to connect cultures, and hold a mirror up to society. Small modern dance companies (like us!) are frankly having a hard time surviving in today's economy and artistic landscape, which is increasing dominated by more commercial dance forms. By contributing to this campaign, you are supporting a historic art form and helping us garner enthusiasm and excitement for contemporary modern dance among general audiences in Philadelphia! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute now, you can still be part of our movement! Here's how:

  • Come see our performance, Structurally Sound, on Saturday September 19, 2015 at either 3:30 or 7:00 at Lithuanian Music Hall in Philadelphia. 
  • Donate goods or services for our silent auction at our performance - email newstreetdancegroup@gmail.com for more information.
  • Bring modern dance to your community! We are available for performances at churches, schools, day care centers, community centers, and meetings. 
  • Inspire your students with the art of modern dance! Our experience teaching artists are available for classes and workshops for all ages, from novices through advanced dancers! 
  • Share the campaign or information about the performance with your friends and families!

Throughout the last century, modern dance has been used to tell stories, expose internal emotional landscapes, to connect cultures, and hold a mirror up to society. Small modern dance companies (like us!) are frankly having a hard time surviving in today's economy and artistic landscape, which is increasing dominated by more commercial dance forms. By contributing to this campaign, you are supporting a historic art form and helping us garner enthusiasm and excitement for contemporary modern dance among general audiences in Philadelphia! 


    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute now, you can still be part of our movement! Here's how:


Come see our performance, Structurally Sound, on Saturday September 19, 2015 at either 3:30 or 7:00 at Lithuanian Music Hall in Philadelphia. 
Donate goods or services for our silent auction at our performance - email newstreetdancegroup@gmail.com for more information.
Bring modern dance to your community! We are available for performances at churches, schools, day care centers, community centers, and meetings. 
Inspire your students with the art of modern dance! Our experience teaching artists are available for classes and workshops for all ages, from novices through advanced dancers! 
Share the campaign or information about the performance with your friends and families!

story:
Short Summary

Here's more information on the production Bad Manners at the Dinner Table!

The Writer:

Renee Necole  - New to the game for sure, but making her mark nonetheless! Play write, poet & visionary, Renee Necole lives to create out of the box revelations for the present day church; relaying the bold and uncut reality of the spiritual realm, fleshly conflict and mental awareness of them both.

Renee Necole is not ashamed to say that her visionary works didn’t start in the Christian handbook of holy. She toured the world from 2001 until 2010 with a burlesque poetry ensemble; until she heard the call of God and dedicated her life and her talents to Christ. Renee Necole has been writing poetry, plays, skits and small productions since she can remember; but put her plan into action for the Lord in 2009. Since then she has created such memorizing skits as "Out of the Box" and "Unveiled"; a stage play dedicated to our female ancestors, which has starred Gospel legend Shirley Murdock.

Renee Necole is currently working on a series of Theater Productions including “Bad Manners at the Dinner Table” as well as a new production coming to a venue near you next spring entitled “Sticks & Stones" a drama filled stage production with twist and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat. No doubt, her works are truly compelling! Her productions, poetry and skits are all written on a personal level to connect with the community and especially broken women.

Renee Necole has written, co-produced, casted & co-casted a body of work which includes: Ladies Room with DNR Productions, A House Full of Secrets with William Alexander Productions, Stuck with Jesonda Productions, Be A Lion with Brand New Sheriff Productions and Ferguson the Musical with Pechanda Dubose.

She is the Owner and Creative Director of Cast Me Not Full Service Agency where her model stands as "Providing Provision for Your Vision. A full service company that provides assistance with casting, directing, procurement, event planning and script consulting of films, theater and promotional events. When she’s not writing, Renee Necole is giving to the community with her charity “A.C.T.S” (Acts of Compassion Thespian Society) which provides volunteers for community events; associated with actors who are compelled to help in acts of humanity.

Mother of 2, Israel and Isaiah and wife of Brian Stringfield, her life is busy; but the call that God has placed on her life keeps her feet moving in the footsteps of her destiny. Keep your eye out for this playwright, author, poet and activist!

About Bad Manners & it's Importance:

Denise lived an exciting life full of drama, excitement and inevitably misfortune. Ride along with Denise as she explains the ups and downs that landed her in the lowest place ever. Denise pleads with the audience to help her solve the age old tale of "who done it" as she quest to find the sin who waged her death. Meet Denise’s sins as they round table to discover who the culprit is. Listen to the pleas from Greed, Envy, Lust, Sloth, Wrath, Pride and Gluttony as they try to convince the audience that they are innocent. This is an interactive stage play that keeps the audience on the edge of their seats and brings some of their very own truths to light when they find out what happens when you invite your sins to dinner.

Why this production is important: 

Renee Necole created P31 Productions to open the door for true to life stage productions that hit home for the Christian community and those they are trying to reach. She wanted to embody true ministry through arts while bringing soul stirring, realty based stage productions with comedic flair and audience interaction. Bad Manners at the Dinner Table is just that! While entertaining and not strictly bible belt material, Bad Manners at the Dinner Table touches on many variables to everyday life in combination with the seven deadly sins that touch us daily (Greed, Envy, Gluttony, Pride, Sloth, Wrath & Lust). While humorous, the truth shines through revealing our inner most secrets and demanding us to face our reality.

Providing Provision for the Vision:

Your contributions to the success of this tour and the magnitude of its impact will touch lives! Every donation will be used to support and further the geographic impact of this production. 

This leg of our Bad Manners at the Dinner Table tour will consist of 8 cities in the southern region of the United States. Planned states are:

  • North Carolina
    • Charlotte, NC
    • Winston-Salem, NC
  • South Carolina
    • Columbia, SC
    • Fort Mill, SC
  • Alabama
    • Birmingham, AL
    • Montgomery, AL
  • Georgia
    • Atlanta, GA
    • Augusta, GA
  • Possible Additional Cities
    • Virginia
      • Chesapeake, VA
      • Roanoke, VA

What We Need:

In detail, here is how we intend to use what we receive to accomplish our goal:

  • All contributions for the Bad Manners at the Dinner Table Tour will be used for the below production needs:
    • Travel
    • Lodging
    • Advertisement/Promotion
    • Securing Venues
  • Here's the breakdown:
  • Travel - Bad Manners at the Dinner Table has a cast of 12 with 2 crew members and 1 sound production technician. To travel from state to state we require a 15 passenger van/bus.
    • Estimated cost for Gas for an 8-city tour is $1,200.00
    • Estimated cost for Van rental for an 8-city tour is $1,600.00
  • Lodging - With a cast of 15 at 8 rooms per city (excluding Charlotte, NC & Winston- Salem, NC) estimated lodging is $5,000.00
  • Advertisement/Promotion - Radio promotion & social media are our two best sources for spreading the word about the tour! We intend to host 30 second time slots at 1 major radio station in each state. Radio rates are currently ranging from $300-$450 for a 30 second ad running several times a day. Estimated total cost is $1,500.00 - $2,250.
  • Venues- While in our search for suitable venues, we are searching for small venues that range in price at $500 - $1,000 and hold no more than 500 in capacity. Estimated total cost for venues is $5,600.00
  • Total Estimated Tour Cost: $15,650.00

Risks & Challenges

As you know with any great feat there are risk and challenges! Here are a few of ours:

  • Risk:
    • Not selling ample tickets to each showcase
    • Not raising the capital to complete the entire tour
    • Show mishaps such as re-casting & production defects.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us spread the word by:
    • Sharing our links on Social Media & by word of mouth
    • Provide services in a tour city such as free or low cost venues or lodging.
    • Per-diem help for cast (prepare meals, toiletries and hospitable gestures for the cast & crew while they are in your city!
    • Help us to locate venues at lower pricing than we've listed!
    • Provide advertisement/promotional assistance in any area that you can.
    • Become a vendor at one of our shows!

story:
The play will be performed at The Flamboyan Theater on the lower east side of New York City from Sept. 21-24th at 8pm. 

An important part of our production will be conversations after every performance that will be led by a variety of mental health professionals who will dialogue with the audience, actors, and artistic staff.  The play serves as a springboard for discussion as it leads its audience to reevaluate their thoughts and opinions regarding the themes of mental health that are portrayed.

Contributions of any size help us create this much needed forum for conversation and storytelling with a talented team of artists who will use film, music, lighting, puppetry, and dance to tell this story.  Our funding will go towards the rights of the production, theater rental, rehearsal space, technical equipment and payment of artists and staff.

Our Team includes:

PRODUCER: Nino Gurgenidze and Jonathan Zautner

Assistant Producer: Laura Delhauer 

DIRECTOR: Jonathan Zautner

MOVEMENT DIRECTORS: Kendra Slack and Jordan Chlapecka

MUSIC: Begi Moniava

Video Art: Mushroomalien Productions 

ACTORS: Laura Delhauer, Nino Gurgenidze, Joshua James, Jamie Roach

Future plans for this production include an educational tour with organizations and colleges to continue to lift stigmas and  promote empathy.  

 For tickets visit 448psychosisnyc.bpt.me

story:
THEATRE N16

Theatre N16 was set up at the start of 2015 to "give hope to theatre makers who had been priced out of making work" Their model was to find a way to provide the lowest overheads possible for a company in London. 

Headed by Jamie Eastlake,

 https://www.thestage.co.uk/opinion/2016/jamie-e...

the theatre grew from strength to strength, offering as a startup for hundreds and hundreds of artists. 

The stats

178 DIFFERENT PRODUCTIONS 
132 Theatre Companies on risk free deals 
1500 Artists
140 Directors 
110 New Writers
17 Technicians 
200 first credits for actors cvs 
25 Actors on Equity contracts for in house productions
28,000 People through the doors and rising  
11 BSL performances 
3 cheap Rehearsal spaces 
42 Number of productions transferred

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are in the process of looking for a new space  it's vital that we secure one by the end of the new year when our agreement with our current building runs out. However to move a full theatre, pay deposits and to allow for us to make a new space the best it possibly can be for audiences and theatre makers we need to find the funds.

A fundraising campaign and a call out to all those people who have worked with us isn't our biggest hope of getting funds we need to move.

A selection of perks are also on offer on the side to add to that warm fuzzy feeling when you donate.

We are extremely confident of finding a new home but if the worst possible scenario happens and we do not, we will refund every last penny pledged. We are theatre n16 though, and we will find one.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Finding a home isn't hard work, we are open to any suggestions that people have! Have an idea? Email jamie@theatren16.co.uk
  • Tell your mates, share on social media, you just never know who may see it!

And that's all there is to it. We are theatre n16. And we're  going to do this. 

 

Read our press release below:

 

Theatre N16 are looking for a new home

After over 178 productions and over 28,000 audience members through the door since moving to the Bedford in 2015, Theatre N16 is looking for a new home from December 2017.

Theatre N16 was set up in 2015 to be a stomping ground for new companies and a place to try out new work, offering affordable deals on rehearsal and performance space. It has offered a ground-breaking, risk-free deal to all companies, which 95% of our guests have taken, guaranteeing that creatives do not leave our space owing the venue money. This is all under the auspices of an Equity Fringe Agreement, with Theatre N16 one of the few London venues to have signed up to the deal to guarantee pay to all creatives working for the venue.

Within this structure, Theatre N16 has offered performance space to 110 new writers, with over 200 first credits for new and young performers, and 42 productions transferring into other venues all over the world. In reaction to industry issues, they have started encouraging and promoting more successfully for female directors and writers, and worked hard to find productions and casting processes that favour BAME performers.

“The increasingly important Theatre N16” British Theatre

Executive director Jamie Eastlake says: “I was sick to death of watching theatre companies get ripped off under business models that relied on funding the theatre first. Instead, we kept finding new innovative ideas to keep a space open. The fringe is the lifeblood of theatre. Having good solid fringe theatre models is what creates new work and new artists and feeds the West End.“

Now, the new owners of The Bedford, Theatre N16’s home for the last two years, have decided to redevelop the pub. The theatre is looking for a new home, to continue their model of offering affordable space to give creatives a first rung on the ladder. Jamie Eastlake says: “This is a call to arms. We have to find somewhere - and we need help.”

"There's a clear passion radiating from this venue" View From The Gods

Anybody who knows of a suitable space or is interested in becoming a patron of the theatre to help us find a new venue, please email jamie@theatren16.co.uk.

 

Venue Box Office Travel

Theatre N16, The Bedford Pub, 77 Bedford Hill, London SW12 9HD Line Up Now (lineupnow.com/venue/atre-n16/)

Balham station (2 min walk) Streatham Hill station (20 min walk)

www.theatren16.co.uk / +44 7969138899 / theatren16@gmail.com

chris.hislop@gmail.com www.chrishislop.com

story:
As Is at Bedlam Theatre, 2015

Mice On A Beam is a not-for-profit business partnership working to challenge, educate and entertain audiences through the medium of excellent theatre. We believe good art is inescapably valuable to provide information without being aggressive or forcing a political agenda, to provoke and stimulate discussion, creating a safe space to start not being afraid of the big issues anymore – and we are going to support our audiences to come with us on that journey.

This year we are taking our first full-length show, As Is by William M. Hoffman, to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. As Is was one of the first plays to stand up and talk about the AIDS crisis and its devastating impact on the people of New York City. In its 30th anniversary year, Mice On A Beam Theatre Company transports 1980s New York to the Edinburgh Fringe.
This play is so important to us because it tells the story of the politics and crisis of AIDS in the US in the 1980s - but that's not all it is. It's a human story, about a community of interlinked people and the impact of the crisis on them, and how to build an unconventional family around you in difficult times. Most importantly, it's a story about love - and how to love someone 'as is', whatever's going on, whoever they are.

As it is, as it was... about the play

I was at the gym soaking in the hot tub when I first heard about AIDS. It was how many years ago now? My friend Brian - remember him? - was soaking, too, and he told me about a mutual friend who had died the week before. It was "bizarre" he said. Brian died last week of the same thing. And he and I once soaked in the same hot tub, making a kind of human soup...

New York, 1985. Rich, a writer who is beginning to find success, is breaking up with Saul, his long-time partner. However, his idyll with his new lover is short-lived when Rich is diagnosed with AIDS and turns back to Saul for sanctuary.

Greenwich Village was the centre for movements that have challenged the wider American culture and the cradle of the modern LGBT movement (as well as the original site for the Off-Off-Broadway Theatre movement and a rejection of commercial theatre!). As Is brings it rekindles 1980’s Village life to life in Edinburgh this year, through lights, textures, graffiti and a vibrant 80s soundtrack. Prejudice and injustice, ignorance, compassion and understanding are played out in a sparkling and rhythmic tapestry, confronting us with the stark realities of Rich’s life and the people around him. Packed with determination in the face of adversity, the ensemble cast highlight the immediacy of a time in which a whole community feared for its life.

Ground-breaking when it premiered, As Is remains an honest, unsparing and sharply funny examination of sexuality, death, and what it means to love someone for now, for the moment, for always, in sickness and in health – as is.

What We Need & What You Get

We are thrilled to be paying our team for As Is national minimum wage, plus profit share up to Equity/ITC minimum. But with a cast of eight, plus a stage manager, director, producer, designers... it adds up. Factor in audiovisual costs, set, props, costume, box office guarantees, royalties, accommodation and travel, marketing and publicity costs, rehearsal space and we are looking to raise at least £35,000 to be able to get our show up and running.

We need your help - in fact, we can't do this without you. Every contribution will go straight towards the show, from set building to costumes to rehearsal space hire to fees for our amazing team to that Barcelona chair they keep talking about.

We need your help to act as ambassadors of our mission, and to donate towards making this work happen. Cuts are ravaging the creative heart of the arts industry. The best way to fight back is to have the courage and ambition to keep practicing, and ethically – but your financial reinforcement is the only way to progress this.

Make a gift towards As Is and let us bring you closer to our work in a number of ways. We'd also like to offer some special As Is souvenirs - let us know what you'd like and we'll see if we can make it happen!

We are also happy to discuss more personalised approaches to acknowledge the incredible support of a leadership gift for more information on this please contact milla@miceonabeam.co.uk.

Just to give you some context:

£10 could pay for an hour of rehearsal space hire

£60 could get one of our actors to Edinburgh

£100 could get our set to Edinburgh

£300 could mean we have publicity materials for the show

£600 could pay for our set

£1,000 could pay an actor’s fee at National Minimum Wage

The Impact

We want HIV/AIDS back on the agenda - and we want it coming from a place of love and understanding.

We want to use our show to create a new discussion platform through the arts. Arts and information work well together, to be provocative, raise difficult issues in a way that's more accessible than a public information talk, and stimulate discussion. To achieve this, we need to make powerful and beautiful art, with a real story at its heart - and we believe As Is is the way to do it.

Live storytelling has always been the most powerful tool for people to broach subjects difficult to fully understand or talk about. We want people to leave this play talking about HIV/AIDS - not in fear, but wanting to find out more.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially - but you can still support the show!

As our aim is that people will leave this play wanting to talk and find out more about HIV/AIDS, we want to complement this with outreach work and collaboration with other organisations. We are seeking sponsors to be able to provide free condoms, information materials, and HIV home testing kits for our audience members, and for them to be able to distribute further afield should they wish to. 

If you can help with any of the above, or organising an event, or just spreading the word about our campaign and our show, your contribution will really help us!

Thank you so much.

As Is at Bedlam Theatre, 2015


Mice
On A Beam is a not-for-profit business partnership working to challenge,
educate and entertain audiences through the medium of excellent theatre. We
believe good art is inescapably valuable to provide information without being
aggressive or forcing a political agenda, to provoke and stimulate discussion, creating
a safe space to start not being afraid of the big issues anymore – and we are
going to support our audiences to come with us on that journey.
This
year we are taking our first full-length show, As Is by William M. Hoffman, to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. As Is was one of the first plays to stand up and talk about the AIDS crisis and its devastating impact on the people of New York City. In its 30th anniversary year, Mice On A Beam Theatre Company transports 1980s New York to the Edinburgh Fringe.This play is so important to us because it tells the story of the politics and crisis of AIDS in the US in the 1980s - but that's not all it is. It's a human story, about a community of interlinked people and the impact of the crisis on them, and how to build an unconventional family around you in difficult times. Most importantly, it's a story about love - and how to love someone 'as is', whatever's going on, whoever they are.
As it is, as it was... about the play 
I was at
the gym soaking in the hot tub when I first heard about AIDS. It was how many
years ago now? My friend Brian - remember him? - was soaking, too, and he told
me about a mutual friend who had died the week before. It was
"bizarre" he said. Brian died last week of the same thing. And he and
I once soaked in the same hot tub, making a kind of human soup...

New York, 1985. Rich, a writer who is
beginning to find success, is breaking up with Saul, his long-time partner.
However, his idyll with his new lover is short-lived when Rich is diagnosed
with AIDS and turns back to Saul for sanctuary.
Greenwich Village was the centre
for movements that have challenged the wider American culture and the
cradle of the modern LGBT movement (as well as the original site for the
Off-Off-Broadway Theatre movement and a rejection of commercial theatre!). As Is brings it rekindles 1980’s Village
life to life in Edinburgh this year, through lights, textures, graffiti and a
vibrant 80s soundtrack. Prejudice and injustice, ignorance, compassion and
understanding are played out in a sparkling and rhythmic tapestry, confronting
us with the stark realities of Rich’s life and the people around him. Packed
with determination in the face of adversity, the ensemble cast highlight the immediacy of a time in which a whole
community feared for its life.
Ground-breaking when it premiered, As Is remains an honest, unsparing and
sharply funny examination of sexuality, death, and what it means to love
someone for now, for the moment, for always, in sickness and in health – as is.
   What We Need & What You Get 

We are thrilled
to be paying our team for As Is
national minimum wage, plus profit share up to Equity/ITC minimum. But with
a cast of eight, plus a stage manager, director, producer, designers... it adds up. Factor in audiovisual costs, set, props, costume,
box office guarantees, royalties, accommodation and travel, marketing and
publicity costs, rehearsal space and we are looking to raise at least £35,000
to be able to get our show up and running.
We need your help - in fact, we can't do this without you. Every contribution will go straight towards the show, from set building to costumes to rehearsal space hire to fees for our amazing team to that Barcelona chair they keep talking about.


We
need your help to act as ambassadors of our mission, and to donate towards
making this work happen. Cuts are ravaging the creative heart of the arts
industry. The best way to fight back is to have the courage and ambition to
keep practicing, and ethically – but your financial reinforcement is the only
way to progress this.


Make
a gift towards As Is and let us bring you closer to our work in a number of ways. We'd also like to offer some special As Is souvenirs - let us know what you'd like and we'll see if we can make it happen!
We
are also happy to discuss more personalised approaches to acknowledge the
incredible support of a leadership gift for more information on this please contact milla@miceonabeam.co.uk.
Just
to give you some context:
£10 could pay for an hour of rehearsal
space hire
£60 could get one of our actors to
Edinburgh
£100 could get our set to Edinburgh
£300 could mean we have publicity
materials for the show
£600 could pay for our set
£1,000 could pay an actor’s fee at
National Minimum Wage   The Impact 
We want
HIV/AIDS back on the agenda - and we want it coming from a place of love and understanding.
We want to use our show to create a new discussion platform through the arts. Arts and information work well together, to be provocative, raise difficult issues in a way that's more accessible than a public information talk, and stimulate discussion. To achieve this, we need to make powerful and beautiful art, with a real story at its heart - and we believe As Is is the way to do it.
Live storytelling has always been the most powerful tool for people to broach subjects difficult to fully understand or talk about. We want people to leave this play talking about HIV/AIDS - not in fear, but wanting to find out more.

    Other Ways You Can Help We understand that not everyone can contribute financially - but you can still support the show!


As our aim is that people will
leave this play wanting to talk and find out more about HIV/AIDS, we want to
complement this with outreach work and collaboration with other organisations. We are seeking sponsors to be able to provide free condoms, information
materials, and HIV home testing kits for our audience members, and for them to
be able to distribute further afield should they wish to. 
If you can help with any of the above, or organising an event, or just spreading the word about our campaign and our show, your contribution will really help us!
Thank you so much.

story:
We decided to just go for it!

Back in 2007, my wife and I got together with some crazy friends and we decided to do something different. We created a show that merges all the things that make us happy: live music, stand-up and sketch comedy, in a playful, fun, rockin' night. And it was great! We've done over 20 different live productions of the Rick Younger Show. 

But Shows in NYC are hard to maintain

Producing a show is expensive, and doing it in NYC is even more so. And we never ask our artist friends to do us a favor. We feel that musicians and performers are valuable, and we offer them some payment (however small) for performing with us. So, for years, we did the show regardless, even if we look a loss. But we can't keep doing that. That's where you come in. Here's what we need: 

  • We need to pay the BAND! "Love Bucket" is a phenomenal six-piece band, whose members have played on Broadway and with Rock Stars. Seriously, this is a great band. 
  • We need to pay the guest performers! We have an incredible team of talented, working actors who create sketches and characters just for this show. 
  • We need to pay the babysitter!!! Rory's not big enough for this show yet. 

The Impact

You aren't JUST supporting just us. There are over 12 artists working on this show, and crowds of people who need to see it! The Rick Younger Show brings joy and laughter to everyone who joins the ride. Let's be on it together! 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't donate, please spread the word! Post a link to the ticket page, or this page on Facebook and Twitter. And tell your friends - they deserve a night out! 
  • Please come out to see the show! May 13th at 9pm!

story:
Sunday, September 13, 2015

11:30 AM - 9 PM
The Detroit Opera House Black Box & Sky Deck
1526 Broadway Street, Detroit, MI

The Inaugural Kick-Off Event aims to introduce the MITTEN Lab to the Michigan community and establish the Lab’s relationship with the city of Detroit. 

The all-day event is free and open to the public (with a suggested donation of $5 per event or $20 for the day). Space is limited, so reservations are encouraged. For reservations, visit our website, www.themittenlab.org.

The event will feature:

·  Panel discussions with early career theatre artists and Michigan-based theatre professionals exploring the art form’s current position within Detroit’s artistic renaissance; the city’s theatrical legacy; the nebulous“emerging artist” label; and how the state is nurturing the next generation of theatre artists. Participants will include: Monet Hurst-Mendoza (playwright), Stefanie Abel Horowitz (director), Emilio Rodriguez (playwright), and artistic leaders from Matrix Theater Company, Theatre Nova, Performance Network, the Detroit Public Theatre, Activate Midwest Festival/Western Michigan University, and more.

·  A staged reading of the new play, BLIND CREST, by playwright Monet Hurst-Mendoza in the Chrysler Black Box Theater.

·  A reception on the Sky Deck with a presentation of selected songs from the new musical, REZONING, by native Michigander, the composer/lyricist Matthew Dean Marsh. Catering will be provided by Sweet Lorraine's Cafe & Bar.


     

We can't make our vision for The MITTEN Lab a reality without you! Your contributions to the Kick-Off Event will help us cover:

-  Rental of the Detroit Opera House's Chrysler Black Box and Sky Deck

- Artists' travel

- Marketing/Advertising the Event

- Supplies & Equipment

Your generous support will directly benefit the inception of The MITTEN Lab, providing with us essential relationships and resources in our infancy to nurture and empower the next generation of theatre artists, and in turn, the wider creative community. 


The MITTEN Lab (A Michigan Incubator for Theatre Talent Emerging Now) is an artist residency in Northern Michigan aimed at providing emerging theatre artists with the time, space, and support to develop new theatrical works.

In the summer of 2016, The MITTEN Lab will officially launch on 60 acres of rural land in lush Bear Lake, MI (located 20 miles south of Interlochen). These projects can vary in degree of development—from the seed of an idea to a final draft. Housing, studio space, and food will be provided. 

    

                                  The Pond at The Mitten Lab. Bear Lake, MI.

The MITTEN Lab will focus on the cultivation of new works by early career playwrights, theatre composers, lyricists, librettists, choreographers, and performance artists. Artists from all across the country may attend, although the Lab will consistently support at least one Michigan artist per year. The MITTEN Lab will begin by working with 3 artists in 2016, expanding to include more artists and longer residencies in subsequent years. Participation will begin by invitation only, and ultimately lead to an open application process.

Work-in-progress presentations of work created at the MITTEN Lab will be showcased at Bear Lake as well as various venues in Detroit.  Michigan has a vibrant arts and cultural scene, and with the revitalization of Detroit, it is our intention to play a part in reshaping Michigan as a national center for new and exciting theatrical work again. It's time to put Michigan theatre back on the map.



·  Although there are a number of residency opportunities available for artists in the U.S., few emphasize the development of early career artists who have yet to reach any significant level of public recognition or acclaim.

·  Many existing theater residencies cater to the already emerged, mid-career artist.

·  There is an over-saturation of early career theatre artists in major cities, like NYC, trying to present work.

· Michigan's creative economy is undergoing a "once-in-a-generation transformation", according to the Michigan Council for Arts and Cultural Affairs. However, there is still a deficiency of new theatrical work showcased in Michigan. 

·  Detroit has a powerful theatrical history: The Nederlander Organization, one of the three commercial Broadway theatre owners, has its roots in Detroit and continues to operate the historic Detroit Opera House as well as the Fisher Theater, where such Broadway hits as Hello Dolly! and Fiddler on the Roof premiered before moving to Broadway. Detroit boasts many theater venues dating back to the turn of the 20th century, though many have been demolished, re-purposed (i.e. the infamous Michigan Garage) or still await restoration.


Katherine Carter (Co-Founder) - Katherine is a Michigan born, New York based director. She is the founding Artistic Director of The Other Mirror, and the co-founding Artistic Director of The MITTEN Lab. Katherine is a two-time director in the Directors Company Adaptations for the Stage Workshop, the 2011-2012 Playwrights Horizons Directing Resident, a Drama League Rough Draft Fellow, and a current a guest director at New York University’s Stella Adler and Atlantic Schools.  www.KatherineMCarter.com

Rachel Sussman (Co-Founder) - A native of Michigan, Rachel is a New York-based producer. Most recently, she produced the acclaimed run of Strangemen & Co.’s THE WOODSMAN (59E59). Rachel is a co-founder of The Indigo Theatre Project and has worked with Second Stage Theatre, Goodspeed Musicals' Mercer Colony, The Sundance Institute Theatre Lab, Lincoln Center's American Songbook, The Tony Awards, the New York Musical Theatre Festival, and CREATE-Ireland in Dublin, Ireland. Currently, she is the Manager of Creative Development at RKO Stage and a 2014-2016 Women’s Project Producer Lab Time Warner Fellow. www.rachel-sussman.com

The MITTEN Lab is a past participant in the Alliance of Artist Communities' Emerging Program Institute.

Special thanks to Jay Eisenberg and Eric Frankel in putting this campaign together.

story:
Short Summary 

During a recent photography workshop in Cuba, I attempted to capture the unique images and vibrant colors of this wonderful culture. The photographer’s “usual suspects” included the Malécon overlooking Havana harbor, the stalled-in-time automobiles, and the extraordinary architecture. These served up daily feasts for the eyes and the lens, but the unexpected highlight of my trip (and the purpose of this appeal) is best represented in this image: a tattered ballet slipper worn by an extraordinary young dancer.

The youth rehearsals of ProDanza, Havana’s 460-member ballet academy, are as breathtaking as any other vista in Cuba. Music and dance are Havana’s primary cultural expression and I came away from my trip determined to honor this cultural jewel and unconditional artistic generosity in a tangible way.   

The young members of ProDanza sorely (literally and figuratively) need the kinds of basics that dancers elsewhere take for granted. Watching these beautiful young artists practice their craft in such distressed equipment- or with no support whatsoever- galvanized me.  Please read this inspiring story to learn more about the situation at ProDanza.

http://www.worldartstoday.com/dance/dancing-dre...

As Cuba begins to reconnect with the outside world. the gift of proper pointe shoes would speak volumes about our hopes for the school’s future, and for our support of the arts in its country.

Currently, the best way to get supplies to these dancers is hand-carried in travelers’ luggage. I have found a great partner in Malia Everette of AltruVistas, who sends many travelers to Cuba each month, who are each able to take a couple of pairs of shoes in their luggage.

By contributing to this campaign, you will allow these young dancers to pursue their dreams. Some Cuban ballet dancers have become members of American and international ballet companies.  Some examples are Alicia Alonso, Jose Manuel Carreño, Lorena and Lorna Feijoo, Julio Arozarena, Vladimir Alvarez, Alahydee Carreño and Xiomara Reyes. After retiring, Cuban dancers have even founded American Ballet Schools. 

What We Need & What You Receive in Return

•    I am asking for $10,000 for shoes, leotards, tights, and other dance supplies, and to set up a continuing support program with this Academy.  Although US/Cuba relations are improving, it is unlikely that the Academy will have regular access to these basic supplies for quite some time. Pointe shoes break down very quickly, especially without sufficient drying time between uses.  Donating just $25 could purchase a pair of pointe shoes. If we meet our goal, We could provide 400 pairs of shoes or 250 pairs of shoes and 200 leotards! Of course it would be fantastic if we can raise more than $10,000 as we want to make this a continuing project.  Detailed accounting of where the money is spent will be kept, and made available to donors upon request.

•     Our backers will receive a memento for their donation, and we are exploring ideas ranging from a postcard from one of my photos signed by a ProDanza student (who may go on to become a prima ballerina) to an original Peter Turnley print, signed by the artist. 

•      All of the donated funds will be used to help the school, including minimal travel costs for myself to Cuba, where we will host a small reception at the Ludwig Foundation in Havana on November 12, 2015 to introduce the ProDanza staff and students to members of the press and community.  

The Impact

The impact of this project will be immediate, as the clothes and equipment that your support allows us to purchase will be brought to the school on November 11th, but that is only the beginning of what we hope to be a fulfilling relationship for the school and the people of the USA, specifically our generous donors. Proper shoes will go a long way in allowing these young limbs to dance safely and to continue to grow in their skills.

As you may have heard, the infrastructure in Havana is in shaky condition. Every day about 30 buildings crumble.  Although the Academy is relatively stable, it would be wonderful to help with structural improvements that are necessary as well.  

In the future I would like to arrange a trip of interested people to experience firsthand the beauty that survives in Havana, lending a few hours to being with the students and maybe even wielding a paintbrush to say that you put actual work into preserving this beautiful school.

Risks & Challenges

There are few risks involved here as I will take all equipment that I have acquired to Havana on November 11th. The challenges are: connecting with larger sponsors, such as Capezio, who can offer donations of clothing or discount pricing on a larger scale. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 If you are unable to contribute money, there are other ways to help!  

Please share the Indiegogo link with friends via email, Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and Instagram

Like and share our Facebook page on Social Media.

Take advantage of the share tools Indiegogo provides.
