story:
Introducing the first Krampus musical comedy and supporting album of Krampus carols


The Musical

An Evening with Krampus is a musical comedy about the story of Krampus, an ancient demon of Austrian and Germanic lore that emerges every December 5th (Krampusnacht) to punish bad children and provide terror to all! The musical is a celebration of Krampus told through a narrative involving a horribly behaved child named Timmy, Timmy's mom, an escaped child, a psychotic neighbor, Krampus the demon and Noel, his faithful elf assistant that only sings and never speaks.  Will old Saint Nicholas even make an appearance? Find out!

The musical stars an all-Minneapolis cast of musicians and actors and will debut at the Phoenix Theater on December 5, 2015 as a part of an alternative holiday festival, and run for 5 performances:


Saturday, December 5th at 7:30pm
Wednesday, December 9th at 7:30pm
Saturday, December 12th at 5:00pm
Sunday, December 13th at 7:30pm
Sunday, December 20th at 2:30pm

Starring: Andrew Newman, Jessica Blum, Anna Lakin, Robb Krueger, Ali Daniels, Nicole Goeden, Madee Weisner, Corey DiNardo

The Album

In addition to the musical, a brand new album of 11 Krampus songs will be released in late 2015/early 2016. It features all of the songs from the musical to be used as Krampus carols in your home! Each song is an original composition (no Christmas music or parodies) in various styles: bluegrass, folk, classical, rock, blues, even a Johann Strauss Jr.-inspired waltz. The CD will feature 17 musicians from Minneapolis and Chicago:

Darren Bartolo, clarinet, piano
Mark Bilyeu, piano
Phil Boulanger, cello
Tyler Cessor, saxophone
Reba Clamp, vocals
Darlene Diamond, oboe
Mike Duffy, bass
Ashlee Hardgrave, vocals 
Jeremy Johnston, percussion
David Keller, cello
Sam Krahn, banjo, bass, vocals, guitars, ukulele, compositions
Ben Osterhouse, cello
Neil Qiang, piano
Tyler Ravelson, vocals
Maria Ritzenthaler, viola
Tiffany Skidmore, vocals
Justin Spenner, vocals

Amanda Lust, illustration and design

Listen to demo excerpts of all songs here: 
https://soundcloud.com/aneveningwithkrampus


Why?

The project began in Chicago as a reaction to the commercialism of the Christmas season and a way for Sam Krahn, the composer, to create an alternative holiday presence while bringing local musicians together during November and December. Several songs came first, then the project evolved into a musical with the involvement of Tyler Ravelson with script writing. A few years later, the musical is finally ready to be performed under the direction of Jenna Papke at the Phoenix Theater, and the songs are ready to be fully recorded, edited and released. 


What you can do

Your support will directly fund the musical performances and the album. These funds will be used for props, costumes, payment for the actors and musicians on both the recording and performances, and costs associated with recording, mastering, and CD production. We're trying to raise at least $5000 to fund the project which will comfortably produce the CD and musical. These costs include: 


$1000 mixing and mastering
$1000 CD production
$1500 for musicians in the recording and live musical performance
$1500 for the actors, props, and costumes

All funding we receive will directly pay the musicians and actors involved in this project and will allow for the release of the album. If we do not meet the funding goal, we will still perform the shows (Krampus goes on!) but musician involvement will be limited and the album release will be postponed for a future date. 


What do you get if you fund us?

Well, not only will you contribute to the Krampus project, but you will also receive some great perks. Here are some of the options: 
1. Download of a song from the album
2. Download of the entire album
3. Physical copy and download of the entire album
4. Tickets to the show in December! 
5. Meet the actors at our opening party
6. Come to a rehearsal at the Phoenix Theater in Minneapolis
7. Personal coffee outing with Sam Krahn, composer, and Jenna Papke, director
(sorry, travel to Minneapolis is not included)


Can't fund us but are excited about this project?

Great! You can still contribute by spreading the word and telling others about the Krampus project and fundraiser! Are you a theater interested in future performances of An Evening with Krampus? Definitely get in touch! 

Help start a new tradition of Krampus worldwide with the first Krampus musical, An Evening with Krampus. Bring your community together through Krampusnacht and leave Santa at home this year. 


About Sam Krahn

Sam Krahn is a Minneapolis based guitarist, performer, composer, and teacher. He is a founding member of the Minneapolis composer collective 113. His works have been performed by members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the Fidelio Trio, Ensemble Uusinta, Ensemble Dal Niente, Duo Gelland, Tony Steve, Christina Baldwin, Lara Bolton, Benjamin Cold, Lux String Quartet, Rappel-Steinmetz Percussion Duo, Contemporary Music Workshop, the Anaphora Ensemble, the Eugene Contemporary Chamber Ensemble, and many others. He has received numerous commissions to compose new works for Ed Harrison of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra (Maraca Concerto), Duo Gelland (Resistance/Resonance), the Fidelio Trio (Trio), Harper College (Spring Dirge), Benjamin Cold (flux-mirror), and the Anaphora Contemporary Ensemble (String Quartet No. 1). He participated in the 17th World Saxophone Congress and Festival, the New York City Electroacoustic Music Festival, the MATA Festival in New York City, the Source Song Festival in Minneapolis, the 2015 Root Signals Electronic Music Festival, and the 70th annual Cheltenham Music Festival in England. He most recently received a grant from New Music USA for a new 35-minute work for saxophone and electronics. He has participated in artist residencies in 2015 at the Millay Colony in New York and Brush Creek in Wyoming. 

Sam recently received a Ph.D. in music composition at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities, studying with James Dillon. He also holds a M.Mus. in music composition from Roosevelt University where he studied with Stacy Garrop and Kyong Mee Choi, and a B.Mus. in classical guitar performance from Boston University. Sam is a classically trained and experienced guitarist. He has played in numerous rock bands, classical ensembles, improvisational groups, and as a soloist. Sam also continues to create new music with his improvisation trio, Sound Collision Alliance.
story_txt:
Introducing the first Krampus musical comedy and supporting album of Krampus carolsThe Musical

An Evening with Krampus is a musical comedy about the story of Krampus, an ancient demon of Austrian and Germanic lore that emerges every December 5th (Krampusnacht) to punish bad children and provide terror to all! The musical is a celebration of
Krampus told through a narrative involving a horribly behaved child named
Timmy, Timmy's mom, an escaped child, a psychotic neighbor, Krampus the demon and Noel,
his faithful elf assistant that only sings and never speaks.  Will old Saint
Nicholas even make an appearance? Find out!The musical stars an all-Minneapolis cast of musicians and actors and will debut at the Phoenix Theater on December 5, 2015 as a part of an alternative holiday festival, and run for 5 performances:

Saturday, December 5th at 7:30pmWednesday, December 9th at 7:30pmSaturday, December 12th at 5:00pmSunday, December 13th at 7:30pmSunday, December 20th at 2:30pmStarring: Andrew Newman, Jessica Blum, Anna Lakin, Robb Krueger, Ali Daniels, Nicole Goeden, Madee Weisner, Corey DiNardoThe Album

In addition to the musical, a brand new album of 11 Krampus songs will be released in late 2015/early 2016. It features all of the songs from the musical to be used as Krampus carols in your home! Each song is an original composition (no Christmas music or parodies) in various styles: bluegrass, folk, classical, rock, blues, even a Johann Strauss Jr.-inspired waltz. The CD will feature 17 musicians from Minneapolis and Chicago:
Darren Bartolo, clarinet, pianoMark Bilyeu, pianoPhil Boulanger, celloTyler Cessor, saxophoneReba Clamp, vocalsDarlene Diamond, oboeMike Duffy, bassAshlee Hardgrave, vocals Jeremy Johnston, percussionDavid Keller, celloSam Krahn, banjo, bass, vocals, guitars, ukulele, compositionsBen Osterhouse, celloNeil Qiang, pianoTyler Ravelson, vocalsMaria Ritzenthaler, violaTiffany Skidmore, vocalsJustin Spenner, vocals

story:
Broadway Bound Dance Company (DBA) Front Street Dance Center, located in Wheaton Illinois is a 501C3 not for profit dance studio. Our mission is to educate young dancers and bring the joy and art of dance to the community. Our program is more than a dance program, we create a dance family where everyone is welcomed and accepted. Our students and families develop friendships that can last a lifetime, and our studio in turn becomes a safe place where parents know their children are going to grow into confident accomplished adults.

  Based in ballet, we also offer jazz, tap, contemporary and hip hop. Promoting strong technique has been our platform for the success of our studio and our performing dance troupe. Keeping the children’s best interests in mind, we set high standards for our staff and our studio. It is our belief to allow children to be children, so therefore we keep our music, choreography and costuming age appropriate.

As part of our mission we offer a scholarship program for dancers and their families that are facing financial challenges and may need financial assistance. Therefore we have created a program that allows all children to dance no matter what challenges families may be facing. To fund these scholarships we rely heavily on donations from the community. These donations are used to provide the instruction and costuming required for students to succeed in dance.

We are seeking funding to help provide scholarships for those families in need. We hope that you can help us achieve our goal in this campaign, as any donation is greatly appreciated by all of us here at Front Street Dance Center. The greater sense of self-esteem and accomplishment that is gained through this instruction is immeasurable for each and every child whose lives we have the ability to impact.

story:
The beloved 1975 musical "A Chorus Line" (Music by Marvin Hamlisch, Lyrics by Edward Kleban, Book by James Kirkwood Jr, and Nicholas Dante) turned 40 in 2015!  We are celebrating the 9 time Tony Award winning musical with a fresh adaptation directed by Tom Rowan this coming February at The Secret Theatre in Long Island City!  In order for this record breaking musical to have a New York production once again, we need funds to make the jazz hands happen!


Why do a funding campaign?

We need $5,000 dollars (flexible) to make this production as historically accurate and high quality as possible. Unfortunately the facts of life for an off off Broadway production at a off off house are that its extremely difficult to finance and guarantee a profit. Equity rules restrict us to $18 top ticket price so even if we sell out a lot of nights it will be a very close shave between losing, breaking even or making [a little] money.

You get to invest in a spectacular production directed by an official A Chorus Line expert and author on the subject and one of the fabulous perks listed in our perks section!

The Impact

A Chorus Line is a revolutionary show that not only epitomizes the life and spirit of a dancer trying to make it in New York, but tells stories of growing up and humanity and has touched the souls and hearts of millions.  The show debuted in 1975 and was nominated for 12 Tony Awards, and won 9, including best Direction and Choreography of a musical by Michael Bennett.  The original production, produced by Joe Papp, ran for 6,137 performances, and was the longest running Broadway show until Cats surpassed it over 20 years later.  

Risks & Challenges

We want to make this production as historically accurate as possible.  A Chorus Line impacted the world of theatre and we want to be able to pay our respects to the well renowned show. As our director, Tom Rowan is the author of the newly released "A Chorus Line: FAQ" book, full of historically accurate information about all aspects of the musical, accuracy is very important to us.  Anyone who is familiar with the musical, knows the triumphant and spectacular finale, which involves high quality props and lots of rehearsal time.  Out of respect for the musical, we would like to emulate this scene as well as the entire show to the best of our abilities; sparkly costumes, TopHats, and all!

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to funds, we need the word spread for our production!  This is a great musical and this will be a great production!  Share our page, tell your friends, come out and support us this February!

story:
Who are we and what are we doing?           

Hey friends! We are Sheldon Carpenter and Ilyssa DePonte, co-founders of Torrent Theatre. We, Torrent Theatre, are a continuously-growing collective of artists who strive to produce art that challenges the status quo. We aim to create theatre that not only speaks to our audience, but also germinates a dialogue within our audience and causes them to think about the trajectory of mankind as a whole.  What has come to be expected of us? Have we fallen into a trap - a vicious cycle of repetitive actions? Do we cling to tradition, or do we as individuals choose to resist that cycle and flood the mind in order to spark a change in our society?

After the success of our inaugural production of Neil LaBute’s Reasons To Be Pretty in September of 2015, we are embarking on a new journey - Mindflood, a short play project! Stitching together the work of nine playwrights from across the nation and exploring everything from friendship to gender roles, family lies to censorship, addressing the United States healthcare system and incorporating a piece so moving it leaves even our actors speechless, Mindflood is an assemblage of eight short plays, calling attention to socially prevalent issues and topics. 

Production Breakdown

Asking For It by Rhea MacCallum

When a young woman reports that she’s been the victim of a hit and run driver she is met with an unexpected and intrusive interrogation.  Asking For It explores the question of, “What if we treated the victims of other crimes the same way we treat rape victims?”  

Bromancing the OK by Joe Salvatore

Jeff and Matt, two young Wall Street traders, have been roommates since college. A late-night discussion in front of the TV reveals a deepening relationship between Matt and his girlfriend. When the men start to talk about their own relationship, the complexities of two straight men having a long term friendship begin to reveal themselves.

Emergency Room by Jeff Stolzer

An ordinary man unwittingly falls victim to a nightmarish system when he finds himself in a hospital emergency room following a minor accident. Fortunately, the man's health checks out fine; unfortunately, his attempt to actually check out of the facility faces complications that are decidedly not of the medical variety.

Family Archive by Ann Marie Shea

Ginny, a successful family practice lawyer, and her beloved younger sister, Molly, are at odds as to how to handle the physical detritus cluttering their late mother’s house. Ginny would gladly toss the whole mess, whereas Molly finds sentimental attachment to every scrap of paper. When Molly finds a discrepancy between the documentary evidence and the oral folklore of the family, Ginny is forced to give up a secret that is at the heart of this fractured family.

Fiancé(e) by Siobhan O’Hara

This play follows the story of Daniel and Rebecca, two people who are both eager to spend the rest of their lives together but not before hitting a few bumps. When confronted with his girlfriend's proposal of marriage in front of his friends and family during Thanksgiving, Daniel's manhood is threatened, causing a riff in the young couples love life and putting a strain on the family dinner. This play puts a comedic spin on gender roles and how we as a society view their purpose. Is Rebecca out of line? Is Daniel's manhood really at stake? 

Katherine and Peter by Gianfranco Lentini

On the night of her engagement party, Katherine realizes what she’s been running from can no longer be outrun. The last six years of her life have brought her to this moment.  Peter, a previously hurt man, is thrown right back into where he barely made it out alive six years prior. The man he’s become wants nothing more to do with where he’s been.  They both seek to answer questions that might very well not have answers at all. And to ask these questions could be just the mistake to ruin everything they’ve built.

The Train by Irene L. Pynn

"The Train" is a dumbshow that has been produced in Florida and Texas. It uses sound effects and music paired with actor movements to tell the story of two lonely people trapped in a crowded subway at rush hour. 

Trash by Justice Hehir and Alyssa Krompier

When two young women are stationed to pick up trash for court-mandated community service, they find common ground as they sift through things left behind, discarded, or misplaced.

It’s comedic, it’s tender, it’s poignant and you will feel so many emotions, but we NEED your help to make this short play project happen!

Who’s On Our Team? 

Director/Co-Producer - Sheldon Carpenter

Production Manager/Sonic Artist - Ilyssa DePonte

Production Stage Manager - Joseph McCabe

Playwrights - Justice Hehir 

          Alyssa Krompier

          Gianfranco Lentini

          Rhea MacCallum 

          Siobhan O’Hara 

          Irene L. Pynn 

          Joe Salvatore 

          Ann Marie Shea 

          Jeff Stolzer

Lighting Designer - Colin Lang

Choreographer - Jeminee Damiano

Cast Members - Szalene Anthony

    Fawn Johnstin

    Roland Lane

    Jeffrey Parrillo

    Alexander Reed

    Kate Rose Reynolds

    Marchelle Thurman

What Are We Asking?

Producing a play (or a collection of them) is no easy or inexpensive feat, which is why we need your help. In order to allow Mindflood to flourish, we need to raise $5,000. This would afford us the costs of the following:

  • The Performance Venue
  • Rehearsal Space(s)
  • Props 
  • Scenery
  • Costumes
  • Promotional Materials
  • Artist Stipends for our Cast and Creative Team

Any donation you can give to this project is greatly appreciated.  We kindly ask that you share this campaign with everyone you know in hopes that we are able to reach out across the globe. If we can get ten people to donate at least ten dollars every day, we will quickly reach our goal and be able to bring our deluge, Mindflood to life - not to mention there are some pretty cool perks available.

If you're connected to social media and the internet, we encourage you to like us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/torrenttheatre), follow us on Instagram (@torrenttheatre) and check out our website (www.torrenttheatre.com) for even more updates on our crusade and to find out how you can become not only a bigger part of this production, but the Torrent Theatre movement as well!

          Irene L. Pynn 
          Joe Salvatore 
           Ann Marie Shea 
           Jeff Stolzer
Lighting Designer - Colin LangChoreographer - Jeminee Damiano
Cast Members - Szalene Anthony
    Fawn Johnstin
    Roland Lane
    Jeffrey Parrillo    Alexander Reed
    Kate Rose Reynolds
    Marchelle Thurman
What Are We Asking?
Producing a play (or a collection of them) is no easy or inexpensive feat, which is why we need your help. In order to allow Mindflood to flourish, we need to raise $5,000. This would afford us the costs of the following:

The Performance Venue
Rehearsal Space(s)

Scenery

Any donation you can give to this project is greatly appreciated.  We kindly ask that you share this campaign with everyone you know in hopes that we are able to reach out across the globe. If we can get ten people to donate at least ten dollars every day, we will quickly reach our goal and be able to bring our deluge, Mindflood to life - not to mention there are some pretty cool perks available.
If you're connected to social media and the internet, we encourage you to like us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/torrenttheatre), follow us on Instagram (@torrenttheatre) and check out our website (www.torrenttheatre.com) for even more updates on our crusade and to find out how you can become not only a bigger part of this production, but the Torrent Theatre movement as well!

story:
Dear Friends,

The Borealis class of Sound Circle Eurythmy is completing our fourth year of studies and looking forward to bringing our bilingual program (English and Spanish) to the Unites States, Mexico and Switzerland.  We three students and our teachers have developed a program over the course of this year specifically with a focus on the English and Spanish language and music, including eurythmy to poems by Juan Ramon Jimenez, Langston Hughes, Arthur Sze and Henry David Thoreau.  Our musical pieces will include works by Granados and Albeniz.  We are looking forward to touring within Colorado, in Mexico and in Europe, because we feel that bringing eurythmy from the United States to audiences who do not always have the opportunity to see eurythmy in English, Spanish or to even see eurythmy at all is extremely important.  We have already been gifted with a large portion of our costs, but we are short by a relatively small amount.  Please help us out!  We could not do this without the support of our family, friends, and colleagues. 

With many thanks,

The Borealis Class

Chelaine Kokos, Elizabeth Uppenbrink, and Silvia Wend

students and our teachers have developed a program over the course of this year
specifically with a focus on the English and Spanish language and music,
including eurythmy to poems by Juan Ramon Jimenez, Langston Hughes, Arthur Sze
and Henry David Thoreau.  Our musical pieces will include works by Granados
and Albeniz.  We are looking forward to
touring within Colorado, in Mexico and in Europe, because we feel that bringing
eurythmy from the United States to audiences who do not always have the
opportunity to see eurythmy in English, Spanish or to even see eurythmy at all
is extremely important.  We have already been gifted with a large portion
of our costs, but we are short by a relatively small amount.  Please help
us out!  We could not do this without the support of our family, friends,
and colleagues.  
With many thanks,
The Borealis ClassChelaine Kokos, Elizabeth Uppenbrink, and Silvia Wend

story:
Helluva Theatre Company is proud to bring you Pirandello150!

Helluva WHAT?

Pirandello150 is a year-long festival commemorating the 150th anniversary of the birth of Luigi Pirandello.

It will bring 14 one-act plays, five major productions, a film program, panel discussions and academic seminars to New York City beginning in January 2017.

Luigi Pirandello (1867-1936) was an Italian dramatist, novelist, poet and short story writer. He has written over 40 plays and was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature for "his almost magical power to turn psychological analysis into good theatre." Pirandello's tragic farces are often seen as forerunners of the Theatre of the Absurd as his work explores the boundaries between reality and illusion. With his invention of the “theater within the theater,” Luigi Pirandello became an important innovator in modern drama. Not only did Pirandello alter the face of theatre forever through his plays, but he also instilled discipline in his actors and placed special emphasis on their work as an ensemble, a radical notion at the time.

The more people we talk to about Pirandello150 (www.pirandello150.org) the more interest it has generated and suddenly we seem to have one Helluva Advisory Board...

Eve Best

Robert Brustein

Lynn Cohen

Mario Fratti

Bruce Goldstein

Joe Grifasi

Italian Cultural Institute

Judith Ivey

The Living Theatre

Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble

Fabrizio Melano

Sherrill Milnes

Brian Murray

Pirandello Society of America

Bill Pullman 

Annabella Sciorra 

Martin Scorsese

John Turturro

...and the list keeps growing and growing!

Helluva WHY?

Out of the 40 plays Luigi Pirandello wrote, most can only name a few, with the most popular being: "Six Characters in Search of an Author"

The production of Six Characters in Paris in 1923 made Pirandello widely known, and his work became one of the central influences on the French theatre. French drama from the existentialistic pessimism of Jean Anouilh and Jean-Paul Sartre to the absurdist comedy of Eugène Ionesco and Samuel Beckett is tinged with what is called “Pirandellianism.” His work has been acknowledged as a major influence by such accomplished playwrights as Harold Pinter and Edward Albee. His influence can even be seen in the religious verse dramas of T.S. Eliot.

Pirandello's work is still widely produced in Europe but a major Pirandello work has not been seen on the Broadway stage for 42 years!

It's baffling. 

Luigi Pirandello wrote great plays, with great characters that are constantly changing, both in their eyes and our own. Pirandello's plays are fascinating and challenging -- and many are genuinely funny. Laugh out loud FUNNY!

Today, traditional social and gender roles are changing. These changes are attuned to Pirandello’s theme of truth vs. illusion. In the words of the prominent critic, playwright, and scholar Robert Brustein, “The basic Pirandellian conflict is internal – between the mask one shows to the world and the actual face of the suffering individual. The truth of one’s character must remain forever concealed if one is to survive in society.”

We think it is the right time to bring new audiences to Pirandello and re-establish his position in the evolution of the dramatic arts. 

Helluva WHEN?

2017 is a Milestone Anniversary! It marks 150 years since the birth of Luigi Pirandello.

2017 will be marked the high point for a cultural relaunch of interest and awareness in Pirandello.

Projected 2017 Timeline

~January

The Film Forum Pirandello Series highlighted by a restoration showing of “Kaos” by the Taviani Brothers.

~February

The One-Act series kicks off. We will present all 14 of the known one-act plays by Pirandello, in four separate programs with different casts, directors, and in different venues and involving different Off and Off-Off Broadway companies throughout the city.

~March

The Living Theatre revival of their landmark production of “Tonight We Improvise”

~April/May

Productions #1 & #2 open*

~Wednesday, June 28

A Gala celebrating the 150th Birthday of Luigi Pirandello for the benefit of all the sponsoring and participating companies/societies of Pirandello150.

~Fall

Productions #3 & #4 open*

*In addition to The Living Theatre production of “Tonight We Improvise” the plays that are currently under consideration are: 

“Six Characters in Search of an Author”, “Right You Are (If You Think You Are)”, “Enrico IV”, “The Rules of the Game”, “As You Desire Me”, “Each in His Own Way", and “Liola”

Productions will be scheduled subject to the availability of actors, directors, theaters and, of course, financing. We hope that at least one of these plays will be given a Broadway production!

Most of our selection of full-length and one-act plays will be in recent or new translations.

~Throughout the year

We also plan:

  • A series of lectures and panel discussions on all aspects of Pirandello’s life, work and influence;

  • Readings of as many of the full-length plays as possible that are not being given full productions;

  • Podcasts of noted actors, writers and other individuals reading selected short stories, plays and segments of novels that will be available on our website at www.pirandello150.org starting from this Fall, 2016.

  • An outreach to high schools and colleges in the tri-state area through academic conferences, lectures and workshops. 

Helluva WHERE?

New York City!

As the preeminent city for the American theater, New York is the perfect center for the Pirandello150 festival. Italian government and cultural institutions are active in New York’s cultural life. Major Italian corporations have important and growing operation centers. Educational institutions focus on Italian art, history, language and design, while enthusiasm about Italian cuisine grows ever more popular. 

We would like to start introducing Pirandello150 in NYC this year, 2016, with two very exciting events that are also featured in our fundraising perks...

(1). A Pirandello Potpourri 

At 6:00pm on Tuesday, June 28, we will celebrate Luigi Pirandello's 149th birthday with a "Pirandello Potpourri": a special "kick-off" event to officially and publicly announce Pirandello150. The Italian Cultural Institute has generously donated their lovely meeting room where we will present a short program of readings and remarks that will preview our plans for 2017. This will be followed by a reception. 

Event: Pirandello Potpourri
Date: Tuesday, June 28, 2016
Time: 6:00 p.m.
Place: Italian Cultural Institute
686 Park Avenue (btw. 68th & 69th Sts.)

(2). An Exclusive Private Reading of "Right You Are (If You think You Are)"

We are planning a special first sneak peek invite-only reading of this fabulous new translation by our very own Helluva Theatre Company's Artistic Director John Martello, in September. It will feature some of NY's finest actors who will be announced soon!

Event: "Right You Are (If You Think You Are)" Reading
Date: September, 2016
Time & Place: TBA

Helluva HOW?

We have a Helluva Advisory Board that will provide artistic direction and advice on the selection of works, venues, casting and scheduling. These noted actors, authors, producers, directors and scholars will help us engage a cross-section of NYC organizations.

But...

...we can only make this all happen with YOUR HELP! 

We need, as everyone always does, initial funds to get the ball rolling, to cover costs, to spread the word...to lay down the pathway for Pirandello150 to actually happen!

Any donation of any amount will help!

DONATE and...

...share in the excitement of the re-discovery of Luigi Pirandello by the theater-going public!

...help us introduce this important and influential playwright to students through workshops, seminars and highly-discounted student tickets to all of our events and productions!

...enable some of New York’s most talented and accomplished actors and directors to delight in the creation of Pirandello’s world on stage in new and recent translations!

...become part of an event that will be an important step in the renaissance of high Italian culture in the capital of the American theater!

...be a part of the Pirandello150 Movement!

...be one Helluva Theatre Supporter!


In bed my real love has always been the sleep that rescued me by allowing me to dream.

—Luigi Pirandello


Wait...Helluva is WHO?

Right, we are the newly formed non-profit Helluva Theatre Company! 

Helluva Theatre Company is dedicated to producing the finest plays of American and world literature and also developing the new work of playwrights working in that tradition.  Our productions will also give actors the unique opportunity to perform in rarely done plays of the theatrical canon and to experience the various styles of play (Greek tragedy, Jacobean, Restoration, et al) that they are rarely given a chance to do.

We are also dedicated to the development of the next generation of theatergoers.  We commit to doing this through:

· Free or heavily discounted tickets to our productions and events;

· Special student matinees of our productions followed by discussions;

· Bringing the theater into the classrooms with performances, classes and workshops.

We have one Helluva Team...

~John Martello as Artistic Director 

~Zoe Anastassiou as Associate Artistic Director

~Burt Wolder as Managing Director

You will be able to learn more at www.helluvatheatre.com as soon as it is launched - our 501(c)(3) status is pending.

Please support us now!!!!!

story:
TICKETS & SHOW TIMES: Rating (17+)

To buy 1 ticket choose the 'Pie in the face' perk. For more browse the other options.
AUGUST (Saturday) 27th @ 7:30pm - The show is 1 hour
AFTER PARTY IN THEATRE (Poet's Den Theatre)!!! 
Attendants will receive HORS 'DOEUVRES, a raffle ticket for PIE CONTEST (there's a drawing to throw a pie in my face woo!), and KAROKE!!! 

synopsis 

  • Hello! My name is Breunna Darling. I was born and raised in the 'City of Entertainment.' Las Vegas, Nevada baby. I sing, act, and dance! I'm a graduate of A.M.D.A (American Musical Dramatics Academy) Some Alumni are : Jason Mraz, Tyne Daly, Jason Derulo, Jessie Tyler Ferguson, Janelle Monáe, etc. I've been performing for six years and I love it! It's the reason I get up in the morning. This show is going to have MONOLOGUES, POETRY, SINGING, AERIAL SILKS and MIME! I'm not bringing sexy back I'm bringing miming back aye!... Okay that was a bad joke. Thank goodness I'm not doing stand-up. 
  • (By the way after the show there will be HORS D'OEUVRES passed, A PIE IN THE FACE CONTEST, and KARAOKE!!!!!!)
  • This is something I've been dreaming about for a year. I hope to make change with this piece. Not just for me, but for the community. By contributing to my project you are helping me make my dream come true.
  • I want to people to come into the theater with no expectations, and leave with a cathartic experience. An experience that healed the soul, opened the mind, and inspire the heart to follow what dreams it desires the most.By contributing to my project you are helping me make my dream come true.

What We Need & What You Get

Break down :

  • THEATRE RENTAL SPACE :$1,600 for two nights at the gorgeous (Poet's Den Theatre.)
  • CREW PAYMENT: Creative/Stage Director $250, Light/Sound Specialist:$200, Graphic Designer: $25 Videographer$ 50 
  • ADVERTISING/MARKETING: 
    • Marketing team: $170 (500 Business cards-$25 Flyers-$30 Posters- $50, Stand+ poster $23.93, Sponsor backdrop $260, Vistaprint 10pt card stock square giveaway posters $30)
  • COSTUME/PROPS: $150
  • Read the perks on the right hand side to see where your funds go and what you'll receive for donating.

The Impact

  • This is not just another show. This is a piece of art that will transform the community. I want the audience to leave with the message. That message is : "Conquer fear and negativity while pursuing your dreams." I truly believe that if everyone did something they loved to do in life, this world would be a better place.

Risks & Challenges

  • Doing a solo show was a challenge I accepted a long time ago. I've conquered a lot of adversities so far with this show, and there are more obstacles ahead.  This is my first SOLO show, and I understand that everything isn't going to flow as smoothly and as efficiently as I would like. 
  • A couple of HUGE risks I'm taking is performing two nights, and having faith that I'll raise enough money in two months.  Having a strong team and supportive people like you to turn to takes away the stress and makes the risk WORTH IT!  

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that everyone can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean that you can't help. Here are some ways: 

  •  WORD OF MOUTH:  Make some NOISE about my campaign!
  • SHARE: Share my Indiegogo Campaign on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter,& etc.
  • CONTEST: 
  • CLICK THE LINK TO JOIN MY NEWSLETTER AND YOU COULD WIN 1 FREE MONTH MEMBERSHIP TO HULU:
  • http://visitor.r20.constantcontact.com/d.jsp?ll...

story:
Into Some Woods

Into the Woods is a musical with book by James Lapine and music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, and it's going up at Bard College! Into the Woods combines several fairy tales, such as those of Cinderella, Jack (and the Beanstalk), Rapunzel, Little Red Riding Hood... and a very important cow. Along with an original story of the Baker and the Baker's Wife, these characters meet and interact in the woods, until they get what they're searching for. And once that happens, everything goes to pieces. Overall, it is a show about wishes, family, and growing up.

What It Will Look Like:

Into the Woods is already not your typical fairytale. And this is not your typical version of Into the Woods. To begin with, we have an 11 person cast for a 21 character lineup, which means that more than half of the cast is playing more than one character. Because of that, each actor will have a base costume, and will add on other pieces for each character. The costumes are detailed, with each actor having about four separate pieces for each base costume. This is also a prop-heavy show, with upwards of twenty props needed. The set is fairly minimal, and will take advantage of black box theater we will be in. It basically comes down to props and costumes for the visuals of the show.

What We Need:

All funding will be going into this show. We will be using donated money for every aspect of the show: costumes, set, lighting, sound, makeup, and props. Our project has support from the Bard Musical Theatre Club, but all of that money went into obtaining the rights for the show. The success of this project depends on you.


Illustration by Trina Schart Hyman.

story:
The Story Behind the Show so Far....

The first presentation of the show took place at the Fringe Festival San Miguel de Allende (http://fringesanmiguel.com) Mexico, in March 2016, at The Skot Foreman Gallery (http://www.skotforeman.com) - to a terrific response.   

Three actors brought eleven poems by the Spanish poet, Federico Garcia Lorca to life, with projections of both the eleven Terry Frost etchings (created in response to these favorite poems of his), and the poetry text in Spanish and English.  Stories and musings on Sir Terry and Lorca, and their work, were woven between the poems. 

The Skot Foreman gallery also housed an exhibition of all the etchings, making it a wonderful  collaboration of an art exhibition and performance.  ("A new and exciting way of experiencing visual art", Skot Foreman said).

HOW THE SHOW WAS BORN...

Janet Prince, one of the actors,  had a "Frost & Lorca"  portfolio rather languishing in a cupboard.  She showed the portfolio  to her friend who started reading the Lorca poems in Spanish.  A memory occurred to Janet - Terry Frost had always wanted to create a theatre set.  What if this entire portfolio could be "brought to life"?     Janet knew that Fringe San Miguel theatre festival (http://fringesanmiguel.com) were always in pursuit of bilingual work, having been a part of the festival with her one woman show in 2015.   Frost & Lorca seemed like the perfect piece to present to them...  

John Morrow and Kate Lowenstein, founders and directors of the Fringe SMA, jumped at the submission of this idea, and just a few weeks later, brought the good news that a British sponsor (who owned two Terry Frost paintings!) wanted to support the first "presentation" at Fringe San Miguel, 2016.  

Within a few weeks, the British contingent of the cast, Janet Prince (London) and Henrietta Weekes (New York), arrived in San Miguel, with John Morrow, a veteran theatre actor and director from New York, wearing the director's hat.   A local resident, the Peruvian actor, Enrique Argumedo, was signed up as the Spanish speaking actor. Eric Oliva, a renowned projectionist from Mexico City, jumped in to work with the images and text. Javier Estrada, a gypsy/flamenco guitarist, provided a soundscape.  They had three weeks to create something worth watching, and began rehearsals in the gorgeous Belles Artes (http://www.elnigromante.bellasartes.gob.mx)

THE SHOW and THE RESPONSE....

People loved it!  We thought we'd  illustrate this direct from the audience's mouths....  

"I'm a visual arts guy, but this really moved me - I actually got teary eyed, which I never do.  I saw my gallery transformed, and how much the audience responded..."  Skot Foreman, gallerist 

"Radical and .... actually, revolutionary.  I'm an old NY theater guy and you pulled this one out of the bag".  Thom Beers and partner,  Reality TV producer, 

"I loved the play......the element of artists considering and interpreting the work of other artists......like it would always be continually evolving and changing......just such an interesting angle. I felt like I was a Dada-ist in France in 1920, which is exactly how I want to feel. All the time." Erin Shultz, painter

"Excellent acting and directing.  Professionally done. Please create more work."  Alberto Lenz,  Director, Belles Artes

"Poetry can be oppressive or confusing, but you made it so approachable and transcendent at the same time- the stories about the artists in between poems felt like a lovely difference in tone and humanized the poetry,"   Bill O Fares, artist

Other words flung around were:  exceptional, heartfelt, powerful, original, exemplary, indescribable, .... AND.....  "you have to do this more, do it again!".

And so we are.....

THE PLAYERS

John Morrow - director

John  is a lifelong actor, director and writer, especially active in the "Experimental Theatre"  scene in New York  during the 60's/ 70's where his plays were performed at LaMama, Theatre Genesis, Museum of Modern Art and The Space for Innovative Development. He helped to found (and taught at) the theatre department of Naropa University, Boulder, CO. He is currently the co-founder and Artistic Director of the San Miguel Fringe Festival, Mexico, the first and only bi-lingual fringe festival in the Americas.

Janet Prince - actor

Janet has worked in theater, television and film for 40 years, both in London, New York and now Mexico. Her one woman show "Murder, Margaret and Me" has been a sell out for three years, and has won various prizes.  

Henrietta Weekes  - actor

Henrietta is a British performer who lives in New York - she has also written and produced live and web events/series. She also works as a moderator/presenter.  She trained at Kimball Studio, NYC.

Enrique Argumedo - actor

Enrique was born in Lima, Peru and his professional training has focused on the field of voice. He has worked as an announcer, actor and storyteller, and his artistic work has played throughout Latin America and Europe.

Misi Bekesi - projectionist/sound/lighting

Naoko Tagai - projectionist/sound/lighting

Musician - to be announced ! 

THE FUTURE OF THE SHOW...

Our aim is to submit our piece to festivals around the world, and to seek producers/companies to back a  tour of Latin America, and also the US and Europe.  

Our professional video of the London show, with the improved image and text projections, lighting and music,  will be our "promo" to also apply for grants (such as The Britsh Arts Council or Anglo Arts, which sponsors shows between Mexico and England).

We think this would also be a good bilingual piece for colleges and schools.

What We Need Now & What You Get

The Portico Gallery, London (http://www.porticogallery.org.uk) has offered two nights for our next presentation - June 15th and 16th (soon!).   For this next show, we will develop the projections, text and lighting, and experiment with different music (the gallery has a grand piano!), and Misi Bekesi and Naoko Tagai - pros in their field of projection for theatrical works - will work with us.  Rehearsals have started now, and will continue" live" on June 11th at the gallery, to develop/fine tune the content with the actors.   

Rosebery's (https://www.roseberys.co.uk) a London Auction House, is located opposite the Portico Gallery.  Their contribution is to lend us the thirteen framed Terry Frost etchings that they happen to house.  A happy synchronicity!

This next step is vital for us, but we're not quite there - which is why we are asking for a bit of help.  We don't need much to make this happen and maximize our work, so that we really have something to "go bigger"....

WHERE THE FUNDS GO....   and HOW YOU WILL BENEFIT  

The funds - $5,000 is what we are shooting for -  would go entirely towards our London production at The Portico Gallery.  If we raise more, we will put it towards our next plans for the show in  the US and Mexico City (in conversation with leading galleries) and more galleries in the UK.  We will keep you posted on it all! 

  You will help pay for:

- the actors, director, tech crew and musician -  transport fares and accommodation costs, production fees

 - production costs at venue: programs, marketing materials and campaigns, any venue costs, equipment rentals

THE PERKS FOR YOU AS A FUNDER...

Depending on your contribution (see perks), you will be known hereon into the future as "producer/funder" and will receive free tickets to future shows - in the US, or any other country the show is performed.

 You will receive a signed Sir Terry Frost centenary postcard of your choice from all the cast.

If and when the show is picked up and toured, your name will be a part of this.

Any of the cast will be willing to offer their contacts and help for anyone that might require some in the field of production and performance.  Everyone is seasoned and skillful.   You name it - voice work, movement/ personal trainings, events, venues, festivals -  avenues to where best to get your work seen or presented.   Any way we can help, really. 

The Impact

We truly believe ( in part based on audience response) this show has real "legs".   Lorca's poetry is a perfect antidote to our rampant materialistic, media saturated, commercialized world.   It's a soul tonic - as are Sire Terry Frost's paintings.   The challenge to present a "no frills" show, just the mystery of poetry and painting to a modern audience and make it not only palatable, but something really impactful was a risk.  But we think we achieved this, and we can only get better...

Risks & Challenges

We have a professional crew at the helm, who worked incredibly well together, under the gun, with a truly challenging and novel project before them.  "But people are scared of poetry!", we had all exclaimed at some point, "how can we get them to love it?"  

We really believed our main task was to humanize the words - never to be didactic, and to find our own meaning and stories in the words.   Hence, we had to create an intimacy and vitality between the actors, in response to the powerful Terry Frost images, which are essentially the set, the environment, the landscape.  The gypsy guitar soundscapes were woven between the poems.

What we arrived at was a kind of dialogue that is "alive", a conversation between the different mediums of art, the two artists' work,  and the players themselves. Something all encompassing,  both profound and light spirited. 

 Other Ways You Can Help

We know that in these turbulent times, it can be hard to donate to anything, so we encourage you to believe in the maxim "anything helps, however small" !  

If you can't contribute, no matter, we'd so appreciate you sharing the word about this show, or  making some noise about our funding campaign. You never know who could be out there, with a passion for Federico Garcia Lorca or SirTerry Frost, or this kind of work. 

THANK YOU ALL.  Help us all to keep creating work that keeps our human sensuality alive - before we become co-opted by the Orwellian" machine" age!!!

Three actors brought eleven poems by the Spanish poet, Federico Garcia Lorca to life, with projections of both the eleven Terry Frost etchings (created in response to these favorite poems of his), and the poetry text in Spanish and English.  Stories and musings on Sir Terry and Lorca, and their work, were woven between the poems.

story:
Short Summary

Hey there! My name is Lawrence Dandridge and I am the writer and composer of Something Like a Fairytale The Musical. This show has been apart of my life since it's conception in 2009. It started as a senior project that I forced onto my high school and it has slowly turned into what I honestly feel like is my life's purpose. I have written multiple musicals since then but Something Like a Fairytale is my baby!
A story within a story, A mother decides to tell her young daughter the story of how she and her husband came to be together. She turns the story into a fairytale so the little girl understands it better. In the fairytale world, we meet a princess who is faced with the decision to love as her heart desires or to put the needs of her family and kingdom above her own. Something Like a Fairytale holds a mirror up to honest love, friendship and what it truly means to follow your heart.
This show not only touches on universal subjects like parental pressure, love triangles, domestic disputes, and divorce (to name a few) but it also shines light on what it means to have a fairytale ending, specifically from the African American perspective. Through music that is influenced by many genres, this show takes us on a relatable journey that bridges the gap between the version of love we all long for and the version of love most of us actually get. It's fun, it's honest,  and it allows the audiences to see a piece of themselves in each character.

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $3,000! Because this is a huge show (with a cast about 26), we want to make sure that we are able to adequately create this world, visually on stage, just as much as we have on paper. This money will go towards set needs (wood, paint, lights, wheels, etc.) as we as costumes and wigs, rehearsal space fees, and other technical elements that this show requires . We have been given only a short 4 weeks to cast and mount this show and we have a $0 budget to pull from.  We really don't want to sacrifice the beauty of this show (or scrap it all together) due to monetary reasons.

Thankfully, because this show has been workshopped in many different ways over the past 6 years, we have a fully produced soundtrack recording of the show. If you pledge a donation of $100 of more, you can win a complete cast recording of Something Like a Fairytale! All of the music was written and arranged by me (Lawrence Dandridge) and was fully produced by Shaquan Welsh. This cast can saaaaang too so it's definitely worth the investment!

If we don't raise our entire goal, we may have to cut out majority of the show for the festival, or worse, not be able to participate in the festival at all. It's just too big of a show not to do on a full scale. Things can easily get lost in translation if the same actress playing the mom (wearing jeans and a T-shirt) is also seen on stage as the princess (In different jeans and a nicer T-shirt). You get me!? 

The Impact

I think this is an opportunity that doesn't come around often for young men of color in the land of Musical Theatre. Lin Manuel Miranda (In The Heights, Hamilton) has definitely pushed down some doors in that regard but a black playwright in contemporary musical theatre hasn't emerged yet and I would love to be that guy! I think it's important for kids to go see shows and be able to think "He looks like me... I can do that one day!" 

I am no stranger to the stage myself. I recently finished the second national tour of Sister Act The musical (TJ) and was featured in the 2015 National Black Theatre Festival. Lots of people know me as Lawrence "The performer" or Lawrence "The singer". I really would love to build a name as Lawrence "The playwright". And people know that if I put my mind to something, I deliever! (I've built a reputation of putting on awesome shows last minute!) I just truly need as much help as I can get from the outside.

Risks & Challenges

If I am being totally honest, this opportunity has come in the height of me being without a steady living space. I have been "house hopping" as I like to call it, with friends trying to save up enough to get my own place after my living arrangement fell through. I even considered not taking the opportunity to partake in the Festival because of this reality. But I had to take a lead of faith on the vision that was given to me to follow my dreams. 

I've been through worse things than homelessness, and trust me I'm not mentioning this to get a sympathy donation. I bring this up merely to show you how dedicated I am the integrity of the project and how passionate I am about sharing this art! I hope that you can put as much faith in me, this story, and this beautifully talented company I've managed to put together, as I do!

Other Ways You Can Help

Trust me, If I was not the one heading this campaign, and was reading it (especially under my current circumstances), I'd feel useless because I know people just don't have the means to contribute monetarily sometimes! We're launching into the height of the holiday season. Cash is tight! I understand that. I'm just asking that you share it with friends and family, like/share our Facebook page to build more awareness, and come to see the show in January at the Elecktra Theatre in NYC! More details will follow... if we meet our deadline!


Fingers crossed!

story:
Short Summary.

What can an ancient fairy tale teach us about how human beings recover?

"My child, if I do not chop off both of your hands, then the devil will take me away, and in my fear I have promised him to do this. Help me in my need, and forgive me of the evil that I am going to do to you."

(from The Handless Maiden by the Brothers Grimm)

Over the last 18 months I have been researching variants of the story "The Handless Maiden" (you can read one version of it here), a huge, enigmatic tale about a girl whose father cuts off her hands in order to save himself from a  bad deal. The story describes how she travels to find a place of safety in a wild forest, marries a king, learns to create and in the process grows her hands back.

As part of the research I have been making contact with people who are healing in some way from something whether it be from illness, mental illness or addiction across the addiction recovery and asylum seeker communities. I want to make visible what I find out and share it with you!

Over the coming months I will be recording interviews with some of people I have met who have something to say about recovery. I'll also be responding creatively to what I find and turning it into immersive experiences in person and online which you (generous supporters) will to get to experience most of first!


What We Need & What You Get

We want to make this piece of work as interactive as we can: from the very start. so while the money you donate will help us to run the project it will also be a way for you to join in the conversation the project is designed to provoke. We are offering you:

  • Access to a secret blog detailing stages of the project and giving an insight into the process , first look at the digital work we will produce, plus the opportunity to participate by sharing your own story; 
  • A chance to have sounds you make be added to a soundscape that will accompany parts of the project;
  • A make-over to highlight your scars and flaws based on the ancient Japanese art of Kintsugi (repairing broken pottery with gold.), a mini photo shoot plus digital copies of the results (see the gilded scar below);
  • A personal invitation to a work in progress showing in Liverpool during the summer.
We also want you to share your story. If through interacting with the project you feel you have a "Handless Maiden" story to share, we would love to hear from you.


We have received support from some very generous organisations in Liverpool, not least the superlative Hope Street Ltd. who are backing the project and Liverpool Anglican Cathedral who are to host a showing of work on the 13th May. We are also generously supported by Arts Council England.

We are asking you for that little extra to enable us to develop materials for the project, provide support to some of the people who will be participating and to enable me to make my public sharings as good as they need to be. Your money will help to:

  • gather and share even more inspiring and honest stories showing us how people recover;
  • provide extra rehearsal space and travel expenses to make sure members of the addiction recovery groups can access the project on a regular basis;
  • provide food, transport, translation services and other support to members of asylum seeker and refugee groups we will be visiting to make sure there are no barriers to their participation and so that they can join us for any live sharing of the work (see info about asylum in the UK here);
  • supply additional props and materials for use during the public sharing.

For this we need to raise at least £800 (£880 including Indiegogo fees). Your support will help us to make participation in the project easier for those who face serious barriers to getting involved and help us to meet our match funding obligation to the Arts Council. Anything more will go towards developing materials and experiences to share with people I encounter throughout the research (that could include you).

The Impact

I wanted to make this project to share the extraordinary stories of people who I have supported and who support me to heal. While researching this story I discovered that I had thyroid cancer. Working with the tale and getting in contact with others who are going through their own recovery journey has helped me to heal and totally changed my interpretation of the story. In summary "Handless" is about sharing the fact that people DO recover after all kinds of emotional, physical and social injuries, but also to think about what the possible goal of recovery could be - what is the end result? (for a great example listen to this story of paraplegic Matthew Sanford who now teaches yoga on the OnBeing website). It's also to look at some of the ways that we can make people socially "Handless" and to support hopeful change.

Risks & Challenges

It's a big project and it's an ambitious one, but we are on a mission to inspire people to hope! Not the fluffy sort, but the one that is a choice, an outlook and linked to the uncertainties of the human condition as well as being correlated to a host of health, happiness and achievement outcomes. I also believe that it is learnable and this project is part of my wish to find out how.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to give any money to the project, sign up to stay in contact with the project on our my website and share, share, share the campaign.
story_txt:
Short Summary.

What can an ancient fairy tale teach us about how human beings recover?
"My child, if I do not chop off both of your
hands, then the devil will take me away, and in my fear I have promised him to
do this. Help me in my need, and forgive me of the evil that I am going to do
to you."
(from The Handless Maiden by the Brothers Grimm)
Over the last 18 months I have been researching variants of the story "The Handless Maiden" (you can read one version of it here), a huge, enigmatic tale about a girl whose father cuts off her hands in order to save himself from a  bad deal. The story describes how she travels to find a place of safety in a wild forest, marries a king, learns to create and in the process grows her hands back.
As part of the research I have been making contact with people who are healing in some way from something whether it be from illness, mental illness or addiction across the addiction recovery and asylum seeker communities. I want to make visible what I find out and share it with you!
Over the coming months I will be recording interviews with some of people I have met who have something to say about recovery. I'll also be responding creatively to what I find and turning it into immersive experiences in person and online which you (generous supporters) will to get to experience most of first!

What We Need & What You Get
We want to make this piece of work as interactive as we can: from the very start. so while the money you donate will help us to run the project it will also be a way for you to join in the conversation the project is designed to provoke. We are offering you:

Access to a secret blog detailing stages of the project and giving an insight into the process , first look at the digital work we will produce, plus the opportunity to participate by sharing your own story; 
A chance to have sounds you make be added to a soundscape that will accompany parts of the project;
A make-over to highlight your scars and flaws based on the ancient Japanese art of Kintsugi (repairing broken pottery with gold.), a mini photo shoot plus digital copies of the results (see the gilded scar below);
A personal invitation to a work in progress showing in Liverpool during the summer.
We also want you to share your story. If through interacting with the project you feel you have a "Handless Maiden" story to share, we would love to hear from you.


 We have received support from some very generous organisations in Liverpool, not least the superlative Hope Street Ltd. who are backing the project and Liverpool Anglican Cathedral who are to host a showing of work on the 13th May. We are also generously supported by Arts Council England.We are asking you for that little extra to enable us to develop materials for the project, provide support to some of the people who will be participating and to enable me to make my public sharings as good as they need to be. Your money will help to:
gather and share even more inspiring and honest stories showing us how people recover;

provide extra rehearsal space and travel expenses to make sure members of the addiction recovery groups can access the project on a regular basis;



provide food, transport, translation services and other support to members of asylum seeker and refugee groups we will be visiting to make sure there are no barriers to their participation and so that they can join us for any live sharing of the work (see info about asylum in the UK here);
supply additional props and materials for use during the public sharing.

For this we need to raise at least £800 (£880 including Indiegogo fees). Your support will help us to make participation in the project easier for those who face serious barriers to getting involved and help us to meet our match funding obligation to the Arts Council. Anything more will go towards developing materials and experiences to share with people I encounter throughout the research (that could include you).

The Impact
 I wanted to make this project to share the extraordinary stories of people who I have supported and who support me to heal. While researching this story I discovered that I had thyroid cancer. Working with the tale and getting in contact with others who are going through their own recovery journey has helped me to heal and totally changed my interpretation of the story. In summary "Handless" is about sharing the fact that people DO recover after all kinds of emotional, physical and social injuries, but also to think about what the possible goal of recovery could be - what is the end result? (for a great example listen to this story of paraplegic Matthew Sanford who now teaches yoga on the OnBeing website). It's also to look at some of the ways that we can make people socially "Handless" and to support hopeful change.
Risks & Challenges
 It's a big project and it's an ambitious one, but we are on a mission to inspire people to hope! Not the fluffy sort, but the one that is a choice, an outlook and linked to the uncertainties of the human condition as well as being correlated to a host of health, happiness and achievement outcomes. I also believe that it is learnable and this project is part of my wish to find out how.
    Other Ways You Can Help If you aren't able to give any money to the project, sign up to stay in contact with the project on our my website and share, share, share the campaign.

story:
Short Summary

The Baffling Adventures of Question-Mark Man is an exciting upcoming Edinburgh Fringe show that needs your help.

The show is a lighthearted family-friendly comedy that follows the baffling superhero Question-Mark Man and his amnesic side-kick Forgotten Boy in a series of hilarious adventures. Taking inspiration from the Marvel Films, the 1960s Batman and Robin and a variety of comic book tropes, this show features physical comedy, word play and crazy characters played by a talented cast. 

We're up in Edinburgh for two weeks, from the 15th to the 27th of August at 12:00. Our venue is The Space on the Mile venue located at Radisson Blu, 80 High Street, Edinburgh, EH1 1TH.

Produced by Bottled Spider Productions, this upcoming production has all the right ingredients for a comic success at Edinburgh and we hope your generosity will help us wow the Fringe-goers.  

Here's a little bit about us as a theatre company: Bottled Spider Productions is an emerging theatre company dedicated to producing new work and revitalising classic works with a contemporary focus. Based in Norwich, Bottled Spider boasts an array of Fringe experience, and we believe we have the skills and experience to make our latest show a hit success. Both our director and writer were involved in a show in last year's fringe and we want to utilise this experience, and a pool of skilled actors from the University of East Anglia to create a five-star show.

It is our goal to bring an engaging, funny and poignant show to the Edinburgh Fringe this year and set a foundation for Bottled Spider to expand into more ambitious projects.

Your money will go towards Fringe Registration costs, venue hire and accommodation whilst in Edinburgh. It will also fund important theatrical elements such as costume, set and make-up, helping this promising project fufill its potential. Your support will allow an emerging theatre company to develop into a home of consistently excellent theatre for years to come.

We can also offer a set of exclusive rewards to generous individuals who are willing to help us out, including a DVD of the show that will be filmed in Edinburgh in front of a live audience and many other exciting gifts.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read our pledge, please share the word and give generously, every pound will be cherished. We look forward to seeing you in Edinburgh!

Fond regards, 

Alec Mann and Scott Younger

 (Director and Writer of The Baffling Adventures of Question-Mark Man.)

story:
What is Solstice Shorts?


Arachne Press is a small publisher with big ideas. We publish mainly short stories and we love reading them aloud to an audience. Last year we launched Solstice Shorts Festival, a hugely successful, free, live short story and folk music event that celebrated the winter solstice and short story day (21st December) on the prime meridian in Greenwich. It was all about TIME and ran from sunrise to sunset, with actors reading a new short story every half hour, and short sets of folk music in between. The event was funded partly by The Arts Council and partly by Crowdfunding.


You can watch the videos of last year's event on Youtube

Sunset in Greenwich on 21st December 2014

We really want to keep the concept alive and growing, with plans afoot for another big event in 2019 (the next time the Solstice is at the weekend) and possibly a dawn reading event around the world,  (I said we have big ideas!) but this year we are aiming at a more modest event as the Solstice (and Short Story Day) fall on a Monday. As a result the theme this year is LONGEST NIGHT.


We have the stories (and poems this year) chosen, and we have musicians planning their sets. Everything is about night and winter!

Authors & Poets

We have stories from David Mathews, David McVey, Frances Gapper, Neil Brosnan, Pauline Walker,Sarah Evans, Wendy Gill.

and poems from Abigail Beckel,Bob Beagrie, Sarah James.

Musicians

Ian Kennedy & Sarah Lloyd (folk duo with a great line in surprising lullabies),


Vassilis Chatzimakris Trio (Cretan folk music, specialise in songs about the night), Vocal Chords (Local community choir with a repertoire of midwinter and night songs).


Actors

We haven't cast the actors yet, we need to have some money committed before we can do that. We work regularly with some really fine but as yet  insufficiently appreciated actors - help us save them from being forced to be Santa or an Elf  this pre-christmas run!

Why you might want to help

By contributing to the campaign you will make it possible to keep the event free, and accessible to everyone; at the same time as supporting writers, musicians and actors by not expecting them to give their time and talent for free.

Solstice Shorts is celebratory - winter can be grim and the shortest day of the year is a turning point, the true new year, when the days finally start to lengthen again, if we can convince the sun to do its thing... We are keeping the tradition of winter storytelling alive and supporting new writing and local musicians. It's great fun too!


What We Need & What You Get

What we will spend the money on:

  • Musical Performers £830
  •  Actors  £1140
  •  Co-ordination/hosting £500
  •  Leafleters £95
  • Printing flyers/ posters £300
  • Video live perf £150
  • Submittable subscription for 3 months £40
  •  Insurance £230
  • Performance rights for stories/poems  £450
  •  Music rights licence £70
  • Contingency (prices going up, things we might have forgotten, cost of raising the funds etc.)
  • Total £4,000

What we are getting for free/ contributing ourselves, to an approximate value of £3,000

  •  The venue
  • 50% of the time to organise
  • General admin costs like phone/ photocopying/ social media promotion
  • Stewards on the night
  • Some musicians for free

What we hope will contribute towards the costs
  • We will sell books at the event, profits from which will go towards the costs.
  • We are running a folk song workshop with Lester Simpson on 28th November. 50% of any profit we make from this workshop will go towards the event.


What we can offer you -
    Some detail about what's on offer including pictures - follow the links for detail
  • Books! (Of Course).

  •  In particular last year's anthology, Solstice Shorts Sixteen Stories about Time; but also other books, including signed ones.
  • Tshirts


  •  Badges. 


  • A professional edit of a short story up to 2000 words or the equivalent length for a novel extract,
  • Personalised greetings cards - your name in our one-line illustrated stories, more detail here


  • A place on a folk song workshop with Lester Simpson (in South London on 28th November) all abilities welcome!
  • original print by Kevin Threlfall

  • Kevin Threlfall Print 1                                 Kevin Threlfall Print 2

  • Kevin Threlfall Print3                                       Kevin Threlfall Print 4

What happens if we don't get enough...

  • Obviously we hope we will get all the money, but if we don't we will scale back the event even more, but we really want it to happen - it is essential that we keep the concept going or we won't be able to achieve the 2019 extravaganza.
  • We have to promote, but we could manage without the banner, just. We must pay the performers, and the licences and the insurance. Most other things are people's time, the most valuable commodity on earth!
  • If we really can't put on the show this year, we'll use the funds collected towards next year - having money already allocated would help enormously with getting Arts Council funding.

The Impact

Last year we created an anthology from the short stories we read at the event - they were all new stories and for many of the authors it was their first time in print. Nearly 200 people attended at least part of the festival, which on the last Sunday before Christmas was quite something. (We had people queueing to get in at 8am, to get the sunrise reading.) If we can keep the festival going it greatly improves our chances of Arts Council funding in the future.


Risks & Challenges

It's always a risk putting on a single event - we have all our eggs in one basket. That's why we include insurance. The biggest risk is insufficient marketing and not getting enough of an audience, which would be desperately disappointing, but we have done this before, successfully, and we run smaller more casual events from time to time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, not everyone has money to give to something like Solstice Shorts - we don't, for example! We give our time and ideas and energy and enthusiasm, and we really need help to make sure as many people as possible know about our festival, and can come along - so if you can't contribute any cash, can you:
  • Share our campaign with others who might contribute
  • Help us promote the event (especially if you are reasonably local!) through linking to us on facebook and twitter and anywhere else you think would work.
THANK YOU!

story:
Short Summary

We are a small troupe of theater artists, most of whom are recent graduates of Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle, Washington. We are putting up a production of a new work entitled Raisins in a Glass of Milk at the end of this month. 

Raisins in a Glass of Milk  is a one act play that brings the hilarious, heart-breaking and shocking stories and experiences of actors of color from across the country, out of the darkness and into the spotlight. Through this collection of scenes and monologues we aim to show that People of Color should finally be seen as a standard, essential part of storytelling as opposed to stereotypes, controversies, and out of date statements.

We feel this play is vitally important to the theater community and evokes a racial conversation that needs to happen. But, in order to do all of that we need a way to pay the people who are working so hard to put on such an impactful piece of theater. By helping us reach our goal of $1800, we will be able to pay each of the six actors, the director, that stage manager, and our scenic designer $200 for rehearsals and performances. This is no where near what they deserve for their valiant efforts, but it is something that rewards them for their important work, and helps them put a small dent in rent,  


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise as much as possible, but whatever we raise will be split within our team of raisins. We do want to show our extreme gratitude for donating to our cause and below are things we want to give you in return for your generosity: 

  • For $25 you will get a signed poster from the cast
  • For $50 you will get a signed poster and your name in the program 
  • For $100 you will get a signed poster, your name in the program, and a pair of tickets to see the show you are so graciously supporting 
  • For $200 you will get a signed poster, your name in the program, a pair of tickets to see the show, and we will specially reserve you the best seats in the house 
  • For $250 and above you will get a signed poster, your name in the program, a pair of tickets to see the show, fantastic seats, and a personal meet and greet with the entire cast so that we can express our immense gratitude in person 

Impact

By contributing to our cause you are:
  • Helping us give a voice to people who have been silenced for too long
  • Spreading this play's message of a need for love and understanding especially in tumultuous times 
  • Showing theater artists that their work means something to the world 

Risks & Challenges

We have a venue for this play, and we have people who care endlessly for this play and the messages it spreads, so we will make this production happen no matter what, but by contributing to our cause you are helping promote the idea that artists should get paid a living wage for the important work they do.   

Other Ways You Can Help

No matter if you are able contribute, or how much you are able to contribute we would love to have you in our audience watching this play, we promise to make you laugh, possibly make you cry, and defiantly make you feel. We run August 25th- 27th at the Alhadeff Studio in Seattle Center. Below is the link to buy tickets: 

  • http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2568810
