story:
A Story About the Power and Perils of Finding True Love

Sometimes there are stories that just need to be told, and this is a story that I've been waiting to tell for more than 20 years.

I was honored to have been chosen by the Gay City Arts Curating Council to participate in Gay City Arts: Uncontained, their 4th annual performing arts season. I'm honored to now stand with an elite group of emerging and established queer artists in Seattle, some of the city's finest.

Your support for this production will ensure that this story about queer life, love, and loss will get told.

About The Production

When There Were Angels is being co-produced by Gay City Arts and Jetspace Magazine. It will play in the Calamus Auditorium at Gay City: Seattle's LGBTQ Center the second and third weekends of November. It was written and will be directed by Robert Roth, with Christian Swacker serving as Co-producer and Elby Brosch as Technical Director. It features a diverse cast of queer performers, including notable actor and cosplayer Abie Ekenezar, actor and director Moshe Henderson, actor and comedian Nick Sahoyah, comedian and host Jeffrey Robert, actor and singer Javion Smith, and introduces actor Collin Fitzgerald to the Seattle theater scene.

 

Abie & Collin

 

Moshe & Jeffrey

 

Nick & Javion

The play tells the story of a young man, looking to discover himself and come to terms with his sexuality, who runs away from his life in Minneapolis to the Broadway Hostel in San Francisco’s North Beach. It’s there that he makes the first real friends of his new life, as well as meets the man who shows him what true love really feels like. At times poignant, funny, and tragic, it’s an adventure of the heart that changes their lives forever.

About The Campaign

The estimated cost of the production is approximately $4,000, and includes:

  • $2,000 for actor compensation
  • $1000 for sound, lighting, and technical direction
  • $500 for sets
  • $500 for marketing

While these costs will be offset by ticket sales, this campaign will help ensure that any upfront costs of the production. I will not be taking any compensation from the show's revenue, and will otherwise be covering any upfront costs out of my own pocket.

The $1,500 raised through this campaign will used as follows:

  • $500 for sets
  • $500 for marketing
  • $500 towards technical needs and actor compensation.

If we don't reach our campaign goal, any funds raised will be used in that order.

About Me 

I’m Robert Roth, a Seattle-based writer and photographer, as well as a marketing, communications, design, and event production professional.

I’m the Editor-in-Chief for Jetspace Magazine, the place to see news, reviews, interviews, and more from around the Pacific Northwest, all from a decidedly queer perspective. You can check out my writing and photography here. I also do freelance creative work for Jetspace Studio, where I’m Principal and Lead Creative.

I write and illustrate a web comic called Birdy & Oso, which may or may not be somewhat based on real-life events.

I’m also a total nerd.

About You

You are a support of queer arts. You want to see queer writers, actors, performers, and theater professionals overcome the challenges of competing against big budget theaters for an audience. You want to see queer artists succeed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, but still want to help, we'd love it if you spread the word about the campaign or about the play.

  • RSVP on the Facebook event page
  • Follow us on our Facebook page
  • Follow us on Twitter
  • Get tickets to see the show
  • Spread the word!
story_txt:
A Story About the Power and Perils of Finding True Love

Sometimes there are stories that just need to be told, and this is a story that I've been waiting to tell for more than 20 years.
I was honored to have been chosen by the Gay City Arts Curating Council to participate in Gay City Arts: Uncontained, their 4th annual performing arts season. I'm honored to now stand with an elite group of emerging and established queer artists in Seattle, some of the city's finest.
Your support for this production will ensure that this story about queer life, love, and loss will get told.
About The Production
When There Were Angels is being co-produced by Gay City Arts and Jetspace Magazine. It will play in the Calamus Auditorium at Gay City: Seattle's LGBTQ Center the second and third weekends of November. It was written and will be directed by Robert Roth, with Christian Swacker serving as Co-producer and Elby Brosch as Technical Director. It features a diverse cast of queer performers, including notable actor and cosplayer Abie Ekenezar, actor and director Moshe Henderson, actor and comedian Nick Sahoyah, comedian and host Jeffrey Robert, actor and singer Javion Smith, and introduces actor Collin Fitzgerald to the Seattle theater scene.
 
Abie & Collin
 
Moshe & Jeffrey
 
Nick & Javion
The play tells the story of a young man, looking to discover himself and come to terms with his sexuality, who runs away from his life in Minneapolis to the Broadway Hostel in San Francisco’s North Beach. It’s there that he makes the first real friends of his new life, as well as meets the man who shows him what true love really feels like. At times poignant, funny, and tragic, it’s an adventure of the heart that changes their lives forever.

About The Campaign

The estimated cost of the production is approximately $4,000, and includes:

$2,000 for actor compensation

story:
Hello!

It's Madison Maylin and James Lawrence of Black Sheep Productions, here - a new film and theatre company that seeks to tell important, thrilling, and bold stories. Thanks for taking a look at our fundraising page.

We're the team behind Tyke - a gripping new play by Rebecca Monks that imagines the events leading up to the true story of an abused circus elephant’s tragic break for freedom. We're taking the show to this summer's Edinburgh Fringe Festival for a full (month-long) run, with three previews at Above The Arts Theatre in Leicester Square. 10% of all our takings at the Fringe will go to a (soon to be chosen) animal welfare charity.


So, what's it about?

Proudlove’s world-famous circus is crumbling. Faced with a financial crisis, his enterprise could fold within a year. The ringmaster knows he needs to bring in the crowds to save it, and for this, he’s relying on his prize attraction: Tyke the elephant.

Stefan – Proudlove’s protégé – is tasked with teaching Tyke new and more demanding tricks. He hires a skilled and passionate apprentice, Veronica, to assist him. The two fall in love, but their relationship is tested when she rebukes the circus’ brutal training methods.

This touching new play is grounded in the true story of Tyke – who killed her trainer in front of thousands of circus spectators, escaped, and died in a hail of gunfire. The play uses puppetry to explore love, power, morality, and animal nature.

Why does it matter?

The play revisits and explores one of most infamous deaths of a wild animal in captivity - asking questions about our morality and power as human beings. 

Our treatment of animals and our reasons for keeping them in captivity is still at the forefront of a global conversation. You may have heard of Harambe, the Gorilla shot dead in Cincinnati Zoo last month; or you may have watched Blackfish, a documentary that changed how the world viewed Killer Whales in Seaworld. 

Sharing Tyke's story is important because wild animals are still mistreated all over the world, and right here in the UK, it's still legal to use wild animals in circuses. 

Why are you fundraising?

Taking a show up to the Fringe is expensive, and our project requires a big team to pull it off.  As a company, we aim to be completely open with everyone who works with us, and those who help fund us can expect the same transparency. Below you can see how far your donation could go.

  • Puppet: Tyke is a beautiful life-size elephant puppet which is being built by the extremely talented Maia Kirkman-Richards. Approx £400 for materials
  • Accommodation and travel: We have to get our 6 performers and Tyke up to Edinburgh, and put a roof over their heads for a month. Approx £2,250
  • Marketing / flyers / posters / listings in apps and magazines: With so many shows at the Fringe, getting the word out is essential: Approx £600
  • Insurance and contingency: We want to make sure the show can still go on should anything happen. Approx £380
Paying our performers is not covered in this crowd-funding goal. 

We're part of the Free Fringe, which means no tickets and no box office - we rely on audience donations at the end of each show. We have chosen not to use the traditional 'profit-share' model (which usually means that the cast wait for weeks to be paid, and only after production costs have been recouped). Instead, we're working to the below model, which makes it harder for the company to recoup but we feel that it's the fairest way to do things. Our two directors and our producer are actors too, so we feel strongly about this issue.

  • 50% of all donations will go directly to our performing company
  • 40% to recouping production expenses (if we don't raise enough here)
  • 10% to an animal welfare charity


How can I help?

We hope to create stimulating and moving theatre whilst contributing to a vital global discussion on animal welfare. We want to raise money and awareness for an amazing cause. And we don't want Tyke's story to finish in Edinburgh, we are aiming to secure a transfer or tour of the show, and your contribution helps us reach a potential audience of thousands.

But to do this, we need your help. We have a range of really exciting perks for those who contribute to our campaign:

  • Free tickets and a glass of prosecco to our West End previews
  • Signed posters and memorabilia from the show
  • Free photoshoot
  • Free 1-hour puppet workshop with Tyke herself
  • 1 week stay in a luxury villa for 8 people in Puerto Banus, Marbella
Can't contribute financially? We totally get it. Really, we do. But could you help us make some noise around the show?
  • Follow  @TykeThePlay 
  • Tweet using #TykeThePlay
  • Share our event on Facebook: Previews and the Edinburgh Run
  • Share our IndieGogo campaign far and wide
  • Know any charities, or people interested in sponsoring us? Put them in touch via madisonmaylin@gmail.com

Who are you?

We've assembled a really exciting creative team to help bring Tyke to life:

  • Writer: Rebecca Monks. Author and Journalist at The List Magazine. Her 2015 show Scour received  ★★★★★ and was hailed as: 'the best thing on the Fringe', and 'exemplary theatre'.
  • Co-Director: Madison Maylin. Actor and director. Directed Full Circle at the Arts Theatre in the West End, receiving ★★★★ reviews from FemaleArts and London City Nights for her 'deft touch'
  • Co-Director: Madelaine Cunningham. Actor, director and writer. Winner of Best New South African Script and Best Newcomer for her performance in play Transition. ★★★★ in South Africa's National Theatre Festival.
  • Producer: James Lawrence. His last performance in a Fringe show, Travesti, won the Scotsman Fringe First and Three Weeks Editors' Awards, and received ★★★★★ from The Skinny, who called it 'a masterpiece of modern theatre'. 
  • Puppet Maker: Maia Kirkman-Richards. Maia is Artistic Director of puppetry theatre company House of Stray Cats. 'inventively made and helmed puppets' - A Younger Theatre
  • Puppet Director: Alice Sillett. Artistic Director of critically acclaimed puppetry company Moon On A Stick -‘Truly magical’ ,‘Different, original and visually captivating'


Thank you so much for all your support, see you at the Fringe!

story:
Hi!  I'm Jadrian, and this is my beard.

I've done all kinds of stupid things with my facial hair over the years...

... but in 2011 I wondered what would happen if I just stopped trying to shape or trim it at all. I've always just kept new facial hair designs until I got sick of them, and I figured I'd get tired of having a big, unruly beard within about a year or so. Turns out I was wrong. It kept growing and growing, untrimmed and untamed, for five years.

Though the time has finally come to cut it off, I've always thought it would be fun if it were detachable, so I could lend it out to other folks who've told me they wished they had a big weird beard like mine. I had a dream of secretly making it into a wig, continuing to wear it so people thought I still had a beard, and then ripping it off dramatically at the end of my dissertation defense. (Turned out that wasn't in the cards.) I wanted to lend it out to drag-king friends in Minneapolis to use in shows, or to baby-faced North Carolinians or Brooklynites who couldn't grow their own but needed some beard cred.

Really, my belief has always been that the primary purpose of facial hair is to add weirdness to the world, and now I have an opportunity to keep that going beyond my own face. I'd love to get your help.

 

What I Need

I'm asking for $500 to cover the costs of turning my beard into a wig. The vast majority of it (probably about $400) will go to a professional theater costume / make-up artist to cut off my beard, make a mold of my face, and then build a wig from the beard hairs to fit the mold and replicate the original. It's very important to me to pay artists fairly, and building a wig is a specialized and time-consuming task.

The rest of the money will cover my travel costs in case I have to contract an out-of-state artist. I will donate any extra money to the Sylvia Rivera Law Project, which does wonderful work to support trans*, intersex, and gender-non-conforming people across the USA.

This is a "flexible funding" campaign, so if donations fall short of the goal, I'll still use your money: I'll donate 10% of it to the SRLP, pay the rest to the artist, and make up the remaining pay for the artist and other costs with my own funds.

 

What You Get

In return for your donation, you can get:

  • The first photos of my chin in more than five years
  • A behind-the-scenes look at the process of making the wig
  • A postcard with (optional) beard hair
  • Updates on the campaign and photos of other people with the beard wig
  • A reservation to borrow my beard for two weeks!

 

The Impact

It's hard for me to say goodbye to this beard, but this project is a fun way to send it out with a bang, to make a small positive impact for trans rights, and to share the weirdness and wonder of having a big beard with more people. A big beard is always a conversation starter, and has a surprising way of bringing people together. Think of how much stranger those conversations would be if you could let someone else try it on for a moment!

 

Risks & Challenges

I have only second-hand knowledge of making wigs, so I'm contracting out that task to a yet-to-be-determined artist. This means that, though I'll do my best, I can't personally guarantee the quality of the outcome. It's entirely possible that the wig will turn out not to be sturdy enough to ship or to wear often, or it might just be ugly. (Well, uglier than my beard already is.)

The main things I can do to mitigate this risk are carefully research an artist, clearly explain what I'm going for, and pay them to take their time. Through many years of friendships, volunteering, and dabbling, I have a lot of experience communicating with artists, so I think this process will be successful.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you think this idea sounds fun, there are a few things (other than contributing) that you can do to help it come to fruition:

  • Grow your own wacky beard, turn it into a wig, and get it out into the world! The beardier the merrier!
  • Share this page with your friends!
  • If you know a theater artist with experience building wigs, get them in touch with me! (Especially if they live near Philadelphia.)

Thanks, and spread the word!

story:
Short Summary

Dry with a Twist Theatrics is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Dry with a Twist Theatrics must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Dry with a Twist has been given the extraordinary opportunity to premiere a new play entitled The Braggart of Bourbon St. in the New York International Fringe festival this year! It is a tremendous honor to join the two hundred plus companies from around the world presenting work in this spectacular festival.

It is our belief at Dry with a Twist that artists should receive compensation for their monumental gifts of time and effort in bringing a new play to life. These actors, designers, musicians and technicians are giving us their summer because they believe in this new play and this opportunity. Our campaign is to simply raise enough funds to gift our company with a small fee for their efforts and to provide space for them to work.

The Impact of Your Contribution

Your contributions to our cause will be going directly to the artists involved. By contributing to our campaign you will have allowed these artists to feel that their work has worth and help supplement their time in bringing our production to life.

As a contributor, at any level, you will join our fierce family of fearless artists and be able to enjoy some exciting perks as outlined at each level.

Risks & Challenges

Times are tough for small collectives such a Dry with a Twist, and the cost of producing in New York City, even at an independent level, is sometimes crippling. Without your support we will not be able to given these actors, designers and musicians the opportunity to showcase their craft for an audience made up of industry, fellow artists, global companies and our beloved friends and family as afforded in this incredible opportunity by participating in the Festival.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that summers are hard on the wallet, but, if you're unable to contribute to our campaign, please share it with the world! You never know who may just click on us.

story:
Want to help launch astronauts into space?

There was probably some point in time where you were like wouldn't it be so cool to be an astronaut?  Well, hopefully if you did become astronaut, you wouldn't encounter ghosts and aliens and a malfunctioning spaceship. Because that's what's about to happen to these five astronauts in a new play called Merkur and Venera.
This summer, Lunar Autumn Theatre is staging a space travel story: science fiction tinged in horror and also the very human fear of letting go of the past. Emily Wrolson, a recent Augsburg College graduate, is directing the play, which was written by Evan Peterson—who is currently entering his third year at Augsburg. The play has been revised, the show is cast, we're ready to make this play a reality.
Allow us to tell you the story (in the most non-spolier-iest terms) and then tell you our story and why we would love for your help in order to make this show as vivid as possible.

The Story

Five astronauts are trapped inside a spaceship en route to terraform a distant planet. Discussions of memories evolve into heated discussions on whether or not ghosts and aliens exist. Then, when the lights begin to falter, they gradually begin to expect the worst. Then the unimaginable happens.

Merkur and Venera has gone through several revisions in a short span of time. A little over a year ago, the first draft was hastily written in between classes. The story was expanded in a Playwriting I class the following year, and then revised. The play has now been accepted into the 2016 Minnesota Fringe Festival. But we need your help. We've already received assistance with the production fees, but there are more expenses and ways you can help (which we will love you for, btw.) Your support of this play means support of new play development and support of young theatermakers.


So What's The Deal With This Thing? (Or: Why Do We Need Support?)

So: by supporting this production, you'll be helping us pay for a multitude of things: production costs, marketing materials, social media boosts, costumes, props, and other things which will come into play down the road.

This show is surprisingly light on tech. There aren't tons of lights or sounds, and it isn't necessary to construct an elaborate set or hire a costumer or anything like that. This show is simplistic, and that's easy on everyone. However: getting the word out is not that easy. There a promotional postcards which need to be printed, ad space which needs to be bought, programs which need to be printed, posters which need to be designed and printed—all of which, unfortunately, costs money.

That's where you come in! If we can gather more funds, we can advertise our show better. And more/better advertisements = better publicity = more people in seats = better turnout in general.

The majority of funding will go to covering the cost of postcards (lots and lots and lots of postcards, as that's the main mode of advertisement in the Fringe.) We'll also be able to buy a "featured show" promotional space on the Fringe website, and distribute posters, boost social media presence, or do anything else we can to get this show to as many people as possible.

The remaining funding will go to costuming and making the show look as stellar as possible.


Hold Up. Specifically: Where's The Money Going?

So glad you asked! Here's the breakdown:

Production Fee - $450
Postcards - $300 (approx. 30 postcards per venue x 16 venues x 9 days)
Programs - $100
Stipends for Cast and Crew - $250
Featured Show Status - $100
Set Design - $150
Costumes - $150

These numbers are as close of approximations as we can make right now, and of course, are subject to change depending on how much funding we get. Of course, the more funding we get, the better we can advertise our show and increase the production value. If we get more than our projected amount, that money will be spent towards additional promotion and paying our cast and crew more than just the box office payout.


So What's Stopping Us?

We've received financial assistance with the production costs for this show. The Fringe typically requires a $450 production fee be paid upfront. Due to us being college students without $450 at the helm, the Fringe delayed the payment and will take that money out of the box office at the end. Delaying payment like this can be a risk, if a show doesn't get many people in the doors and receives under $450 in box office sales. That would mean the artist gets no money and the Fringe loses money. That's bad.

While that is a potential risk, it's a risk we shouldn't have to worry about. While it's not critically necessary, it would be ideal to be able to pay some (if not all) of the production fee from fundraising. That would mean more money from the box office going directly to the artists. That's good.

But the biggest challenge is the time constraint. We're trying our darnedest to make a spooky, beautiful (spookily beautiful? beautifully spooky?) show in a month and a few days. And we'll make it. But we'll be working on it every day from now until August. We're working on a strict schedule. And with you on board with us, we can ensure that that month-and-a-few-weeks go by in smooth sailing.


Um, I Want to Help But Money's Tight

Maybe, right now, you're not in a position to donate money. And that's okay. We get it. But don't leave! You can still help!

"How?" you ask.

"Well," we say, leaning forward in our chair, assuming a dramatic voice. "The internets."

Yes: the internet. Social media is incredibly powerful and waayyyyyy cheaper than print. We'd love it if you could boost our show on whatever social media platforms you use. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, Pinterest, Yelp, Foursquare (idk, whatever you use.)

If you're interested in joining our street team, get in contact with us! (We don't actually have a street team yet, but that could totally be a thing that happens.)

I guess what we're trying to say is: make noise. If you can't donate, or even if you can: get the word out there. Because we can be promoting this show from here to oblivion, but that only gets us so far. With you on board, the impact of our reach will grow exponentially. And that would be really cool.


But When Can I See It?

Soon enough. There are five performances:

Thursday, August 4 at 7:00 PM

Saturday, August 6 at 1:00 PM

Tuesday, August 9 at 8:30 PM

Friday, August 12 at 10:00 PM

Saturday, August 13 at 1:00 PM

All performances take place at the University of Minnesota Rarig Center in the Arena Stage. Tickets will go on presale July 1.


Thank you so, so much for your support. We'll see you space.

—Evan and Emily and the whole Merkur and Venera crew
story_txt:
Want to help launch astronauts into space?
There was probably some point in time where you were like wouldn't it be so cool to be an astronaut?  Well, hopefully if you did become astronaut, you wouldn't encounter ghosts and aliens and a malfunctioning spaceship. Because that's what's about to happen to these five astronauts in a new play called Merkur and Venera.

This summer, Lunar Autumn Theatre is staging a space travel story: science fiction tinged in horror and also the very human fear of letting go of the past. Emily Wrolson, a recent Augsburg College graduate, is directing the play, which was written by Evan Peterson—who is currently entering his third year at Augsburg. The play has been revised, the show is cast, we're ready to make this play a reality.
Allow us to tell you the story (in the most non-spolier-iest terms) and then tell you our story and why we would love for your help in order to make this show as vivid as possible.

The Story 
Five astronauts are trapped inside a spaceship en route to terraform a distant planet. Discussions of memories evolve into heated discussions on whether or not ghosts and aliens exist. Then, when the lights begin to falter, they gradually begin to expect the worst. Then the unimaginable happens.
Merkur and Venera has gone through several revisions in a short span of time. A little over a year ago, the first draft was hastily written in between classes. The story was expanded in a Playwriting I class the following year, and then revised. The play has now been accepted into the 2016 Minnesota Fringe Festival. But we need your help. We've already received assistance with the production fees, but there are more expenses and ways you can help (which we will love you for, btw.) Your support of this play means support of new play development and support of young theatermakers.

But When Can I See It?

All performances take place at the University of Minnesota Rarig Center in the Arena Stage. Tickets will go on presale July 1.

story:
Our Goal

Contributions to this campaign will support the west coast premiere of A Breakup Is Swift, following its success at the Capital Fringe Festival. The play received five stars from DC Metro Theater Arts, and caught the eye of critics at Washington City Paper, Washington Post, DCist, and DC Theater Scene. At the festival we met Susan Jackson and Diana Brown of Southern Railroad Theatre Company, who encouraged us to find a new audience in their home of San Francisco. Donations will help three of the play’s original actors, Ben Kleymeyer, Elle Sullivan, Nick Duckworth, travel to the Bay Area and pay for additional production expenses. We’ve raised $1,500 so far toward our overall goal of $15,000 to make it happen. We are now fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non‐profit arts service organization. As a result, your contributions for the charitable purposes of A Breakup Is Swift are tax deductible!

"A Breakup Is Swift is quickly relatable, and funnier than I expected. By enjoying the awkwardness, the audience finds solace that, yes, we’ve all been there before."
--Alan Zilberman, Washington City Paper

About the Project

“It started when a friend sent me a written copy of a breakup conversation,” says artist Clint Bagwell. “I was challenged to find actors who would re-create the real-life event and interpret it in their own way.” The six scheduled shows use the same script, but each is uniquely delivered by a different set of performers.

"Artist Clint Bagwell has lifted the virtual messages of an ending relationship, into a heightened theatrical piece that is memorably gender-defied."
--Benjamin Dennis, DC Metro Theater Arts

The play follows “Cameron” and “Dale” as they rehash the their brief but intense encounter. A Breakup Is Swift promises nothing profound in the words that are spoken; instead the actors offer a hyper-realistic portrayal of two people talking in an honest way. The artist recounts the early stages of his creative process: “when I read the text, I didn’t want to alter anything, but I did change names and references to specific locations. I found that if I also made the gender of each character open, we could play with those possibilities.”

Actor Ben Kleymeyer plays “Dale” in two different performances; once against a male “Cameron” then again with a female version. “Creating two different characters from the same text is not something I’ve done before. They ultimately have the same goals/needs/character traits, but what is different is how these things manifest themselves… and how they interact with the other character. I imagine it to be like what would happen if you watched the same person in two different relationships,” he explains.

"Much of the dialogue feels like something I've said or heard from someone while falling out of love."
--Amanda Erickson, Washington Post

How your contribution will be used:

Funds from our immediate goal of $3,500 will go towards insurance for the shows, and help us purchase airline tickets at optimal rates. This Indiegogo campaign is just part of our overall strategy to raise a total of $15,000 for the project. Other expenses include rental of the venues Exit Theatre and Stage Werx (already paid), printing, promotion, light operators, materials for merchandise, and other miscellaneous expenses. Most importantly, we believe that the creative talent should be rewarded for their hard work--meeting our total fundraising goal ensures that actors are paid, plus lodging and a modest per diem is provided for their trip.

PERKS

As a contributor, you'll receive our never ending gratitude. At certain levels, donors will enjoy special access to the creative process through video interviews and invitations to private rehearsals. We also offer gifts in the form of limited edition posters and t-shirts.

"Shows a real breakup conversation, in all its unsparing hilarity... It makes for riveting theater because so much of relationships are performance anyway."
--Rachel Kurzius, DCist

About Us

Clint Bagwell utilizes public space, technology, and collaboration to explore the notion of reality as a social construct. His conceptual work has been exhibited at Southern Exposure Gallery in CA, Impakt Audiovisual Arts Festival in the Netherlands, Collective Unconscious in NY, and University of Mary Washington in VA. Clint Bagwell received an MFA from San Francisco Art Institute and a BFA from Virginia Commonwealth University. He has taught at Virginia Commonwealth University, University of Mary Washington, NOVA Community College, and Howard Community College.

Ben Kleymeyer is a theatre artist and director in the DMV area. He recently graduated from the University of Maryland’s School of Theatre, Dance, and Performance studies. While at UMD he worked as the artistic director of the Maryland Shakespeare Players where he directed A Queer Midsummer Night’s Dream and Macbeth. Ben recently joined the Kennedy Center Directing Intensive Program as an assistant director.

Elle Marie Sullivan earned her degree in theatre from the University of Central Florida and has studied at Stella Adler Studio of Acting and International Performing Arts Institute. She is an Associate Artist at InterAct Story Theatre and was recently seen in Stillpointe Theatre's production of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead.

Nick Duckworth studied acting at UC San Diego and, more recently, has trained with DC's Studio Theatre. He has been featured in a variety of theatre and lm projects in the DMV area including A&A's stage production of Do You Pray or Prey?, the upcoming lm series Thirst, and ID's Evil Kin.

Your Impact on A Breakup Is Swift

DIY projects like this start from scratch and rely on the hard work of the creative talent to produce the show and find an audience. The Fringe shows went better than expected, and we attribute most of that to the hard work the group put into promoting it. We’re trusting to have a similar experience in California, but it will depend on us to make it happen.

Traveling to a new town is a big challenge. Your support will assist the growth of the project as it reaches new cultural and geographic communities. It will also help keep ticket prices affordable, so that we can attract students and emerging artists in the Bay Area.

"In an age where relationships begin with a swipe to the right how do you really know you’ve gotten to know the real person behind the digital façade? These are the questions asked in Clint Bagwell’s new play A Breakup is Swift."
--Sarah Scafidi, DC Theater Scene

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are a member of the artistic community who cannot contribute financially, we hope that you will help spread the word on social media. The Indiegogo share tools on this page make it easy!

And if you're in the San Francisco Bay Area, tell a friend: A Breakup Is Swift is taking on California this January!

Thanks for your support, and LET'S GET AWKWARD!

---

A Breakup Is Swift is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of A Breakup Is Swift must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
About GET OVER YOURSELF

This one woman show is written, performed, and produced by Kristin Mothersbaugh and directed by Jessica Lynn Johnson of Soaring Solo. The Hollywood Fringe Festival 2016 is only the second time the show will be produced, and it is very exciting! Joseph Orellana and Megan DeHart are helping with the Tech! The performances are at the Underground Theatre Annex at 1314 N. Wilton Pl. in Los Angeles, CA at 8:00 pm on Saturday June 25th and 2:00 pm on Sunday the 26th. Tickets are available on the Fringe page at: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/3811. Use the code "self love" for $10 tickets!!! :D

The plans are now underway for Get Over Yourself to show in the United Solo Theatre Festival in New York  and in Chicago's Greenhouse Theatre Center's Solo Celebration in 2017. Also in the works is taking the show to my past schools in Cole Camp, Sedalia, and Springfield, MO. 


Why Fundraise?

Producing a show is expensive.  All of the theatre festivals cost money to be a part of, then there is rehearsal fees with the director, renting the space, postcards, programs, and ads, and trying to help out the tech crew, not to mention buying new equipment and travel fees.


Why help out?

Contributing to independent solo theatre is contributing to the lone artist in all of us. Fundraising this show may also help bring it close to you. This show is completely self-produced with any money I have other than rent going to it.  Any donation is greatly appreciated and goes a long way! Donating to GET OVER YOURSELF is sending the message that we don't have to wait for approval for our dreams to come true, we can make them happen ourselves.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are a broke artist too, I get it. If you can't donate, please just share! 

Social Media is a great outreach for causes such as these. 


Thank you all so much!


Love,

Kristin Mothersbaugh

story:
7 Doors is a story of loss, pain and hope told through powerful choreography and dynamic original music

The Impact

The idea of 7 Doors came to me through my own painful experience of loss. A divorce that felt like a death! I was so devastated and thought, how am I even existing? How will I ever feel normal again? It was one of the hardest things I've been through. But being on the other side of that loss I am stronger, wiser and my ability to love is greater. Surviving that pain showed me how fragile and precious life is and how powerful LOVE can be.  - Alessandro Pellicani, creator and director/choreographer

I've had similar life experiences, as have so many others. Through this show we believe we can bring the human experience to the stage in a way that hasn't been done before. It was so incredible to share the beginning of this project with an audience back in April at BAM studios. The response was so overwhelmingly positive that we know this project will succeed. Our ultimate goal is to eventually bring it on a Broadway Stage. Be a part of our dream!  -Jesse Brewster, co-creator and composer/lyricist

What are we asking:

  • We are asking for $43,000 so that we will be able to continue our developmental journey to a full production stage, paying for the performance and rehearsal space, the cast and creative team, stage manager, and travel for our composer, aerial choreographer and videographer 
  • we are excited to offer you unique perks in exchange for your generous donation, check them out. Especially if you like to dance and Italian cusine.
  • In case we don't reach our goal we will use the funds to record and master as many songs as possible that will be featured on a full length album of the show's soundtrack.
  • Just remember that every $ counts, there's no such a thing as a small donation. With your contribution you will be a part of bringing this groundbreaking and original production to life!
  • If you can't help financially there's always the good old fashion way of word of mouth, so spread the word, you never know who's listening.

Thanks for your time, the 7 DOORS team!!!

story:
What is Bar Wotever?

Bar Wotever is a weekly queer cabaret night that is held at the Royal Vauxhall Tavern every Tuesday evening. It is a platform for performers to showcase their work to a loving audience and a place for people to feel loved and welcome. 

Bar Wotever has been running for over 11 years and is one of the longest cabaret nights in the world. We would like to take Bar Wotever on tour to spread our love, energy, and wotevers all over the United Kingdom. It is important that we take our loving environment and place it around the UK so everyone has the chance to feel welcome in a queer space. By offering open mic slots to the local community, Bar Wotever on Tour will reach out to people around the UK who may want to perform on a stage but don't necessarily  have the platform to do so. 

In each city we visit, we will create a space that includes everyone (no discrimination tolerated). There will be performances by regular performance artist from Wotever World, a call for open mics for people who wish to perform who live locally, and of course, community news, so that we can help spread the good news and events that are happening around the city we are visiting.

Cities we will be visiting so far include:

 Glasgow - 30th September

 Bristol - 7-9 October 

Brighton - 12-13 October 

Exeter - February 

And More TBC

To receive donations from other Wotevers would leave us extremely thankful. The donations would allow for us to achieve our goals and spread our energy around the UK.


What We Need & What You Get

The money raised will go towards:

- Travel

- Accommodation 

- Paying the acts and crew - We would love to be able to pay our acts a reasonable price for their effort, time, and fabulousness. We would love to be able to pay the crew for all of their hard work for the duration of the tour. 

- Relevant Insurance costs

- And all of the unexpected costs that may appear.

By donating £10 you will provide an artist or crew member with dinner. 

By donating £20 you will contribute towards a train ticket to a tour location.

By donating £50 you will contribute towards a hotel room for an artist(s) or crew member(s) for the night. 

Check out our perks to see what we can offer you in return for you generosity! 

The Impact

We want to take Bar Wotever on tour so we can sow our seeds of love, energy, and community around the UK. We understand that some parts of the UK do not have a large LGBTQ+ community and would love to bring our loving family and safe space to those places. By having two open mic slots we will create a platform for those who wish to perform but don't quite know how or where to begin. By hosting many queer nights and events in London, Wotever World already has a huge impact on the LGBTQ+ community. Wotever World has created friendships, relationships, and many many fond memories over the years and we wish to continue to provide these connections by touring the UK. 

Challenges

We understand that going on tour comes with it's challenges but we believe we can jump over any hurdles that come our way with the help from everyone at Wotever World, our performers, and our loving audience members! 

Social Media

Follow us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/WoteverWorldLtd/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/woteverworld

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/woteverworld/

story:
Short Summary

We're All Friends Here present In. A. Hoop., the first production in a body of works created through verbatim montage. Writer Darren Yorke, director Sarah Bradley and aerial performer and actor, Kate Finegan have collaborated on this piece. 

In. A. Hoop. has been accepted to be showcased as part of the Scene + Heard Festival of new works in progress in Smock Alley in February 2017. 

The Scene + Heard Festival graciously provides an excellent platform for developing work, allowing it to be critiqued by its audience who give honest feedback through a variety of mediums. 

In. A. Hoop. will have the opportunity to be seen by a number of representatives from producing companies, venues and festivals, who, if they see potential in the project, are in a position to support it as it develops further towards full production stage.

Your donation would contribute to covering the logistical costs of safely staging an aerial performance, which are outlined in more detail below :-)

What We Need & What You Get

We are running this project on an incredibly low budget, but due to the collaborative nature of this unfunded festival, potential income from box office will still not be sufficient to cover our costs.

We are raising €500 to cover our expenses for staging In. A. Hoop. at the Scene + Heard Festival this February.

This money will go towards hiring a professional aerial technician to rig the aerial hoop in the venue in compliance with health and safety standards, the hire of aerial performance rehearsal space, flyers and costume.

Although we have a small amount to raise, we are still offering some great perks for your donation. You can get tickets for the show and a free flexibility class with Kate, our performer.

The Impact

In. A. Hoop. is innovative art in its exploration of verbatim montage as a form of dramatic writing and as a combination of aerial dance and theatre in a one-woman style show.

Your contribution will covering the logistical costs of staging this formally inventive  production. 

Projects like this are increasingly difficult to acquire funding for as the arts are now funded on a project-by-project basis in Ireland, leaving little room for the development of scripts and the invaluable amount of audience feedback that comes with the Scene + Heard Festival.

Risks & Challenges

We are almost there! A wise person once said that the hardest thing was coming up with an idea. 

The folks at Scene + Heard certainly think we've got something great to give and we have been working our socks off developing the script and performance. With a proven track record in successful theatre and performance work, our cast and crew are sure to knock it out of the park.

The big risk facing us is that without this money, we would be unable to safely prepare the theatre for the show, and therefore, could face cancelling the performance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to donate, there are plenty more ways in which you can help!

  • Come see the show! We are doing this to get valuable audience feedback and would love to see you there!
  • Please share this campaign with friends, family and followers via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter etc.
  • If you can provide or know of any rehearsal space for free or discounted in Dublin, please get in touch. Similarly, if you can provide a discount on flyer printing, we're certainly interested.

Thank you for your time and attention. We hope to see you in Smock Alley this February 16th-18th at 9.30pm and 18th at 2pm for the first run of In. A. Hoop. as a work in development.

story:
Fund a raw, riveting, transformative performance retelling potent sacred stories!

 The collection of stories presented in From Eve to Me was created over AmyJo Mattheis’ professional life as an ordained pastor, university professor, non-profit executive and as a mother, daughter, lover, partner, friend and citizen of this world and universe. In this masterful performance, AmyJo skillfully guides her audience through an experience of ancient sacred stories from the voice of the feminine that remaps the shape of how we have been told to view the world and be in it; shifting the painful stories of domination, scarcity, separation and control to a tale of abundance, co-creation, sensuality and unity.

This transformational work retells the stories that divide, separate and breed fear in our collective consciousness, inspiring all who see the performance to become cultural and societal change agents. Please help this master storyteller, biblical scholar and agent of inspiration bring From Eve to Me to the stage!

LIVING INTO A NEW STORY  - At a time when our world appears fragmented, hostile and unbelievably misogynist, a new foundational story is necessary. You can be a part of this movement to heal the world!

As a Lutheran Pastor, AmyJo heard the stories of her congregants burdened with the belief that no matter what they did, they were not good enough. As a university professor, she read the life-stories of students who routinely struggled with the idea that they were flawed and had to prove their worth. Living and working around the world taught her that this is a shared phenomenon. You may have struggled with these feelings yourself.

Story is the way we learn. We are shaped in spirit and mind by the narratives we tell as well as by the collective stories that have shaped society. The Creation Myth is the foundation of Western Civilization. Shared by three world religions, this story has done more to disconnect and separate individuals from their true, authentic heart and from each other, than any story ever told.

Re-telling this story from the long-silenced voice of Eve allows us to experience Her story live, to connect with the wisdom and reality of Love, and to remember the creativity and abundance of our souls. Retelling the most potent and foundational story of our civilization will profoundly alter the reality of our world today.

Contributing to From Eve to Me is making possible the dissemination of badly needed medicine for a society sick from the story of domination, judgement, separation and scarcity.

Funding From Eve to Me brings healing to individuals who struggle with the dis-ease of self-doubt and to the wider community by dissolving the illusion of separation and weaving a web of interconnection through Love. 

If you haven’t seen the show, but would love to experience it vicariously … here’s what people are saying about From Eve to Me:

"I laughed, I cried, I grieved the pain of all women who were never able to share their stories, or who were never witnessed for their truth and love.  Thank you for bringing these women to life, so we might see them in a different way.  Finally HERstory is being told!" Cindy Ma, Founder and Host, SHE Living TV. Berkeley CA

"Mesmerizing. Energetic. Honest. Empowering. Inspiring." Heather, CA.

“Damaging patriarchal stories were re-told in a way that was actually healing; no one was made wrong. It was truly an opening up to love.”  Brian, CA.

“The combination of AmyJo’s scholarship, years of experience, skills and deep believing in how it was, allows her to transform a very old, limiting and often degrading story, into Love, allowing us to see More than One Side of the Story.” Brenda, CA.

“To say I was captivated the moment AmyJo started speaking, would be an understatement. She has a real authentic gift for creating meaning through metaphor and every sense of my being was wrapped up in the words she spoke, as she told the spiritual tale. Time stood still, and it felt as though we were all holding our breath…watching, waiting as AmyJo relived the story and made it understandable and real.” Karen, England

“AmyJo is riveting as a sacred storyteller. As she weaves the story, she transports you back in time and into the thoughts and emotions of the main character so that you too, experience the event on a visceral level. I was mesmerized during her performance and have reflected back on her teaching numerous times.” Bonnie, Indiana

CALL TO ACTION!

  • Financially contribute and help us reach our $33,000 goal in 40 days!
  • Get the word out! Please tell your friends, family and community about From Eve to Me! Like our posts on Facebook, re-tweet our latest updates, or, even better, share your enthusiasm in person! Sharing our Indiegogo campaign will help us raise the money we need to bring From Eve to Me to a broader audience!
  •  Volunteer your marketing, social media or event planning skills to help us improve our promotion until we can fund a part-time position.
  •  Offer your space to host a From Eve to Me performance. Paying for venues is expensive! We want to offer the show to as many people as possible. Free space would be a great help!
  •  Connect From Eve to Me with your congregation, community or conference. Schedule a performance today!

Re-Telling the Story of Struggle to Grace! 

Anyone who has ever given birth to a new project or raised a child knows that there is a risk that your idea will stumble. As an artist and a mother, the challenge is to live from the belief and tenacity that it is time for From Eve to Me to go out into the world.

As a creator, AmyJo strives to live into the story of endless possibility, grace, ease, abundance and trust that when we follow our hearts and listen to our instinct, the path is opened and connections with all that we need align.

There are so many stories to re-tell and so many people to reach! If we do not receive additional funding, we will not be able to expand, to hire support staff or to focus on creating more sacred stories.

To address these challenges, the team at From Eve to Me is committed to the following:

1)  Creatively sourcing performances so that From Eve to Me has a consistent schedule of shows for individuals to attend.

2)  Remembering that From Eve to Me is bigger than any one person and engaging others in this movement.

3) Focusing on building and expanding the show’s reach using whatever means possible.

story:
Short Summary

Our new show is all about Snow, North Pole, A Terrible Disaster and a little bit, just a little bit about Love.

My Love Lies Frozen In The Ice...

A tale of love, loss and an unexplained power of the human heart.

A dark and mysterious tale of a balloon expedition. In 1897, three explorers took off to the North Pole in a free-flying balloon. The trip was supposed to last a month. It took a little longer... Behind them, at home, they left a woman who could not forget them… Follow us on that journey through the whiter than white snow and darker than dark nights, where nothing is what it seems… 

Dead Rabbits theatre is a young physical theatre company under the artistic direction of Kasia Zaremba-Byrne. The company style relies on visual, ensemble storytelling, puppetry and a large dose of humour.

In the Summer of 2016, the company won 2 international awards for 'The Dragon' at Edmonton Fringe Festival, Canada.

'The Dragon' was a sold out show and got 5 out of 5-star review from the main local newspaper – Edmonton Journal.

http://edmontonjournal.com/entertainment/festiv...

We love traveling and showing our work to very different audiences. At the same time, we meet lots of great people and have lots of fun. We hope our audiences also share our sentiments!!

We don't have any funding and all the work is supported from our own pocket. Sure, this should change soon, if we keep going and audiences like us. We work very hard and hopefully, this will show. 

Your money will go towards the design of the show, costumes and set. Perhaps even towards some of the costs of flights to Canada. We are not paid for our work, but maybe one day we will be. That's our hope at least. 

Come and see us in Canada and say hello if you spot us flyering outside the festival venues... we like to chat...

And please tell others if you like us....

story:
It's in your future to give.

FUTURE tense! needs your generous financial support. 

Donations raised will offset the costs of producing and live streaming of the two-show series featuring futurists, comic and music artists on Sat. Nov 19 and Sat. Dec 17, 2016 at Lee’s Palace Upstairs Cave.

"I think of art, at its most significant, as a DEW line, a Distant Early Warning system that can always be relied on to tell the old culture what is beginning to happen to it."

Marshall McLuhan

Nov 19 and Sat. Dec 17, 2016 at Lee’s Palace Upstairs Cave."I think of art, at its most significant, as a DEW line, a Distant Early Warning system that can always be relied on to tell the old culture what is beginning to happen to it."Marshall McLuhan

story:
It's 1886 and ten-year-old Isabelle is enamored of the enormous statue about to be unveiled in New York harbor. Her father and brother are going to go watch the dedication, and Isabelle doesn't understand why she's not allowed, just because she's a girl. But it turns out that the very thing Isabelle loves about the statue- that a woman has been chosen to represent liberty- has drawn the attention of the Woman's Suffrage Association. They have something to say about it and a daring plan to make themselves heard. Meanwhile Jackie, a young black woman, has her own thoughts about this statue, but is she even at liberty to express them? With cameo appearances by Lillian Devereux Blake, Emma Lazarus, Joseph Pulitzer and others, this play explores the state of women's rights at the time of the birth of an iconic landmark.

Why Donate Now?

Unveiling Liberty has been in the works for a while and is just blossoming now, at a remarkable and frightening moment in the history of our country. We believe that a story like this one, about the history of gender inequality in the United States, the early suffrage and women's rights movements and the intersection between gender and racial inequality, is more relevant now than ever. What is truly the meaning of freedom?

After our March production, we are taking this play into schools in and around Jersey City. We believe that by presenting live theater to school children, we can help them understand the social forces they see influencing politics and society today, and also teach them that history is not a finished story in a book, but is something they can take part in and influence. 

Government funding for the arts is in peril right now, and funding for public education seems precarious as well. However, you can help us keep the theater open. If you believe that supporting your local, professional theater company and arts education can make a difference to children and audiences in the tri-state area, please donate!

Other Ways You Can Help

Just gave your last dime to the ACLU?

  • Help us get the word out by sharing our campaign with others you know!

They have something to say about it and a daring plan to make themselves heard. Meanwhile Jackie, a young black woman, has her own thoughts about this statue, but is she even at liberty to express them? With cameo appearances by Lillian Devereux Blake, Emma Lazarus, Joseph Pulitzer and others, this play explores the state of women's rights at the time of the birth of an iconic landmark.
Why Donate Now?
Unveiling Liberty has been in the works for a while and is just blossoming now, at a remarkable and frightening moment in the history of our country. We believe that a story like this one, about the history of gender inequality in the United States, the early suffrage and women's rights movements and the intersection between gender and racial inequality, is more relevant now than ever. What is truly the meaning of freedom?
After our March production, we are taking this play into schools in and around Jersey City. We believe that by presenting live theater to school children, we can help them understand the social forces they see influencing politics and society today, and also teach them that history is not a finished story in a book, but is something they can take part in and influence. Government funding for the arts is in peril right now, and funding for public education seems precarious as well. However, you can help us keep the theater open. If you believe that supporting your local, professional theater company and arts education can make a difference to children and audiences in the tri-state area, please donate!
Other Ways You Can Help
Just gave your last dime to the ACLU?
Help us get the word out by sharing our campaign with others you know!

story:
What we're up to

Simply put, we have set out to create the best show that we can offer you. We believe in the power of live theater to remind ourselves and our audiences that we're not as separate as we might appear to be, and that genuine communion between people is still possible. Live theater creates this communion, and now more than ever we see this as necessary and beautiful—even integral to our survival.

We also seek to entertain, pure and simple. Since we don't do shows very often and don't have the foundational support of an established, year-round theater company, we need your support. You can help in three easy ways:

  • Come see our show
  • Contribute to this campaign
  • Spread the word like wildfire (via word of mouth, social media, personal emails, and the Indiegogo share tools)

If you feel compelled and can help in any way, we thank you from the bottom of our hearts. 

What we need & what you get

We are committed to paying each artist that works on this show. And we're equally committed to putting on one of the BEST shows you'll ever see. In order to achieve these two goals, here's how our funding needs break down:

  • The play's budget is $9,185. That includes space rental; paying six designers (theatrical and marketing), a stage manager, two board operators, two stage hands, a box office manager; set, props and costumes; marketing (posters, programs and a newspaper ad); and our promo video. (The actors and show creators are deferring payment.)
  • We expect (fingers crossed) to make $4000 in ticket sales.
  • That means we need to raise at least $5,185 to cover our costs.

In exchange for this, you get to see a show that you won't soon forget, know that you are an integral part of supporting this one-of-a-kind experience that will bring people closer together, and maybe even get a poster and/or a Treefort Pass.

Why help?

Instead of us telling you why, we'll let our friends and community tell you why:

“...An archeological experience of the soul...Or rather, the soul of an Eighties hesher grappling with life, the loss of a girlfriend, and the wisdom buried in a video game." — Sawing Wood

“...An exploration of memory and perception...teeming with nods to old-school Boise. Ingenious, funny and arrestingly poignant...wrapped in comedy, adventure and innumerable references to The Legend of Zelda and Pink Floyd.” — Boise Weekly

"You guys, if you're in Boise for Treefort GO SEE THIS PLAY! It is brilliant, hysterical, bizarre, and like nothing you've ever seen. I can't remember having laughed so hard. It manages to be funny and deeply moving at the same time. It's full of surprises and insights that can only be understood when you experience it. The Empty Boat Theatre Company has changed my understanding of theater by showing me just how fun and mind-altering seeing a play can be." — Anna Ura, visual artist

"Boise! You DO NOT want to miss this show!" – Nicole Pierce

"Easily the best event of Treefort 2017. GO SEE THIS." – Ellen Campbell

"This play was amazing and brings to life the greatest myth in prog rock. If you're in Boise, take two hours out of your Treefort to have your mind totally warped." – Josh Gross

story:
Short Summary

Since 2014, JOYEMOVEMENT  has  performed in festivals such as Emergence in Durham, La Femme in Chicago, IL,  Women's Showcase in Charlotte, Greensboro Fringe and at colleges and universities such as Greensboro College, Guilford College, University of North Carolina at Greensboro and at Duke University as a part of the CADD Conference in 2016. The company is a 2016 recipient of the Regional Arts Grant which supported Uplift Girls, a community engagement project. JOYEMOVEMENT is based in Greensboro, North Carolina.

  • For Love of Country... was selected to premiere Jan 26-28th, as part of the 15th Annual Greensboro Fringe Festival  
  • The company has funded itself by grants and through the generous gifts of individual donors and families, which has allowed us to touch many lives in a just two years. 
  • In order to bring this evening-length piece to the stage we will need support for costumes, original music composition, set design or digital media, artist fees, as well as marketing support to fill the new Van Dyke Performance Space. 
  • Although we will be presented by the Greensboro Fringe Festival we will still need to produce our own work. 
  • In a time when division is so prevalent we hope to inspire audience members and participants to reexamine embedded societal ideas. By rearranging context, our hope is to incite reconsideration, and propose alternative understandings. 

What We Need & What You Get

Cost Breakdown:

Costumes: $300

Props:$100

Artist Stipends: $1000

Set Design: $300

Online Marketing and Promotion: $100

Music Composition: $200

 

Rewards: 

Please check out our special thank you gift options on our perks page! 

The Impact

  • Although we started working on the concept of this piece in Spring of 2016 it has become more evident that the differences that make up our country need to be better understood. We know that through performance we are able to open up lines of communication that were once closed, encourage people to see things in new ways and open up a different dialogue.
  • We have done much with very little since 2014 and we know we can have an even greater impact with your support.
  • Dance depends on people like you and your generous support. 

Risks & Challenges

The Van Dyke Performance space is a brand new state of the art dance theatre that can seat  200 patrons. It will be challenging to fill the house for our Greensboro Fringe Run. But we know our work is not just for the art community and often touches people from all walks of life.

After filling The Crown Space at the Carolina Theatre in March 2016 we are up for the challenge of filling this space.  We are so excited to reach audience members from many backgrounds and all ages. We plan to engage with elementary, middle and high school classrooms, colleges and universities and other community members that may have never seen a dance performance but doing mini engagement projects leading up to the premiere. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • If you are able to make an in-kind donation of materials or a barter of your artistic skills please let us know, that would go a long way to helping us reach our goal!
  • Please share this with all the folks in your network far and wide. Every little bit helps!

story:
This page has been moved to:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-rise-and-fall-of-dracula-at-hollywood-fringe-dance--2/x/16316686#/

Short Summary

We are Melissa Ortiz, Cassandra Ambe and David Kayser, founders of Cadame Co. - a team of artists who strive to produce artwork in multiple mediums, including immersive theater performance, music, film, and handcrafted visual art. We are presenting our work, The Rise and Fall of Dracula at the Hollywood Fringe Festival 2017. 

It is an original script that fuses contemporary dance, reimagined myths, and original music to tell a story of Power, Belief, and Companionship.

What We Need & What You Get

We Need:

  • Fringe Registration Fees
  • Venue Fees
  • Marketing
  • Costumes
  • Specialty Lighting/Props
  • And blood - because it is a vampire story, after all.

What You Get:

  • $1 - High five when we see you!
  • $10 - Shout out on Facebook plus previous perks.
  • $25 - Character study poem from Dracula plus previous perks.
  • $50 - Cast signed poster plus previous perks.
  • $100 - Digital download of original music by David Kayser plus previous perks.
  • $250 - Framed sheet music of Dracula’s theme plus previous perks.
  • $500 - Signed copy of script plus previous perks.
  • $1,000 - Dracula’s cape, used in production of the play, plus previous perks.

 

The Impact

We are offering a fresh perspective on a classic story with a focus on ethnic diversity and gender equality. This production focuses on the female perspective; with a female writer, director, choreographers, and a diverse cast. The Rise and Fall of Dracula brings a unique take on an age old tale. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially to the campaign we would welcome anyone to join our street team to promote the show. For more information please contact info@cadamecompany.com

story:
The Lost Teaspoons by Vincent N. D’Onofrio is part of the emerging wave of twenty-first century American plays, written in the classic style that looks back in order to see forward.  The play is the journey of a teen- Doug, navigating his way through the urban mine fields of the 1950s Bronx.

The Lost Teaspoons  is topical and universal in its themes: Youth, Struggle, Broken Homes, First Loves, Forlorn Dreams, PTSD Veterans, Dementia in old age, and of course Hope.

Under the direction of WENDY TONKEN, we've assembled a cast of top-notch actors who will bring this play to life!  OBIE Award winner ROSINA FERNHOFF*, ROBERT FUNARO* (The Sopranos, Vinyl, American Gangster,) CHRISTIAN MUSTO*, PATRICK HERAGHTY, WILFREDO ROLDAN, EMILY DALTON, MARY LAHTI, and LOUIS HERRERA.

* Appearing Courtesy of Actors Equity Assoc. 

Why This Matters 

Theater is the magic carpet of civilization where  humble lives are ennobled and inspiration is on display. With the help of scenery, lights and makeup, the stage becomes a mirror  to see ourselves.  Join the cast of the Lost Teaspoons who peer into that mirror and... 

This is  the dark side of the fabulous 50s- without the rock n roll and ‘fifteen cents a slice pizza’. The Bronx was a tough place to be sixteen and independent with no family to fall back on- Where every day was a struggle to survive. Yet, armed with a dream and ferocious determination, Doug learns to accept the hand he was dealt and sail by the winds of his faith, hope and courage.

This is a story of urban struggle- showing a teen trying to make something of himself even when no one else believes he can! The Lost Teaspoons is a story with a dual message: Never lose hope in yourself  and  believing that, can  change anything. 

That's the message we are asking you to support! 

A Note About the Play

 The Lost Teaspoons  has been a labor of love - three years in development with two  well received readings that included talk backs with the audience.

Now, it's time for you to witness the journey, feel the passion and the excitement as Doug slowly unravels the mysteries of growing up, even as his world is falling down around him.

 Join the Challenge

Freed from the shackles of commercial constraints, small theater companies and independent producers, like us, are the only entities that can produce exciting outside-the-box dramas . We ask you to be part of our community of drama lovers, willing to be patrons of the independent tradition: insuring that productions like ours will continue to grace the stage.

    Obstacles

     Like the characters in our play: We too face obstacles- and our main obstacle is the cost of production....Soooo, please...

     Join the Challenge

    It is well known ‘money can’t buy happiness or love’  but it can produce a play! We are in need of your financial support because this production belongs to the genre of ‘shoestring productions’!  And we’re running out of shoe string!

    Join in our fundraising effort by supporting the The Lost Teaspoon’s campaign! Whether small or large, all donations count and get us closer to our goal of raising $12K.

    How We Will Use Your Gift:

    A stipend for the actors, technicians and stage management.

    Theater rental, rehearsal space, props.

    Transportation,

    Insurance,

    Fees for selling tickets online.​

    It’s Easy to Contribute:

    All donations are made online –Use the easy-to-follow instructions: Select your Perk, click on the tab and follow the instructions.  We thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

    • Gifts

      We have fine gifts in our perks column to show our appreciation for your gift. Help bring this story of hope and courage to the stage. Please make giving a donation a priority.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Sometimes one can't contribute, but you can still help:

    • Ask family, friends to get the word out and make some noise about the The Lost Teaspoons campaign.
    • Share the Indiegogo/Facebook link with a personalized 'Check out this link message.'
    • Come see the play or Gift a pair of tickets.
    • All tickets $20. available on https://thelostteaspoons.brownpapertickets.com/
    • And Goldstar and TDF.

story:
What Are We Doing?!

We are Double Blind Productions a new collaborative group of performers - aerialists, clowns, jugglers, dancers, actors, musicians + a writer and visual artist. We are dedicated to telling complex stories through circus and provoking our audiences to make meaningful choices as part of the work.

We are based in Pittsburgh, Boulder, and New York City.

 

Escape Velocity is our first production and we are thrilled to have a confirmed performance and venue as part of the New Hazlett Theater’s CSA series. Three members of our group - Mandy Hackman, Moriah Ella Mason, and Angela Whalen - grew up in southwestern PA reading tarot and imagining future experimental performances. Now over 10 years later we are joined by an all-star cast of collaborators (Miles Wilder, O’Ryan the O’Mazing, John Hackman, Robert Guido, and the Bombyx Collective) returning to our roots and crafting a multiple-choice narrative circus.


With your support we will have the resources to create and document a polished, professional performance. We will be able to premiere Escape Velocity to the crowds in Pittsburgh and then pursue touring the production around the country.

What We Need From You! 

Your contribution will allow us to:

  • Costume our cast of 10 ($700)
  • Purchase props to fill out our world under the Big Top ($250)
  • Purchase additional rigging for our aerial acts so we can replace older parts and stay safe! ($600)
  • Provide a travel stipend for our Boulder-based artists to travel to Pittsburgh ($1,000)
  • Rent a projector ($400)
  • Purchase additional documentation in photos and videos ($500)
  • Offer stipends to our artists (because paying artists is important! And many of us will have to take some time away from our day jobs to make this show happen) ($5,500)
 

We have been fortunate to receive two small grants, but we still need to raise $5,500 in order to cover the gaps. That’s why we’re turning to our community. If you love the circus, risk-taking art, immersive theater, tarot decks, chance operation, or people dressed up as dancing bears, we are asking you to donate today and help Escape Velocity take flight!

 

What You Get

We are doing something unique in the world of theatre by expanding the role of circus arts on a modern American stage. We hope this is the first of many such productions meshing live music performance with circus arts contained within an original story. 

We also have lots of ways to say thank you to our supporters and super-fans including:

  • Original artwork buttons so you can deck out your backpack or favorite jean jacket
  • A signed Midway poster of your favorite sideshow
  • A copy of the original tarot deck used in the show (The Wayfarer’s Deck) signed by the principles
  • Tickets to a work-in-progress showing and cocktail party in Denver/Boulder or Pittsburgh
  • An in-person or skype Tarot reading
  • An in-person or skype “circus strong” personal training session so you can run away and join us under the Big Top
  • Invitation to the dress rehearsal in Pittsburgh where you will get to see all three endings of the show (this is the only way you are guaranteed to see every ending!)
  • Downloadable vimeo link to the show after its premiere (so you can keep it forever like the precious treasure it is ;)

We’ve chosen a flexible-funding campaign. Even if we don’t raise our goal the show will go on! . . . But we’ll have to compromise on artist stipends, costumes/props, and documentation. We believe that artists deserve to be paid for their work and that audiences deserve the fullest realization of a project’s vision. Please help us make that happen today by donating at whatever level you can.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Short on cash but want to help the us out? Already gave but want to do more? Thank you! You can help us by:

 
  • Sharing our campaign with your networks on instagram and facebook
  • Volunteering for our fundraising parties
  • Donating props and costume materials 
  • Helping with promo videos or photos if you are a professional willing to do some pro bono work :)

Email ella.mg.mason@gmail.com for more info about volunteering and in-kind donations.
