Rent a projector ($400)
Purchase additional documentation in photos and videos ($500)
Offer stipends to our artists (because paying artists is important! And many of us will have to take some time away from our day jobs to make this show happen) ($5,500)
 We have been fortunate to receive two small grants, but we still need to raise $5,500 in order to cover the gaps. That’s why we’re turning to our community. If you love the circus, risk-taking art, immersive theater, tarot decks, chance operation, or people dressed up as dancing bears, we are asking you to donate today and help Escape Velocity take flight!
 
What You Get

We are doing something unique in the world of theatre by expanding the role of circus arts on a modern American stage. We hope this is the first of many such productions meshing live music performance with circus arts contained within an original story. 
We also have lots of ways to say thank you to our supporters and super-fans including:

Original artwork buttons so you can deck out your backpack or favorite jean jacket
A signed Midway poster of your favorite sideshow
A copy of the original tarot deck used in the show (The Wayfarer’s Deck) signed by the principles
Tickets to a work-in-progress showing and cocktail party in Denver/Boulder or Pittsburgh
An in-person or skype Tarot reading
An in-person or skype “circus strong” personal training session so you can run away and join us under the Big Top
Invitation to the dress rehearsal in Pittsburgh where you will get to see all three endings of the show (this is the only way you are guaranteed to see every ending!)
Downloadable vimeo link to the show after its premiere (so you can keep it forever like the precious treasure it is ;)


We’ve chosen a flexible-funding campaign. Even if we don’t raise our goal the show will go on! . . . But we’ll have to compromise on artist stipends, costumes/props, and documentation. We believe that artists deserve to be paid for their work and that audiences deserve the fullest realization of a project’s vision. Please help us make that happen today by donating at whatever level you can.
 
Other Ways You Can Help

Short on cash but want to help the us out? Already gave but want to do more? Thank you! You can help us by: 
Sharing our campaign with your networks on instagram and facebook
Volunteering for our fundraising parties
Donating props and costume materials 
Helping with promo videos or photos if you are a professional willing to do some pro bono work :)

Email ella.mg.mason@gmail.com for more info about volunteering and in-kind donations.

story:
The Push Comedy Theater

In 2014, The Push opened in Norfolk's NEON district.  In that time, we have brought Hampton Roads hundreds of shows, classes and workshops.  The Push has become home to the Norfolk Comedy Festival, The 666 Project: The Horror Anthology Show, Panties in a Twist: The All-Female Comedy Show, Who Dunnit: The Improvised Murder Mystery, Tales from the Campfire, Tell Me More Storytelling and countless other improv, sketch and stand-up comedy shows. 

Why A Crowdfunding Campaign?

To be perfectly honest... we've starting to outgrow our space.  We have simply run out of room at the Push.  Currently, classes are taught Sunday through Thursday and shows on Fridays and Saturdays.  We have some great new shows in the pipeline, but nowhere on the schedule to put them.  We have the demand for more classes and workshops, but nowhere to teach them.

That's where the Push Comedy Theater Training Center comes in.  With the new Training Center, we can now have shows Wednesday through Sunday.  It means we can have classes going on simultaneously at the Push and the Training Center.  It means our groups and house teams will need a place to rehearse.  It means more awesome comedy for Hampton Roads.

The Push Comedy Theater Training Center

The Training Center will be located at 2710 Granby Street in Norfolk, VA.  It will consist of 2 large classrooms that can be used for improv, sketch and stand-up classes, as well as rehearsals.  We will be able to have 2 classes going on at the Training Center while shows or additional classes are going on at the theater.  Our office, which currently resides at the theater, shares the same space as our props and costumes.  We will move the office to the training center, which will give us more space for and the ability to better organize our props and costumes.

What We Need

We've found the perfect spot, we've signed the lease and construction has begun.  But we need help making our training center a home.  We need lobby furniture, chairs for the classrooms, computers for the office, tv for the sketch room, refrigerator for the break room, lighting fixtures, sign, permits and the myriad of little things that quickly add up.

What You Get

We have a lot of fun and exciting gifts for those who donate.  They run the gamut from useful (tickets, classes, t-shirts) to weird (vegan lunch with Ed Carden, a game of Risk with the Pushers) to the downright unnecessary (a poetry reading by Brad McMurran).

We're making sure that no matter how much or how little you give, you'll walk away with something awesome... or at least somewhat memorable.

The Impact

The Push Comedy Theater has quickly become an important part of the City of Norfolk and the Hampton Roads arts community.  With your help, we can ensure that the Push Comedy Theater continues to grow and continues to bring great comedy and comedians to the 757.

I Want To Help But I'm Broke

We understand.  Which is why we have pledge levels as low as $2.  But there are other ways you can help besides giving money.  Spread the word about the Push Comedy Theater Training Center and our Indiegogo campaign.  Share it on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.  Heck, you can even share it on Google +.  Tell your friends and relatives about it.  Make it the subject of conversation on your next Tinder date.  Believe it or not, there are still some people out there who don't even realize the Push Comedy Theater exists.  So please help spread the word.

If I Donate, When Will I Get To See The Training Center

If all goes according to plan... and the contract gods smile favorably upon us, the Push Comedy Theater Training Center will be open for business in January 2018.

story:
The Company

Drastic Action is a contemporary dance company directed by Aviva Geismar. We create thought-provoking dances that stems from a fascination with the nuances and paradoxes of human behavior. Many of our works explore the ambiguity of interpersonal relationships and the effects of disintegrating social systems. We aim for audience members to recognize themselves and others in our dances, which often tread the delicate line where comedy and tragedy meet. Since 1989 the company has performed in numerous venues throughout the US and Germany.


Soaking WET

One of Drastic Action’s long-standing interests is using innovative movement languages to take a close look at psychological predicaments. We bring audiences inside the psyches of characters in our dances through their kinesthetic responses to the action on stage. Drastic Action is currently developing half-program of dances to be presented February 1-3, 2018 at the Soaking WET series at the West End Theater. The intimacy of this 60-seat theater on Manhattan’s Upper West Side makes it a perfect setting for the work we will present.

The Dances

The program will include two new dances stemming from Geismar’s long-standing interest in our hidden internal worlds. “The Bind,” for veteran dancers Jake Szczypek and Darla Stanley, portrays a couple struggling to find an authentic connection. A halting, stuttering physicality of ambivalence emerges as their desire to be understood butts up against their fear of communication. Canadian composer and long-time Drastic Action collaborator, Annabelle Chvostek, has developed a new musical score for the piece.

 

 “Urge,” is a meditation on our desire to control ourselves, others and the world around us. Grapes serve as focal points for this “Anti - Bacchinalian” exploration of desire and repression. Three central dancers are joined by a “post modern chorus” of two, who are part stage managers/part nurses/part guards. Sometimes benevolent and sometimes threatening, they usher the three core dancers from scene to scene, while wheeling IV poles loaded with multi-tiered baskets of grapes. This ambitious dance-theater work, continues Geismar’s long-standing exploration of props as psychological metaphors. Hyunjin Kim, Mengying Lin and J’nae Simmons are joined by chorus performers, Ilana Cohen and Eunseo Park.

 

Collaborators

The creation of these dances involves not only the efforts of 7 outstanding performers and a composer, but also a vocal and performance coach, a costume designer and a sound engineer. Your tax-deductible donation goes directly to pay these artists for the work that they do. .

 

Collaborators

Performers

Ilana Cohen

Hyunjin Kim

Mengying Lin

Eunseo Park

J’nae Simmons

Darla Stanley

Jake Szczypek
 

Original Music

Annabelle Chvostek


Additional Music

Jonah Parzen-Johnson

 

Costume Design

Mandarin Wu


Sound Engineer

David Ashford

 

Vocal and Performance Coaching

Heather Huggins

 

 

Here is what your financial support can do:

$15 pays for one hour of rehearsal space

$40 buys us one IV pole

$80 covers the cost of 2 hours of sound engineering

$200 pays for one costume

$300 buys grapes for all rehearsals and performances 

$1,200 pays for original music for The Bind

No amount is too big or too small.

story:
Summary

This campaign is so important because this message has to reach the masses. There are so many young people making not-so-great life choices.  This story address substance abuse, sexual abuse, depression, emotional baggage, women's issues, relationships, and so much more. It cannot be done alone. This is a huge undertaking that should surely be done in excellence. With your help, The Maya in Me will premiere this Summer in Los Angeles, CA. With much favor, we will carry this message even further. We would like to mount this show by June 1, 2018.

    Tameka Bob is the true definition of a Southern Girl. Born in Savannah, Georgia, and raised in New Orleans, Louisiana, her morals are strong, and foundation solid. Raised in a single-parent home, she watched her mother work long hours and simultaneously pursue a college degree, all in an effort to provide for her children.  After years of experience as a Mental Health Counselor, and a few Film and Television roles, she made the faith filled decision to relocate to Los Angeles, California. From La to L.A.

    Tameka Bob was educated in the New Orleans, Louisiana public school system, receiving a high school diploma from McDonogh #35 Blue Ribbon School.   She attended Northwestern State University, where she earned a Bachelor of Science in Psychology, a Master of Education in Counselor Education, with an emphasis in Community Counseling from Southeastern Louisiana University, and a Doctoral degree from the University of New Orleans in the field of Counselor Education, with an emphasis in College Counseling. Dr. Bob’s dissertation research focused on Sons’ Perceptions of Their Fathers Influence on Their Decision to Pursue Higher Education.

    Tameka’s stage experience ranges from Dreamgirls, to her very own written work, It’s a Man’s Thing, which received rave reviews, and several Los Angeles Theatre productions in between.  Her Film & Television credits span from Lifetime’s Racing for Time, where she undeniably stepped into the role of “Tray,” to HBO’s Treme, as Cheri Lambreaux, to co-starring alongside of Scandal’s Guillermo Diaz in “Futurestates: Ant.”  Tameka stays busy by producing her own projects, including writing, directing and starring in the short drama “False Truth” and the documentary “The Question.” 

    She is the founder of CTY Coaching & Personal Development, a service provided to creatives, dreamers, and entrepreneurs to assist in preparing for purpose; the Creator and Host of Dr. Bob's Real Reality, a talk show where Dr. Bob seeks to assertively educate and encourage women of all ages and nationalities, with intuition and experience as her sole teacher. 

    Tameka is active with her Church community - California Worship Center, where she serves with the California Worship Center Dancers, Music Ministry, and F.I.R.E. Youth Ministry. She stands on Romans 8:28 - And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to His purpose.

    This Production will be directed by Jessica Lynn Johnson. Jessica is a Published playwright, awarded BEST NATIONAL SOLO ARTIST by the Dialogue One Festival, has toured internationally with her solo shows for over a decade and is a proud Board Member and Submission Screening Panelist of the LA Women’s Theatre Festival.  Johnson’s solo work has been seen in the LA Women’s Theatre Festival, the NYC Samuel French Playwright Festival, the Kansas City Fringe Festival, the NYC International Fringe Festival, the Sola Voce Festival, the Monodrama Thespis Festival in Germany, the Black Magic Women’s Theatre Festival in Amsterdam and enjoyed an extended run at NYC’s prestigious Theatre Row on 42nd Street.  Most recently, Johnson was thrilled to direct 5 solo artists in the LA Women’s Theatre Festival, 20 solo shows in Whitefire Theatre’s Solo Fest 2018, and 15 solo shows in the Hollywood Fringe Festival 2017. Over the years, her solo shows haven taken home TOP OF FRINGE, ENCORE PRODUCER AWARDS, & several other accolades!

     

    What We Need & What You Get

    • Funding to pay crew:

    Director $600

    Stage Manager $300

    Musicians - (3 piece professional band); Rehearsals and a minimum of 3 performances $2000

    Dancers (4 professional dancers) - Rehearsals and a minimum of 3 performances $2000

    • Funding for Venue Rental:

    Hollywood theater space $1250

    Rental Insurance $150

    • Funding for Marketing: $450

    Promotional Bookmarks & Posters

    Photo shoot for cover art

    • Registration Fees for Theatre Festival $250

    This is a modest budget, and there is more needed. However, the figures above will get the job done. ✅ 

     

    The Impact

    The Maya in Me seeks to educate and inspire audiences by telling a story of transparency, faith, and resilience, through artistic expression and the wisdom of Dr. Maya Angelou. We plan to begin production in the city of Los Angeles in the Summer of 2018. Based on research, there has not been a one-person stage production of one's personal story where Dr. Angelou shares similar experiences and advice. 

    Set in New Orleans, Louisiana, the story begins with an all too familiar scenario during childhood, walks the audience through her young adult life as 1/2 of a dysfunctional relationship, and progresses to an escape marriage, all while working toward a Doctorate degree. There are many twists and turns during this ride of love and life.  

    The first stage play produced by Dr. Bob, titled "It's a Man's Thing" received rave reviews. Audiences were pleased with the manner in which she was able to connect the life of the Black male with their contribution to society. She has since gone on to produce, direct, and write meaningful works, leaving the audience in awe. 

    Other Ways You Can Help for FREE

    A bit broke, but would still love to support? You can still help by spreading the word! Seriously, every little bit helps. Here’s how:

    1. Share this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter & Instagram and make sure to tag us in it. Also use the hashtag #mayainme
    2. Comment on this campaign. Go to the top of the page, and click the "comments". We'd love to hear what you're thinking. 
    3. Follow us on social to see our progress and shout out videos. "Tameka Bob" on all social media.

    Indiegogo also has share tools!

     

    Current Sponsors 

    Life Wonderfully Designed    https://life-wonderfully-deigned.myshopify.com

    Aundrea T. Harris-Growth Agent.  www.aundreatharris.com

    Colorful Roots     www.colorfulroots.com

    Special thanks to Darryl Sampson of Samp Son’s Productions

story:
Life in show business for the past several decades has afforded me great opportunities to work with everyone from Meryl Streep to Whoopi Goldberg, Maggie Smith, Ethan Hawke and recently, the Coen Brothers movie, The Ballad of Buster Scruggs. Four Broadway shows, twelve movies including Sister Act 1 & 2 and Kingpin, numerous television appearances, four solo shows where I portrayed Harper Lee, Willa Cather, Agatha Christie, and even someone named Prudence Wright Holmes! Perhaps you saw Bexley, OH! at New York Theater Workshop where the Associate Press proclaimed, "You're in the hands of a master storyteller!"

I'm running this campaign to raise funds to take Agatha is Missing! to the world's largest arts festival and marketplace, where it will be performed 25 times, over the course of the month of August. Over 3,500 shows will be playing in Edinburgh and my goal is to interest international producers, presenters, and promoters in my work; and to transfer that work to tours and venues in the UK, US, and beyond. 

Your generous donations, no matter how small or large, will not only help pave the path toward this enormous adventure by laying the foundation for smooth travel, comfy lodging, ace publicity, festival fees, and producer fees (yes, I pay them to produce the show) - but you will also become a part of the future life of Agatha is Missing! and my other shows. By supporting this show, I will be better able to engage larger audiences and discover more professional opportunities to world-renowned platform.

The $7,500 raised here on IndieGogo will go toward the expenses listed above as well as marketing materials, flyering team, technical staff, prop & costume maintenance, local transportation, brollies & wellies, and of course food and drink - gotta love that haggis!

Perks for donors include everything from your moniker on Agatha's fancy website, to performance coaching, a guest appearance by Miss Marbles at your next soiree, and even your own room for two days and two nights in my Edinburgh flat. Me putting out is extra, dear ones. 

If I don't reach my funding goal, I am still bringing the show to Edinburgh!  Every halfpenny, tuppence, and Benjamin will go toward the production - and more importantly, the future of the production. 

Miss Marbles needs to be seen in her homeland, the UK. Based on the crowd-pleasing runs of the show here on the east coast, I strongly believe that Agatha is Missing! will resonate with Agatha Christie fans - and entertain theatre, murder mystery, and comedy-lovers across the pond.

Performing a solo show is always a challenge - it's just me. And navigating this festival alone, both professionally and practically will be a test of my own fortitude and patience. However, I am more ready than ever to take a risk on this venture, and jump in head first with your help.

I know that many of us are watching our pennies these days, but contributions of any amount really do add up. And if your bank is broken but you have hundreds of airline miles to spare, I am happy to take them off your wings. If you have connections in the UK, I'm happy to have them at the show. And if you have a moment to forward this campaign to your artist-friendly, Agatha Christie-loving friends, I'd greatly appreciate it.

On behalf of myself and Miss Marbles, I thank you for your consideration and support and I look forward to sharing the bagpipe sounds, tartan sights, and Scottish whiskey-induced stories with all of my mates, both old and new.

Ta! - Prudence Wright Holmes

Life in show business for the past several decades has afforded me great opportunities to work with everyone from Meryl Streep to Whoopi Goldberg, Maggie Smith, Ethan Hawke and recently, the Coen Brothers movie, The Ballad of Buster Scruggs. Four Broadway shows, twelve movies including Sister Act 1 & 2 and Kingpin, numerous television appearances, four solo shows where I portrayed Harper Lee, Willa Cather, Agatha Christie, and even someone named Prudence Wright Holmes! Perhaps you saw Bexley, OH! at New York Theater Workshop where the Associate Press proclaimed, "You're in the hands of a master storyteller!"
I'm running this campaign to raise funds to take Agatha is Missing! to the world's largest arts festival and marketplace, where it will be performed 25 times, over the course of the month of August. Over 3,500 shows will be playing in Edinburgh and my goal is to interest international producers, presenters, and promoters in my work; and to transfer that work to tours and venues in the UK, US, and beyond. 
Your generous donations, no matter how small or large, will not only help pave the path toward this enormous adventure by laying the foundation for smooth travel, comfy lodging, ace publicity, festival fees, and producer fees (yes, I pay them to produce the show) - but you will also become a part of the future life of Agatha is Missing! and my other shows. By supporting this show, I will be better able to engage larger audiences and discover more professional opportunities to world-renowned platform.

The $7,500 raised here on IndieGogo will go toward the expenses listed above as well as marketing materials, flyering team, technical staff, prop & costume maintenance, local transportation, brollies & wellies, and of course food and drink - gotta love that haggis!
Perks for donors include everything from your moniker on Agatha's fancy website, to performance coaching, a guest appearance by Miss Marbles at your next soiree, and even your own room for two days and two nights in my Edinburgh flat. Me putting out is extra, dear ones. 
If I don't reach my funding goal, I am still bringing the show to Edinburgh!  Every halfpenny, tuppence, and Benjamin will go toward the production - and more importantly, the future of the production. 

Miss Marbles needs to be seen in her homeland, the UK. Based on the crowd-pleasing runs of the show here on the east coast, I strongly believe that Agatha is Missing! will resonate with Agatha Christie fans - and entertain theatre, murder mystery, and comedy-lovers across the pond.
Performing a solo show is always a challenge - it's just me. And navigating this festival alone, both professionally and practically will be a test of my own fortitude and patience. However, I am more ready than ever to take a risk on this venture, and jump in head first with your help.
I know that many of us are watching our pennies these days, but contributions of any amount really do add up. And if your bank is broken but you have hundreds of airline miles to spare, I am happy to take them off your wings. If you have connections in the UK, I'm happy to have them at the show. And if you have a moment to forward this campaign to your artist-friendly, Agatha Christie-loving friends, I'd greatly appreciate it.
On behalf of myself and Miss Marbles, I thank you for your consideration and support and I look forward to sharing the bagpipe sounds, tartan sights, and Scottish whiskey-induced stories with all of my mates, both old and new.
Ta! - Prudence Wright Holmes

story:
33 1/3 – House of Dreams, by Jonathan Rosenberg and Brad Ross, is the story behind the most prolific and successful independent recording studio in history and the visionary who helped create it, Stan Ross. Gold Star Recording Studios served as a “mecca” for the West Coast music scene from 1950 to 1984—a period of tremendous social and political change in our country. Over 120 Billboard Top 40 hits and hundreds of other memorable songs were produced in this small Hollywood studio on the corner of Santa Monica Blvd and Vine Street, including the number one most frequently played song in the history of radio, The Righteous Brothers’ “You’ve Lost That Lovin’ Feelin’.” This unparalleled success was due to the efforts of Stan and his dedicated team of employees including Grammy Award-winning engineer, Larry Levine.

The innovations of Ross’s creative engineering methods and his unabashed charisma put Gold Star on the musical map as the studio where hits were made.. So, it wasn’t surprising when in 1958, a young producer by the name of Phil Spector came to their studio to record his first hit, “To Know Him is to Love Him” and never looked back. Gold Star's one-of-a-kind custom-designed echo chamber, combined with the genius of Spector and the creativity of Ross and Levine, brought to the world the now-famous “Wall of Sound.”

Gold Star’s existence spanned the four most important decades in American pop music, which included the turbulent 60’s, psychedelic 70’s, and into the 80’s when punk rockers paid homage to the studio that helped put “Rock and Roll” on the main stage.

When Stan opened his doors in 1950, Los Angeles was still very much an underdeveloped “cow town” dominated by country music. The major labels like Columbia, RCA, and Decca all had studios in town but they were not considered to be in the same league as their sister studios in New York City. By 1984, L.A. became the number one music recording city in the world and Gold Star was a driving force in this shift.

The presentation of 33 1/3 – House of Dreams, a work of historical fiction, takes the audience on a trip back in time with Stan Ross – business owner, chief engineer, teacher, mentor, and friend to all who made the pilgrimage to pop music’s “House of Dreams.” Over the course of three decades, many obstacles had to be overcome, including:

● The pressures of balancing the needs of the musicians with those of their powerful Union.

● The stresses of designing and updating equipment to keep up with a fast and changing technical landscape.

● The relationship issues between Stan and his wife as Stan attempted to balance a demanding work schedule with the responsibilities of being a husband and father, in the midst of the “Swingin’ 60’s” in Los Angeles.

● A city experiencing the growing pains of racial integration including the 1965 Watts neighborhood riot.

● A movement by the young generation leading to the anti-war "give peace a chance movement," igniting the Sunset Strip riots in LA and the 1967 “Summer of Love.”

● The changes within the recording industry, shifting from large studios to home-based recording studios.

● A music industry that was transitioning from mono to stereo and from analog into the digital and computer age.

These challenges caused the stress and tension that brought on physical and emotional heartbreak and challenged Stan's ability to move forward in guiding Gold Star’s future.

One of the first independent studios in the 50’s that was truly “color blind.” Gold Star often worked with African American artists (Hugh Masekela, Bobby Day, The Robins, Barry White, Charles Wright) and Hispanic artists (Ritchie Valens, Chris Montez, Thee Midniters, The Champs), during periods of outside racial tension when not all studios welcomed artists of color. 

Many notable artists recorded at Gold Star. The list includes Herb Alpert & the TJB, Brian Wilson & The Beach Boys, Duane Eddy, Eddie Cochran, Sonny & Cher, Buffalo Springfield, Iron Butterfly, The Ronettes, The Crystals, Art Garfunkle, The Turtles, The Seeds, Tina Turner, The Runaways, Black Oak Arkansas and The Ramones among many others.

An elite group of studio musicians, including the likes of Leon Russell, Carol Kaye, Hal Blaine, Don Randi and Glen Campbell, otherwise known as “The Wrecking Crew,” made Gold Star their "home away from home." Gold Star Recording Studios ignited many careers from singers to songwriters; musicians to arrangers, and even actors who often believed that they could successfully create the next hit record...if they recorded it at Gold Star.

33 1/3 – House of Dreams, with its themes of creativity, competition, commitment, and camaraderie, is a story that is just as contemporary today, combined with many of the best pop music songs of the past century. It’s a musical featuring the soundtrack of your life that will have you singing along and tapping your feet, and it's a story that will stay with you long past the standing ovation. 

OUR GOAL is to raise these funds to close the financial gap required by the local theatre to bring this show to the stage in Summer 2018. 
Your contribution will help us share the unique story of Gold Star in this special production that is nearly ready to take the stage. Your support will allow us to purchase all of the sets and costumes, secure licensing rights for the remaining songs, and to host our show in a San Diego theatre, all with the ultimate goal of reaching Broadway.

We have interviewed over 40 individuals who worked and recorded at Gold Star. These individuals were there, right alongside Stan and the Gold Star team. They have continually inspired us and it's their stories that we hope to share with you on the stage. We hope to bring them to the opening night of 33 1/3 – House of Dreams so that they can relive their musical past. JOIN OUR TEAM and help bring 33 1/3 – House of Dreams to life!

Dreams really can come true.

With sincere appreciation,

Brad Ross & Jonathan Rosenberg

story:
Greetings & Salutations!!


Hey Funders & Friends!! My name is Darius Colquitt. I'm a Writer, Entertainer & Performance Artist, originally from the South Side of Chicago. Since a very early age, I've had a passion for Storytelling. The ability to weave a tale and take an individual to far off distant lands (and even some we've been familiarized with) is a skill that I've admired for many years and worked hard to garner the ability of performing. After all, it is our words & our stories that shape future generations overtime. Our stories and examples have the ability to teach the lessons that the youth of today need to strengthen their experience; to enable their personal journeys. If we don't contribute, we surely hinder growth and development. That's my personal belief. 

So, over five years ago, I started a labor of love; Writing a production, documenting my youthful journey, growing up with my parents in one of the roughest yet most legendary areas of the nation: The Englewood neighborhood of Chicago, IL. In this non-fictional, one man show, I've left no stone unturned. I cover the broad base of a lot of the expected subject matter... Danger. Drugs. Violence. But, more than that, the writing, and the delivery therein, keeps an inspired, hopeful stance, proving that adversity may alter us, but has no overall say on what we will become & what we can achieve as individuals, persistent to follow our dreams. Below, you'll find some of the promotional language of the piece and a more in-depth description of my background.


About The Production:

(From the Press Release)

Chicago IL – Join Award-Winning Chicago Entertainer, Darius “T.Q.” Colquitt, as he reflects on his personal, nostalgic journey, growing up in Chicago's Legendary Englewood neighborhood. A Collaboration of Monologue, Spoken Word Poetry, and Multimedia featuring Original & Covered Music, it's journey you don't want to miss.

“We live in many worlds on a day to day basis... and our worlds vary depending on the scope through which we see and live our lives... created from the underlying fabric of the worlds we were delivered into and brought up in... This is the story of the start my world, my scope, some of my view on some of the things that have shaped me into the individual that I am today. Now, I was always taught that the truth will set you free so, as I hold you hostage for the next hour or so, you’ll hear all my truth... Whether you like it or not!”



About The Artist:

(BIOGRAPHY & BUSINESS PORTALS)

DARIUS “T.Q.” COLQUITT is an Award-Winning Professional Entertainer, Writer & Director from Chicago's South Side. Starting out as a child actor, "T.Q." appeared in several SUBWAY Restaurant Ads & an ABC Television Movie entitled "There Are No Children Here", all before the age of ten. Now, at age 28, he shows no signs of slowing down, having premiered in 70+ productions with numerous theatrical companies & entertainment entities throughout the Midwest, including Cornerstone Productions, ETA Creative Arts Foundation, Black Ensemble Theatre, Chocolate Chips Theatre Company, Theatre At The Center, Big Noise Theatre Company, HoperaWorld, Fine Print Theatre Co., Half/Bloc Entertainment, PUSH Films, Orion's Belt Films,  New Faces Global, Actors Theatre & Jewish Theatre Grand Rapids. "T.Q." has had the great honor of sharing spaces with some amazingly talented celebrities and personalities including Oprah Winfrey, Maya Angelou, Keith David, Dr. Phil McGraw, Bob Love of The Chicago Bulls, and Country Icons, The Judds. In addition to sitting on the board of several Midwest Arts Organizations, "T.Q." tours his original solo works under his self-titled entity "Darius "T.Q." Colquitt & Company" and serves as the lead vocalist of the Chicago-based band, "Wilson Wilson".

Facebook.com/DTQCCompany
Instagram: @DariusColquitt

Twitter Handle: Brn2DrmBig


About The Campaign:

Now, as for the campaign itself: I've had the opportunity to workshop this hour-long, full length piece in front of fairly large audience, as well as deliver a few shorter pieces from the production to smaller groups. All have been met with rousing vocal support and an overwhelming craving for more. Not just that. I've received the same response the world over: 

"I have/know someone who needs to see/hear/read that."

It's one thing to give compliment and acknowledge a person's artistic integrity or contribution... But, when you hear those words... when you've been told that your work NEEDS to be shared... you know that it's time to work HARDER. I always been taught "You have not because you ask not". Another way of putting it: "Closed Mouths Don't Get Fed." So, I open my mouth and ask you, the Reader, to become the Contributor and assist me in the furthering of my goal for this campaign: to raise a minimum of $5,000. It's with your assistance that I hope to prepare this production for an official Chicago Mounting, as well as a flexible touring piece, giving me the ability to share the message of the production in a continual manner. The Rough Breakdown of what these funds will achieve can be found below. But first, I want to introduce you to an idea that keeps me pursuing... " Live in 3D: Desire, Drive & Destiny"

As an Entertainer, this is one of my mantras.:

DESIRE Inspires You... DRIVE Propels You... DESTINY Embraces You.
It's the combination of these three factors that led me to the overall initiation of this campaign. I have ONLY one Desire... and that's to continue to be an inspiration through the work that I have the good fortune of creating & contributing my time to... And this production encompasses alot of that. The Destiny I see for this piece is to be able to openly tour it in large and small venues for the audiences that need to see it:  I want this piece to be seen in communities where the idea of being successful is clouded with the idea that "making it" in itself is nothing more than a dream deferred. That's where My Drive kicks into high gear... I want to be able to tell that young child whose been convinced that they are not talented... have no gifts... don't fit in.... and don't reflect the norm... that they, in fact, have talents, have gifts, are an individual and have more inside of them than they could ever imagine. I want to teach youth and young adults to tap into their inner voice and start following whatever dreams they are hot-wired for. I want people to learn to captain their own ships and to remind them, especially folks within the overpopulated, urban areas, that they have more worth than they give themselves credit for and deserve to be the successes they see when they look in the mirror, daydream of better and fall asleep at night. I believe this production has the ability to give that kind of hope back to the people... All creeds, colors, religions and backgrounds.

What We Need & What You Get

Here are the specifics of where your money goes.

All Production Costs for the First Full Length Mounting of "Til The World Blow Up: A South Side Love Story" featuring all technical elements. Production Costs Include, but are not limited to:

  • Venue Rental for a minimum of Three Performances: $1250-$1500
  • Furnishing/Maintenance of Stage Properties (Props): $250
  • Furnishing/Maintenance of Proper Costuming: $500
  • Collapsible/Movable Set Design & Construction: $500-$1000
  • Multimedia Tools (Projectors, Add'l Tech  Equipment): $2500
  • Videographer for Documetation of Performance, used for Future Promotional Material

This is a rough breakdown of budgeted funds for not only the first production, but the continual production of this piece in many venues, large and small. Fund breakdowns have been determined through research of multiple venues around the Chicagoland area as well as the rates for rental vs ownership of equipment necessary for the mounting of the full length production. Commonly,  Renting equipment can be very costly, so my eye is set on ownership of all technical properties. My hope is that by alleviating all future rental costs, sans future venues, I'll be allowed more flexibility in the aspect of touring to various locations and mounting the story for multiple audiences. In the event that the minimal $5000 goal isn't reach, I will continue with the mission of mounting the piece within the perimeters of resources garnered and promotions thereof.

Any and all donations made will be recognized with a production credit in the playbill and on Social Media. Your name will be listed as a donor, based upon the level of your donation! You will also receive special, limited edition gifts for your generous contribution. (Please see the Perks for more information.)


Other Ways You Can Help

I do understand that sometimes, people cannot contribute in a financial sense, but in sharing my vision, you are still a very important factor in this campaign. Many of you may have been present for the first workshop. Your support of the piece is crucially critical to its continuation. So, please, SHARE this campaign with friends and family. POST it in your social media outlets. TALK to people about the production and give feedback to those it may impact, including myself. You can also send people to my facebook business portal, driving folks to show their support of the entity. The more this piece and the home entity (Darius "T.Q." Colquitt & Company) are promoted, the more assistance we have the opportunity of receiving.

The Facebook Link: www.facebook.com/DTQCCompany

The Instagram Link: @DariusColquitt

The YouTube Link: youtube.com/channel/UCgvocTD0xHoptVytzYUXs0Q/feed


YOUR VOICE WILL MAKE THE DIFFERENCE IN THIS CAMPAIGN. PLEASE SHARE THIS WITH EVERYONE AND HELP ME BE THE CHANGE WE ALL WANT TO SEE IN THE LIVES OF OUR PEOPLE.

 I do understand that sometimes, people cannot contribute in a financial sense, but in sharing my vision, you are still a very important factor in this campaign. Many of you may have been present for the first workshop. Your support of the piece is crucially critical to its continuation. So, please, SHARE this campaign with friends and family. POST it in your social media outlets. TALK to people about the production and give feedback to those it may impact, including myself. You can also send people to my facebook business portal, driving folks to show their support of the entity. The more this piece and the home entity (Darius "T.Q." Colquitt & Company) are promoted, the more assistance we have the opportunity of receiving.
The Facebook Link: www.facebook.com/DTQCCompany
The Instagram Link: @DariusColquitt
The YouTube Link: youtube.com/channel/UCgvocTD0xHoptVytzYUXs0Q/feed

YOUR VOICE WILL MAKE THE DIFFERENCE IN THIS CAMPAIGN. PLEASE SHARE THIS WITH EVERYONE AND HELP ME BE THE CHANGE WE ALL WANT TO SEE IN THE LIVES OF OUR PEOPLE.

story:
About Tellin' Man

Tellin’ Man is a play written by Rudy Gray. It takes place on a plantation and portrays a would be slave revolt that is averted because the "tellin’ man" (one of the slaves working on the plantation) informs the master of its impending occurrence before the actual event. The plantation owner has in his employ a particularly cruel and adulterous overseer who attempts to rectify the problem. It is the actions of the overseer that brings to light the racial hatred and bigotry that existed then and we still see remnants of today. Also experiencing financial difficulties, the plantation owner is faced with possibility of selling the plantation. A rescue attempt disguised as a sale of the plantation ends in the death of the overseer. The slaves conspiring to revolt escape and some slaves remain behind. The play encompasses a full spectrum of human emotions from love to hate and really exemplifies the triumph of the human spirit.


Meet The Tellin' Man Team

Rudy Gray - Playwright

Rudy Gray is a Playwright, Author, Screenwriter, Professor, and Historian.  He has won three John Golden Playwriting awards, a Creative Artists Public Service Award for Playwriting, first prize in the New Works of Merit Playwriting Contest, the CAPS Award and a Writers Guild of America Screenwriting Fellowship.  He was also nominated for an AUDELCO Award for excellence in theatre (BEFORE THE
FLOOD at The AMAS Rep).  He is also a member of The New York Teachers of English, The American Federation of Teachers and The Professional Staff Congress, the union for college professors in the CUNY system.  He has taught at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, CCNY, Norwalk CC and Lehman College. In addition, he as published two novels, DND and THANK GOD FOR MR. CHANEY, both Editor’s Choices.

Christen Omantra Callahan - Director

Christen Omantra Callahan is an emerging New York City director and producer.  She started her career working in New York City schools close to two decades ago.  Her eclectic assortment of credits include traditional musicals such as Greese, The Wiz, and Rocky Horror Picture Show. She has also directed new works musicals such as Our Stories Our Voices, Rumple Who, and A Time to Love and Newlywed Hostage Party.  She is also well versed in her direction of new works plays such as A Credit to His Race, Sister Gladys, A Day Outdoors, That L-Word, and Leaving Nic.

Gregory Maker - Producer/Music Director

Gregory Maker has been part of the professional music scene worldwide for well over thirty years. He has received a Masters degree in Music Composition from Brooklyn College, City University of New York. His instrumental mastery includes the bass violin and the electric bass.  Working as a freelance musician and composer, Gregory’s credits include a full spectrum of musical genres including Broadway (A Raisin in the Sun, Evita, and Singing in the Rain), Off-Broadway (The Great McDaddy), Jazz (The Billy Harper Quintet, Lonnie Liston Smith and The Cosmic Echoes), Classical Music (The Symphony of the New World), R&B  and Cabaret. He has worked with diverse artists including Marvin Gaye, Peggy Lee, Jerry Lewis, Chuck Berry, Perry Como, Cab Calloway, Buddy Rich and Hubert Laws just to name a few.


We Need Your Help!

The purpose of this campaign is to raise funds to allow Tellin’ Man live in a larger venue. As a contributor, you will be directly helping to facilitate the necessary dialogue that could start the awareness that America so desperately needs.

With your help, the run of the stage play will last for three weeks with approximately 14 shows. By assisting us in meeting our financial goal, we will be able to employ critical production resources such as but not limited to:

  • Actors
  • Directors
  • Musicians
  • Choreographers
  • Stage crews
  • Managers
  • Lighting design
  •  Advertising and publicity

To enable a run of this production of Tellin’ Man is to seize an opportunity to promote healing through dialogue about this American drawback. Your support embraces change.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Donating of time, resources and talents are welcomed!
    • Please contact us at tellinman@gmail.com to help.

story:
Help Bring Spamalot to Tulsa!

Why We Need Your Help:

Theatre Pops was launched in 1989 and is an original member of SummerStage Tulsa. Our mission is to provide theatre by the community, for the community, while focusing on shows with great stories and strong messages. In June 2014, Theatre Pops earned its first Tulsa Award for Theatre Excellence (TATE) for its production of Seminar by Teresa Rebeck. We recently closed a critically lauded production of August: Osage County at the Tulsa Performing Arts Center.

We're always looking for shows that are different, exciting and new to our community. When we decided to venture into the wide world of musicals, we knew not just any show would do. It had to be funny, smart and something we haven't all seen a million times. In other words, it had to be Spamalot, a musical comedy "lovingly ripped off from" the 1975 film Monty Python and the Holy Grail. 

With your tax-deductible contribution, you will be helping Theatre Pops bring this hilarious, exciting and irreverent show to life. We believe that Tulsa, and Oklahoma, deserves the best community theatre around, and we swear by Excalibur that with your help, we will give the community we love the theatre it deserves! 

What We Need & What You Get

You may be wondering “Why do you need money and how will my donation be spent?” We need $5,000 to pay for some of the up-front costs. Musical theatre isn’t cheap, folks. And while we have been working diligently to secure the funding for the remainder of the production, your donation will ensure that Spamalot is secured and on its way to a theatre near you (The Tulsa Performing Arts Center)! Every dollar you donate towards our goal of $5,000 will go directly to paying for Spamalot up-front costs. Any funds raised in excess of our goal will be directly applied to other production costs. If we don’t reach our goal, your generous contribution will still go towards making the production that much better and never in the pockets of knaves or folks having coffee on the company dime.

The Impact

We welcome the opportunity to partner with you in this community arts endeavor, realizing that a creative and thriving arts environment will produce citizens who are a transforming influence in their community and their world.  We’ve been building momentum season over season in bringing you innovative and exciting works of theatre. We want to continue to raise the bar and build our community. Your donation will help us do that.

Risks & Challenges

Theatre Pops is dedicated to bringing professional-quality theatre to the Tulsa community. In keeping with this ideal, we're always looking for a challenge! Spamalot will be our very first musical, and we are delighted with our inaugural choice. 

Our biggest challenge is funding. The up-front costs of producing a musical are extensive, from securing rights, to performance and rehearsal space, to securing the best creative minds for our team that Tulsa has to offer. We know that Tulsa has the talent and passion to make this project a success, and with funding secured, not even the Black Knight could stand in our way. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Is your money shrub not producing enough green to donate at this time? We understand! There are plenty of ways that you can still help! 

·  Visit our Facebook page to become an official herald of all things Theatre Pops and Spamalot related! Liking and sharing our daily updates helps us get the word out, and the word is good! 

·  Share our campaign with EVERYONE you know. The more people we can reach with this campaign, the better. Seriously, be that person, and share as often as you can! 

·  If social media isn't really your thing, or you live in the dark ages, we're always looking for not quite dead volunteers! Send us a message on Facebook or contact us at info@theatrepops.org and join us in the wonderful madness of putting on a show!

·  Last, come see our show! It’s at the Williams Theatre at the Performing Arts Center on August 13-23, 2015. Buy tickets at www.myticketoffice.com

story:
Our Story

The Rocky Horror Picture Show has been a Cult Classic for decades, 2015 marking the 40th anniversary of the film’s release in 1975.  All around the nation, and the world even, groups of people come together in a theatrical setting and Shadowcast the film.  What is “shadowcasting” you may ask?  Well, to put it simply, people dress up as the actors in the film and perform the alongside the film, shadowing the actors.  However, the fans of Rocky Horror have made much more of it, creating an Audience Participation aspect to the experience, where folks in the audience are given things to throw and prompted when to throw them. 

We, the Unconventional Conventionists of Greensboro, NC, are a RHPS shadowcast who celebrated our 3rd anniversary in January 2015.  Over the past three years, we had been gathering props and costumes from all over the place, ranging from local thrift shops to custom made costume pieces from both online and in-the-cast seamstresses.  We have been building our audience, working on our performances, building up our presence within the community and making sure that the folks who pay to see us go home feeling good about what they saw.  Almost all of our funding as come out-of-pocket of the performers within the cast, up until around June of 2014 when we acquired merchandise to sell at our shows.  Even still, with the selling of merch and Prop Bags, everything we made went back into the show, either to replenish Prop Bags or buy materials for props or costumes.  Everything we have done has been purely volunteer work on the part of the cast.  The only thing we get is the joy of working together as a cast and performing for people who share a similar passion: Rocky Horror Picture Show. 

Everything had been going great since we started, up until the few weeks before our Anniversary show.  At the end of 2014, we learned that the theater which used to house us, formerly the Carousel Luxury Cinemas, was changing ownership and being renovated.  We were all in a panic because we did not know if our show was going to continue at the theater or what was going to happen with our cast, we just knew that we would not let this slow us down and tear us apart.  Weeks passed until we finally received word from one of the managers of the theater saying we were given the “Okay” to go ahead with our January shows as scheduled.  We were all excited to continue, but nervous, not knowing what to expect.  A few days before the show, we called the theater to check on our props and costumes, which the old management had allowed us to store in the theater.  The new manager assured us that everything was fine.

The night of our Friday night show, we arrived early at the theater, in case there were any issues.  The theater had been going through many noticeable renovations in just the lobby alone, and we knew more were to come.  Upon arrival, we were mortified to find that our props and costumes had been misplaced during the renovations.  The managers searched the theaters, the upstairs areas, storage closets, even the dumpsters outback, to no avail.  That night, we performed our show with the props we had brought with us and the lighting of 3 cell phone flashlights. However, it did not stop us from performing. In fact, it fueled us to prove we are more than just our props and costumes. 

In the following weeks, after meeting with the new theater management, there was nothing that could be done about everything that had been misplaced. 

TL;DR:

All of our Props and Costumes that we used to perform in our Rocky Horror Shadowcast were misplaced and lost during theater renovations and we need help.

And that brings us here. 

What We Need:

After assessing the items which were misplaced and their value, we came up with over $1,600 worth of things which we had compiled over the past 3 years.  We are basically starting from scratch as a cast, except the only difference between now and 3 years ago is you—the Community.

Our goal for this funding campaign is $2000 so that we can try to replace the things which were taken and also build onto that to make us a more “legit” cast.  All money donated to the cause will go towards creating/buying costume pieces, such as our golden Space Suits, as seen in the pictures, or the beautiful, yet short lived, Columbia Sequin Tail Coat.  We will also be using funds to go towards props which went missing, like our amazing “Sonic Transducer” Panel Shower Curtain (also pictured).  Other uses of the money will be to create new props that we had been planning, like a foldable “Tank” prop to be used during the lab scenes, the Grandfather clock from the Time Warp scene, and other props and costumes.  Basically, we will be using this to create a better show for the audience. 

Absolutely none of the funding goes into anyone’s personal pocket.  Everything we get from you guys, even if we don’t reach our goal, will be used to replenish costumes and props once had.

The Impact

The impact of the success of this campaign would mean that we could get our show back to where it was a lot faster with much less financial stress put on the people within the cast.  Without this campaign, our funding relies on the sales of Merchandise and Prop Bags at our shows (and the contribution of dedicated cast members).  On average we make approximately $60 (on a generous night) in sales, which puts at about $120 a month from sales alone.  Donations would help us up those numbers to get us back on our high-heeled feet faster. 

If you have seen one of our shows, then I would you could attest to how much we enjoy the performance aspect and how much the audience enjoys it.  Being able to afford our props and costumes would allow us to focus more of our attention on the performance aspect and cater to the audience each night, giving them a show they paid for.  The more accurate and well-performed the better.  We’ve got the performance aspect down, we just need the screen-accuracy that every Rocky Horror Shadowcast craves.

Risks & Challenges

·  One of the challenges of building our costumes and props back up is that so much of our stuff we once had was thrifted.  Some of it was close to the screen-accurate and others did just enough.  The issue that we are going to run into is trying to find more semi-screen accurate props and costumes.  In the Greensboro area alone, there are many thrift shops which we can look through.  We just have to think about what can be used “as is” and what needs to be worked on.  Luckily, we have a few folks within the cast who are handy with needles and can help us alter things we have bought using the funds. 

·  Another major challenge is deciding what props and costumes are more important and need to be found first.  As a cast, we discuss which costumes/props are necessary to having a good performance and decide which pieces we need to look for or have custom made.  We are also open to feedback from our community members as to what they feel is the most important aspect to making our show run and look better. 

Why should I fund this?

This is a community project that has been in the works since 2012.  We have come a long way since our first show and we have had most of that noticeable progress ripped away from us.  Any funding will help us to gain that back and give our performance back to the community. 

How else can I help?

Advertising is always a thing we need help with, be it for the campaign itself or our cast/show as a whole.  Sharing the campaign link on your Social Media is a great way to help contribute, because even if you can’t, you might know someone who can.  Sharing our Facebook page is also a great way to help because it gets the word out that there is an active cast in Greensboro, NC who performs on a regular, monthly basis. 

Another, more direct, way that you could help is by donating your skills for sewing, building, acting, or anything that you think could help. We are very receptive to people wanting to join our cast and crew.  If you are handy with a hammer and nail, or have the hook up with some fabric or building materials, let us know what you can do and how you want to help.  Everything matt

Facebook page is also a great way to help because it gets the word out that
there is an active cast in Greensboro, NC who performs on a regular, monthly
basis.  
Another, more direct, way that you could help is
by donating your skills for sewing, building, acting, or anything that you
think could help. We are very receptive to people wanting to join our cast and
crew.  If you are handy with a hammer and
nail, or have the hook up with some fabric or building materials, let us know
what you can do and how you want to help. 
Everything matt

story:
When starting the Dubrovnik Tap Festival our primary aim was to provide dancers in this part of Europe with the opportunity to learn from today's best tap masters. Every year we provide full and partial scholarships to about 40 dancers. Anyone who has been to our festival knows that it is a place where providing affordable dance education is a priority. Unfortunately, this year, part of our funding has been cut and without your help we will not be able to give out any scholarships.

We are proud that our festival is not only a place for tap dancers from all over the world to meet but also a place where dancers who ordinarily could not afford it are given the opportunity to learn from the best.

We all know the important role dance plays in bringing together communities, shaping lives and sharing love and peace.

For all these reasons we are reaching out to you to help us make sure that this festival remains one where the emphasis is strongly placed on education and sharing the love that we all have for our art form!

Any donation will help, no amount is too small!

Thank you for helping us in this cause!

story:
'The Festival'

The 17th Annual IFE-ILE Afro-Cuban Dance Festival features two days of dance workshops -- including son, orishas, reggaeton, salsa rueda, rumba (guaguanco, columbia & Yambu), Afro-Modern, Cha-cha-cha, and more! There will be a panel discussion with scholars on relevant cultural issues, after parties presented by Miami Salsa Congress and Salsa Lovers, and a closing night premiere of 'Under Heaven and Earth,' a new performance by renowned choreographer/IFE-ILE Founder Neri Torres.   

'Under Heaven and Earth'

For six short months in 1980, the doors were opened for Cubans seeking to leave their homeland.  Through the Mariel Boatlift, more than 125,000 Cubans, from all walks of life, made the 90-mile journey across the Florida straits. This chaotic exodus shaped the lives of Cubans and Cuban Americans—families were torn apart and reunited, opportunities were lost and found, and a nation’s perception of an entire country was forever changed. 

IFE-ILE is Florida’s premier Afro-Cuban dance organization, working with a mission of preserving, promoting and cultivating Afro-Cuban culture through dance and music, while facilitating cross-cultural understanding through the storytelling art of dance.  For decades, IFE-ILE has presented festivals, workshops, classes, and lectures.  And now IFE-ILE is working to create Under Heaven and Earth, a new performance that delves into the journey of the Marielitos, those who arrived through the Mariel Boatlift, and the impact it made in various communities by exploring how migration impacts cultural patterns and develops fragmented identities. 

Under Heaven and Earth will premier at the 2015 IFE-ILE Afro-Cuban Dance Festival, August 22 - 24 in Miami, FL.

What We Need 

We are asking for your support to create this piece, and all that goes into an artistic project of this magnitude, a reality.  This includes:

  • Choreography
  • Dancers
  • Musicians
  • Set Design
  • Venue
  • and much more!

Your contribution will not only support this unique form of dance and music, but will help tell the story of Marielitos in a new way, showing their struggle, their humanity and their place in the world.

story:
When five college students decide to hit the road for spring break, their trip is perfectly lined from D.C. to L.A. In plain view, there are no bumps in the road, no inclement weather, and no stopping for directions. However, it’s difficult to notice how smooth the road is when each of them has their own windy path to maneuver. Logan sees the trip as an adventure, and hopes to make amends with Zach, who, since high school, has become a completely different person. Zach insists on bringing his girlfriend, Katie, along who is clueless about Zach's past. Logan’s best friend Rose tries to keep everything steady without worrying about her own problems, and Teddy, well, is seemingly just along for the ride. After days of traveling, reminiscing, and arguing, a sudden obstacle in the road forces the friends to gain some perspective. They must keep traveling, and as they move forward their trip becomes a lesson. The group may not know exactly what direction they’re going, but at least the wheels are turning.

WHEELS WILL TURN

After graduating college I found myself driving around in a white passenger van for TheatreIV, a subdivision of Virginia Repertory Theatre that mounts hour long theatrical spectaculars across the United States in everywhere from elementary school cafeteriums to large Renaissance theatres. Being trapped in the cold tin walls of van can be daunting if you don't have supportive and caring cast. Luckily I was able to find Kelsey Fehlner in my passenger seat and a friendship was born. After directing Kelsey Fehlner in Stage B Theatre Company's latest production, Kelsey accepted a new tour offer while I took a job at Richmond Triangle Players.

Time went by and more tours passed before Samuel Tolley and Kelsey came to me with a proposal for a thought provoking and exciting idea for a musical they had been writing. Kelsey and Samuel had been toying around with the idea of writing a new musical for some time, but the wheels began to turn for the writing duo when Kelsey lost her favorite stuffed animal during a trip on tour. During a drowsy, late-night creative session an important question was posed: What if we took the setting of a cold, claustrophobic, cramped van and told the story of high school friends reclaiming a part of their childhood? With this idea a tale of love, a race for time, and an adventure of friendship was born: Wheels Will Turn.

What you will witness opening night is a polished and fully realized musical that is the result of a culmination of countless hours of hard work. But it cannot be done without your help.

WHY DO WE NEED MONEY?

It goes without telling that production means a lot to each member attached to the production. This is a world premiere musical and the audience will be hearing this material for the first time. With hopes of this being the first stop of a fantastic journey we anticipation to take, we would consider this the first workshop production. We want to shape and mold this production to be the very best it can be with the resources and ideas that are given to us. With a heavy mixture of dedication, hard work, passion, and real life events we are all approaching this production with open minds letting the work blossom into the garden it's meant to be.

Mounting a brand new theatrical production is a daunting and seemingly impossible task. The risks are endless every step of the way and most of the time we put our faith in the unknowing. Will the audience walk out at intermission? Will a strong gust of wind in the theatre blow the set over? Will the projector work the way we want it to every performance? Will our microphones pop and buzz throughout the production? The creative team can do everything in our power to answer “NO!” to these questions but there will always be a factor inexpediency. Actors might be forced to drop out, a winter storm might bury the East Coast, someone might get an unforeseeable illness, etc. With each dollar you donate you are closing the gap on that inexpediency and helping us reach a finished and lustrous production. We have the dates and the space and without a doubt the production will occur. Because no matter what, the wheels continue to turn.

Ticket sales rarely are able to fund theatrical productions nowadays based upon the myriad reasons of economical downfall. Due to the spontaneous nature of Stage B Theatre Company's productions in the past we are left with a low budget and big dreams. While in the past, Stage B has made little out of nothing we really do want to give this production all we have. We have big plans for “Wheels Will Turn.” For example, we have plans for making a edited video of the full production, a CD of the original performing cast, and many more exciting things planned so please take the time to donate now! We have many different perks that you will receive for any amount of donation. Even donating just two dollars will give you access to our behind the scenes blog. Feeling generous? For donating a whopping thousand dollars you will receive a sponsorship credit for the production and several extra rewards all laid out on the perks page, so check it out!

DID YOU KNOW?

  • A little under 30 percent of any donation will go to the technical elements of the show?
  • 22 percent of any donation will go towards the performers for the show and 30 percent of your donation will go towards musicians?
  • Just under 20 percent will go towards the promotional materials and miscellaneous purchases throughout the production?

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

We understand. Times are tough and you don't have it in your budget to throw money at us. There are other ways to help! Just simply sharing our campaign or promotional materials on social media or by word of mouth is fantastic. We'll also need plenty of volunteers to hang posters, usher, work our box office, or even working on the production! To volunteer or offer any help with the production shoot us a message or email at stagebtheatrecompany@gmail.com.

STAGE B THEATRE COMPANY

In the fall of 2010, Tommy Callan and Lucian Restivo met with Graduate student Justin Amellio in a small office on the Virginia Commonwealth University campus. At first it was just an Advanced Directing class in hopes to further their education but it soon came to fruition that this class would mean more. Inspired by the words and wisdom of Justin, Lucian and Tommy one day would hope to create their own work as well as showcase the many talented friends. While the two brainstormed, an idea formed. What started as mere coffee chatter soon become constant conversation that led to bigger ideas. With idea after idea flowing, it was hard to keep up. This dynamic duo needed someone to level them out.

After discussing company members and weighing their options, it was concluded that Lisa Hardt was the best fit. With her stage managing expertise and aspirations to be a future Production Manager, she was asked to join the team. With an enthusiastic “yes,” this team was pumped and roaring to go!

The first show came about through the ever-ticking clock of the duo's senior year. With everyone moving away, Lucian strived to work with his classmates as much as possible before parting to separate states. Lucian approached Ashley Keeter about her undying love for Neil LaBute in hopes that he could direct her in reasons to be pretty. It was settled. The first show was set and it was on to creating the rest of the company.

Now in our fourth year, we've been producing central new works as well as regionally premieres centering with Generation Y issues. Stage B Theatre Company was awarded with the 2012 Richmond Theatre Critic Circle award Best Locally-Developed Work with our devised work “Brew: Locally Grown Stories from Richmond's Coffee Community” by Ian Page as well as produced “Peter Pan: The Boy Who Hated Mothers” by Michael Lluberes in Chicago, IL directed by Josh Chenard. To learn more about Stage B Theatre Company's past productions please visit our website at www.stage-b.org.

In Richmond, Virginia university theatre students are often left with a loss of professional experience due to time constraints within their curriculum and a lack of characters for their age range. Stage B has been created to aid these students and other young actors as an extension of university learning and as a stepping stone when they approach the professional world. Lucian and Tommy fully believe it is the right time and place to make a mark on the Richmond and Chicago theatre scene. By creating Stage B Theatre Company, Lucian and Tommy promise to approach shows with minimalism in mind, while still producing quality theatre.

ABOUT THE TEAM

Lucian Restivo (Co-Founding Artistic Director of Stage B Theatre Company/Director) is an actor/director in the Richmond area. He has toured with Missoula Children's Theatre and Theatre IV. Favorite credits include and Soldier, Come Home (Dan Luke) with the Beacon Theatre; The Lyons (Curtis) with 5th Wall Theatre; bare (Lucas) with Richmond Triangle Players; Dog Sees God (Beethoven) at the Firehouse Theatre Project; The Who's Tommy and Psycho Beach Party (Nicky) at TheatreVCU. Directing credits include dark play, or stories for boys with SALT; reasons to be pretty, Edith Can Shoot..., all girls , and Chatroom with Stage B Theatre Company. Assistant directing credits include The Beebo Brinker Chonicles (dir. Noreen Barnes), Dirty Little Showtunes, and bare (dir. Justin Amellio; winner 2013 RTCC Best Musical) with RTP. He has interned at the Studio Theatre and Ford's Theatre in DC. He is currently the Production Manager at Richmond Triangle Players. VCU '11.

Kelsey Fehlner (Book/Rose) is a graduate from Christopher Newport University with a major in Musical Theatre and a minor in dance. Past productions include Footloose as "Rusty" at Live Arts Theatre, Robin Hood as "Lady Marian" at Four County Player, Steel Pier as "Precious" at CNU and Chatroom with Stage B as "Emily". She is currently working her second year for Theatre IV and is touring Hugs and Kisses. Recent Theatre IV productions Include Stuart Little as "Stuart" and Snow White as "Snow White".

Samuel Aaron Tolley (Music and Lyrics/Music Director/Logan) is a New Hampshire native who has been living in Richmond for the past two years. He is currently an actor for Virginia Repertory's touring children's theatre with the musical, 'Hugs and Kisses.' His original children's theatre works have been seen all over NH as well as in Ashland VA at the Whistle Stop Theatre. He is very excited to present he and Kelsey Fehlner's first full length original musical with Stage B productions. He would like to thank Bruce Miller for providing the stage, His father for recording the accompaniment, Louise Keeton for bringing him to VA in the first place, and all the amazing friends he has made in Richmond for making these past two years unforgettable. In August, Samuel will be moving to South Korea to teach high school music at an international school just outside of Seoul.
