story:
What is this all about?

Welcome to our IndieGogo Campaign for "A Young Lady from Rwanda - A Play" (https://www.facebook.com/YoungLadyFromRwanda)!

We have two actors and one director who are working very hard right now to memorize the script, and produce this wonderful play by Sonjia Linden. We find this work so powerful, so moving, and with current events where issues of social inequality and discrimination against race and gender crop up daily. We knew we had to produce this show of healing.

Hence our tagline: "Presenting a theatrical play to help heal the wounds of all genocide."

This is not something that has just happened in Rwanda, or Bosnia, or Cambodia, or during the Holocaust. This is happening now. Out in the world, and where we live. We wanted to do something to make this more visible and we wanted to do something to help in the best way we know we can - through art.

We know that WE KNOW a lot of people in the New River Valley and Virginia who would want to see this show and help bring these issues to light and engage in conversations to heal our communities. We think our campaign, and this show, can do just that.


What do you want?

We need $6000 to initially produce this show. This money will help us:

  • Purchase the rights for an initial 5 productions from Dramatic Publishing
  • Pay our cinematographer, who made our great IndieGogo campaign video!
  • Pay our director for her time in bringing these characters and their stories to life
  • Pay our actors who have donated their own time and money to work on, not just learning lines, but investing in the technical elements in the show
  • Tour the show - The New River Valley is a big place, with many venues ranging from 15 minutes to an hour away. We will need to be able to cover any gas and venue costs to bring this show to our community
  • Printing costs for our programs, promotional and educational materials
  • Funding sister show, a reader's theatre piece entitled "Upstanders". We believe that reader's theatre is the key in attaining education and empathy with our audiences for this production and we would love to be able to offer this for free to anyone who will see our show.


What will I get?

We have some great educational and promotional materials that we have developed along with this show, and we know, not everyone will do theatre for social justice, but there are a lot of folks who are interested in peace, social justice and global issues, let our work be your gain:

  • Every little bit helps, and we are grateful for every dollar, so for smaller donations, you will get things like immortal internet fame for backing our show! (Along with more tangible options like buttons and postcards featuring our logo.)
  • As donation sizes increase, so do the rewards, we can offer posters and t-shirts, or a whole collection of promotional materials for you to own!
  • Another donation option is that we will help you produce "Upstanders" for your group! If you make a small donation, we can give you our work on the reader's theatre electronically, so you can do it at your own school, church, or other advocacy organization. Save time and effort, and let us help you spread change!
  • Finally, you can bring a show to you, anywhere within 2-3 hours of driving time! For just $500 that will cover our production costs and you've allowed us to have a wider audience. We see this as the best win-win ever!


What will this do?

In the New River Valley, there is a strange dichotomy to live theatre. It is always well attended and beloved, but never makes a huge profit to be fiscally viable by larger organizations. What this means is, a show with two actors don't amount much to a hill of beans in this crazy, mixed-up world.

But there are so many shows out there that are not children's shows, or murder mysteries, or comedies, or musicals, that can influence and change audiences. Shows that can open up dialogue in communities to make them better. Serious shows with small casts that audiences will want to see they just have to start somewhere.

We want this to start here and now. With your support, you are voting that we need this type of work and art in our community. You are saying you need us. We know we need you, but if you have always wanted to see or do this type of work, we critically need your support.

We will be able to use "Young Lady From Rwanda" as a launching pad for small, socially conscious theatre in the area, and we can cater to smaller audiences in smaller places. This cannot happen without direct community support. The city cannot do it, the state cannot do it, the schools cannot do it. ONLY. YOU. CAN.

We would love to take your hand in this exciting new partnership and have you run forward with us. Help us grow this small theatre movement in our area and produce a truly great show with some long-term New River Valley artists. Like our bumper stickers say "KEEP IT LOCAL!" - not just with our farm to table approach that feeds our bellies, but our art to audience approach that feeds our souls.

What if we fail?

Our biggest risks and challenges facing this project are quite simply funding it and building an audience. Step one is getting us out there in the social media sphere and out in our community. This is step one.

We know it won't be easy, but many of us have been doing theatre and making art in the New River Valley for many years now. We know what this community is like, because we live and work here, and because of that we know we will never be able to have actor or artist be our only profession. Those are the facts.

But there IS community support. We have experienced that. And we know that if we do not produce theatre and art, it will not exist in this community. We have seen droves of neighbors just like you come out and support us. We are asking you to do that again.

Simply, and boldly, we will not fail, we just see varying degrees of success. We hope that with your support, we will reach our campaign funding goal, or contribute any amount you can, because anything will help.


    What can I do?

    Please consider making a financial contribution in any amount, even if that amount is $1.

    But we realize, as struggling artists ourselves, that people who want to see our show, may be folks like us, with no extra money to spare. So please go to our Facebook page, like it, share it. Spread the word!

    Share this campaign with everyone who loves live theatre with a good message and that aspires to change the world. Even if you don't live in the New River Valley, do not think that there is nothing you can do to help - you can support us by donating and sharing!

    Message us if you want to bring our show to your group, school or church - we will work with you in making sure that whomever wants to see this show - will.


    From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you for supporting theatre in the New River Valley!
story_txt:
What is this all about?
 Welcome to our IndieGogo Campaign for "A Young Lady from Rwanda - A Play" (https://www.facebook.com/YoungLadyFromRwanda)!
We have two actors and one director who are working very hard right now to memorize the script, and produce this wonderful play by Sonjia Linden. We find this work so powerful, so moving, and with current events where issues of social inequality and discrimination against race and gender crop up daily. We knew we had to produce this show of healing. 
Hence our tagline: "Presenting a theatrical play to help heal the wounds of all genocide."
This is not something that has just happened in Rwanda, or Bosnia, or Cambodia, or during the Holocaust. This is happening now. Out in the world, and where we live. We wanted to do something to make this more visible and we wanted to do something to help in the best way we know we can - through art.
We know that WE KNOW a lot of people in the New River Valley and Virginia who would want to see this show and help bring these issues to light and engage in conversations to heal our communities. We think our campaign, and this show, can do just that.

  What do you want?
We need $6000 to initially produce this show. This money will help us:

Purchase the rights for an initial 5 productions from Dramatic Publishing
Pay our cinematographer, who made our great IndieGogo campaign video!
Pay our director for her time in bringing these characters and their stories to life
Pay our actors who have donated their own time and money to work on, not just learning lines, but investing in the technical elements in the show
Tour the show - The New River Valley is a big place, with many venues ranging from 15 minutes to an hour away. We will need to be able to cover any gas and venue costs to bring this show to our community
Printing costs for our programs, promotional and educational materials

Funding sister show, a reader's theatre piece entitled "Upstanders". We believe that reader's theatre is the key in attaining education and empathy with our audiences for this production and we would love to be able to offer this for free to anyone who will see our show.
   

What will I get?



We have some great educational and promotional materials that we have developed along with this show, and we know, not everyone will do theatre for social justice, but there are a lot of folks who are interested in peace, social justice and global issues, let our work be your gain:

Every little bit helps, and we are grateful for every dollar, so for smaller donations, you will get things like immortal internet fame for backing our show! (Along with more tangible options like buttons and postcards featuring our logo.)

As donation sizes increase, so do the rewards, we can offer posters and t-shirts, or a whole collection of promotional materials for you to own!
Another donation option is that we will help you produce "Upstanders" for your group! If you make a small donation, we can give you our work on the reader's theatre electronically, so you can do it at your own school, church, or other advocacy organization. Save time and effort, and let us help you spread change!
Finally, you can bring a show to you, anywhere within 2-3 hours of driving time! For just $500 that will cover our production costs and you've allowed us to have a wider audience. We see this as the best win-win ever!




What will this do?In the New River Valley, there is a strange dichotomy to live theatre. It is always well attended and beloved, but never makes a huge profit to be fiscally viable by larger organizations. What this means is, a show with two actors don't amount much to a hill of beans in this crazy, mixed-up world.But there are so many shows out there that are not children's shows, or murder mysteries, or comedies, or musicals, that can influence and change audiences. Shows that can open up dialogue in communities to make them better. Serious shows with small casts that audiences will want to see they just have to start somewhere.We want this to start here and now. With your support, you are voting that we need this type of work and art in our community. You are saying you need us. We know we need you, but if you have always wanted to see or do this type of work, we critically need your support.We will be able to use "Young Lady From Rwanda" as a launching pad for small, socially conscious theatre in the area, and we can cater to smaller audiences in smaller places. This cannot happen without direct community support. The city cannot do it, the state cannot do it, the schools cannot do it. ONLY. YOU. CAN.We would love to take your hand in this exciting new partnership and have you run forward with us. Help us grow this small theatre movement in our area and produce a truly great show with some long-term New River Valley artists. Like our bumper stickers say "KEEP IT LOCAL!" - not just with our farm to table approach that feeds our bellies, but our art to audience approach that feeds our souls.
  What if we fail?
  Our biggest risks and challenges facing this project are quite simply funding it and building an audience. Step one is getting us out there in the social media sphere and out in our community. This is step one.
We know it won't be easy, but many of us have been doing theatre and making art in the New River Valley for many years now. We know what this community is like, because we live and work here, and because of that we know we will never be able to have actor or artist be our only profession. Those are the facts.
But there IS community support. We have experienced that. And we know that if we do not produce theatre and art, it will not exist in this community. We have seen droves of neighbors just like you come out and support us. We are asking you to do that again.
Simply, and boldly, we will not fail, we just see varying degrees of success. We hope that with your support, we will reach our campaign funding goal, or contribute any amount you can, because anything will help.
    What can I do?
 Please consider making a financial contribution in any amount, even if that amount is $1.
But we realize, as struggling artists ourselves, that people who want to see our show, may be folks like us, with no extra money to spare. So please go to our Facebook page, like it, share it. Spread the word!
Share this campaign with everyone who loves live theatre with a good message and that aspires to change the world. Even if you don't live in the New River Valley, do not think that there is nothing you can do to help - you can support us by donating and sharing!
Message us if you want to bring our show to your group, school or church - we will work with you in making sure that whomever wants to see this show - will.


From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you for supporting theatre in the New River Valley!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Fear No Colours is a young and dedicated theatre company based in Glasgow, Scotland. The focus of our work is firmly based in contemporary plays and physical theatre, as well as radical adaptations of classic writing. This year we are taking on two plays by Sarah Kane, Cleansed and Phaedra's Love, and we need your help to bring these shows to the Edinburgh Fringe festival.


SARAH KANE

Sarah Kane is easily one of the most influental playwrights of recent times. She studied drama at Bristol University, graduating in 1992, and went on to an MA course in playwriting at the University of Birmingham, led by playwright David Edgar. Her life and career was turbulent, and after finishing five plays and a short film, she committed suicide in 1999. Although celebrated across the world, her plays are not often staged in Britain. Fear No Colours identifies with the passionate way her plays approach universal themes such as love, sex, death and pain - both emotional and physical. The company draws on these themes in our aesthetic work, looking at ways to stage catastrophe through movement, technologically mediated performance and stylised representation.


WHY THESE TWO PLAYS

Cleansed and Phaedra’s Love are Kane’s least performed plays in Britain. Both texts challenge their director and performers through ‘impossible’ stage directions, and pushes the limit of theatrical representation to the extreme. Cleansed posed an exciting challenge to the company’s director Julia Midtgard, and after a successful directing exam presentation at the University of Glasgow we decided to challenge ourselves further by taking on Phaedra’s Love. Both plays expose the tragedies of characters who will do anything to stay in love, whatever the cost.

It will be devastatingly hard work and the blood might not always be entirely fake, but we are hoping to be able to offer a truly experiential afternoon in the theatre.

With 2015 marking the 20th anniversary of Kane's debut play Blasted, we feel this is the perfect time to immerse ourselves in the work of this extraordinary playwright.


WHAT ARE THE SHOWS ABOUT?

Cleansed:

In a torture institution of the heart, seven lovers are faced with the impossible: love is indestructible and to stay in love, they must survive anything.

Our main intentions with Cleansed are to explore the catastrophe and violence of love, as well as investigating ways of representing the 'impossible' stage directions in the play. We want to reach into the core of the play and attempt to bring the base conflict and themes of the text to the surface.


What our audience said about Cleansed:

'An engaging and affecting interpretation of the text'

'An extremely thoughtful and committed engagement with the material'

'A powerful, raw and fresh interpretation of Sarah Kane, which poignantly reaches the humanity of her work'


Phaedra's Love:

When queen Phaedra falls madly in love with her stepson Hippolytus, disaster is inevitable. The prince has no interest in anyone's affections, and his apathy soon throws the nation's morals into irreparable turmoil.

Through a bold and passionate approach to the material we attempt to expose the pain of a love strong enough to cause catastrophe to an entire nation. By using movement and video, we are exploring how skin and flesh can be used as a visceral site of performance.


WHY THE FRINGE FESTIVAL?

The Edinburgh Fringe festival is one of the largest annual events of live performance in the world. Every August around 3,000 shows are on offer in the Scottish capital, trying to capture the attention of the theatre industry, as well as offer memorable and powerful experiences to a massive international audience. In here lies amazing opportunities for performance makers and companies, and also the possibility of connecting with and affecting people who enjoy live performance.


WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

The Edinburgh Fringe is a costly affair for most companies and performers, and with few grants available, we rely on the kindness of strangers to help obtain our goal. Money raised will go towards covering venue hire to ensure we have a space to perform our material, fees to the playwright’s estate, as well as material for the productions and a roof over our heads.


Our budget:

Venue £7425

Playwright fees £2500

Accommodation £3900

Production materials £220

PR/marketing £350

Fringe registration fee £800


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you would like to support Fear No Colours in other ways than donating, we would be very grateful for help spreading the word about our company and our campaign. To stay up to date on our work and adventures, you can follow our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/fearnocolours which will introduce you to our lovely team and keep you up to date on all our future endeavours.

 

OUR TEAM

Julia Midtgard - Director

Born in Norway, Julia is in the final year of her MA (hons) Theatre Studies degree at Glasgow University, studying directing with Graham Eatough. Previously she studied acting, improv and physical theatre in 02/03 at Sunnhordland FHS, Norway. In 2014 she directed Heterophobia by Austin Low, and earlier in 2015 she directed an excerpt from David Greig's Brewers Fayre for Crossing The Lines at the Arches, in collaboration with Playwrights' Studio Scotland.

After Cleansed and Phaedra's Love, Julia will focus her efforts on a semi-devised physical performance inspired by George Orwell's Animal Farm. The company aim to have the finished piece ready this autumn.


Ensemble:

Erfan Shojanoori is in his first year at the University of Glasgow studying Theatre Studies and Philosophy. As an actor, he had his first experiences in high school, playing Fagin in Oliver the musical and Benvolio in Romeo and Juliet. His first role as an actor in University was Tinker in Cleansed. In 2014 he wrote and directed his first short film: 3 Cigarettes.


Lourenço de Almeida, born in Portugal, is in the last year of his Theatre Studies & Economics Honours Undergraduate course at the University of Glasgow. Lourenço played the role of young Oscar in the 2008 Spanish movie, Oscar. Una Pasión Surrealista. In 2013, Lourenço gave the voice to 'Antonio' in the Portuguese voice-over of Universal Studio's Despicable Me 2. Lourenço has been accepted into the two-year Tom Todoroff Conservatory and will begin his studies in New York in September 2015. 


Samuel Skoog is a London born, New Zealand raised Theatre and English Literature student at the University of Glasgow. He has participated extensively in Wellington arts and fringe festivals, including several devised works with Pattacake Productions, and Hamlet in The Rehearsal: Playing the Dane with Pan Pan Theatre. He was also a member of Long Cloud Youth Theatre, a training and performing group that worked throughout Wellington theatres. After finishing high school he moved back to the UK, where he took part in workshop courses with RADA and Central schools, and became a board member of STaG (Student Theatre at Glasgow). Having worked in amateur and semi professional productions for many years, he is very excited to continue expanding his horizons with Fear No Colours.


Callum Partridge is born in London, but raised internationally having moved country every four years since he was born. He studies Philosophy, Politics and Theatre at the University of Glasgow. He has performed in various amateur and semi-professional productions, whether as a musician or as an actor; in London, Oxford, Glasgow. Since attending the University of Glasgow, he has attempted to find some theatre work that could potentially diversify his involvement with the art; and with Fear No Colours Theatre Company, his attempts are coming to fruition.


Siofra Ivy Jessica Dromgoole, born in London, is in her first year at the University of Glasgow, studying English literature. Her first role after numerous high school parts was Grace in Cleansed. She is very excited to continue expanding her repertoire, and to be a part of Fear No Colours.


Andrew Sergeant is in his second year of training at New College Lanarkshire, formally Motherwell College, studying Musical Theatre. Previously Andrew spent two years at Langside College studying Acting and Performance under direction of Steve Dollan and David Lee Michael. Currently Andrew is working on Boogie Nights, Shane Richie's disco musical where he has taken the lead role of Roddy O'Neill alongside the role of Robin in Cleansed. Going forward Andrew is looking to continue his studies either in Glasgow or London and taking more time to focus on Musical Theatre before entering the industry as a working professional. Andrew would like to thank Julia and the rest of the cast for welcoming him into the company with open arms.


Hannah Torbitt is in her final year at the University of Glasgow studying Theatre Studies and Comparative Literature. Always interested in theatre, she first wrote, directed and performed in a local pantomime when she was 15. While at University, she has performed in student productions, playing The Nurse in A Streetcar Named Desire and Marianna in a postmodern adaptation of Measure for Measure. She also appeared in It's Not Yous It's Us, a short video clip for the National Theatre of Scotland's Yes, No, Don't Know, 5-minute Theatre Show. After University, Hannah would like to pursue further training in acting.


Aea Varfis-van Warmelo is a trilingual actor, currently based on Glasgow as a first year student of Theatre and Classics. After having moved to the UK in 2012, she became heavily involved with student theatre, performed in Romeo and Juliet, Frankenstein, and Pool (No Water), among others. She is a member of The National Youth Theatre of Britain, having trained on their Epic Stages course and performed in their devised, immersive production: Viral. Other training includes physical theatre with Frantic Assembly and vocal training with the voice coach for the RSC. She remains active in Glasgow and looks forward to working with Fear No Colours.


Anna-Kathrin Lindner, born in Germany, is in her first year at Glasgow University studying Geography. She has worked as an actor, ASM and in AV in productions led by Tom Bailey between 2009 and 2013. Roles she took include Anna Fierling in Mother Courage and Her Children and Emilie in Dangerous Liaisons. Anna-Kathrin is part of English Theatre Leipzig (AD, SM, publicity) and the NSDF 2015 technical team.


Raymond Wilson has been involved in theatre, musicals and short film in and around Glasgow since a young age, particularly in Clydebank where he grew up. He is a regular actor in STaG (Student Theatre at Glasgow), and has performed in several of their productions including Jerusalem (2014) and A Streetcar Named Desire (2013).

story:
Our Story

Charity Clark-Anderson and Angela G. King first met as members of the all-female cast whose rendition of venerated author and playwright Pearl Cleage's A Song for Coretta was voted "Best Play of the Season" by the subscribers to the Detroit Repertory Theatre. From then on, the two would often bring up the possibility of starting a group to help nurture aspiring local playwrights whenever they would run into each other at various theater events. Leah Smith, marketing and development director for the Rep, eventually overheard just such a conversation and piped up, "You can meet here!" From that extraordinary proposition emerged The Detroit Playwrights' Lab ("The Lab").

More than 20 individuals came out to Detroit's oldest professional theater on July 25, 2016, for the first-ever meeting that Clark-Anderson and King held for The Lab. Individuals who included nationally renowned local playwright and retired Wayne State University English professor, Bill Harris. And, by Skype from Los Angeles, author of the award-winning "Detroit Project" trilogy of plays highlighting her hometown, Dominique Morisseau.

Meeting every other Monday since then at either the Rep or office space provided by member Doreen McArthur, The Lab now counts the likes of Jeffry Chastang, author of Dauphin Island, the dramedy produced for the Rep's 2017-18 season to rave reviews, among its ranks. Clark-Anderson received an Audience Favorite nod for the one-act excerpt from her Legacy that was produced during Planet Ant Theatre's 2017 BoxFest Detroit festival. Member Collette Cullen's The Encore was a semifinalist in the 2018 Detroit New Works Festival. Her Dressed to Kill, Dressed to Die monologue is a finalist for the 2018 Women's Theatre Festival in Raleigh, North Carolina. And Emilio Rodriguez' Swimming While Drowning has been selected for the 2018-19 season of Stages Repertory Theatre in Houston.

The Lab is sustained not only in our mission as a forum for playwrights of varying levels to come together and hear their works read and critiqued. We also offer writing exercises, group theater outings and other related undertakings to help cultivate the full creative development of our members' unique individual voices. 

Encouraged by the undeniable success of our first stage showcase in July 2017, The Lab will be joined by some of Metro Detroit's most promising stage directors and aspiring actors to present our upcoming sophomore showcase!

Her Dressed to Kill, Dressed to Die monologue is a finalist for the 2018 Women's Theatre Festival in Raleigh, North Carolina. And Emilio Rodriguez' Swimming While Drowning has been selected for the 2018-19 season of Stages Repertory Theatre in Houston.
The Lab is sustained not only in our mission as a forum for playwrights of varying levels to come together and hear their works read and critiqued. We also offer writing exercises, group theater outings and other related undertakings to help cultivate the full creative development of our members' unique individual voices. 
Encouraged by the undeniable success of our first stage showcase in July 2017, The Lab will be joined by some of Metro Detroit's most promising stage directors and aspiring actors to present our upcoming sophomore showcase!

story:
About Us

Founded in 2017 by a group of dedicated artists, our professional theatre company strives to help increase the ever-growing interest for the arts in Vancouver. By producing gripping, contemporary theatre with a heavy focus on up-and-coming Canadian playwrights, we seek to reignite the community’s passion for live performance.

 

Our Goal

We believe that the theatre should be a place open to everyone and not only the rich and retired. Live performance is so important in our community, especially in the technological world that drives us and we want to give people the chance to see ground-breaking stories acted out on stage in front of them. Our goal is to produce high-quality, professional theatre while making it accessible to our community by keeping our ticket prices at $20.00.

 

Our Artists

The Vagrant Players theatre Society acts as a creative shelter for everyone regardless of race, gender, sexuality, and religious or political views; we welcome all artists who have a desire to bring important, impactful stories to the forefront of our community, and an audience that is eager to make that community a part of the North American theatre conversation.

Our team is led by creative directors Cody Kearsley (Riverdale, Power Rangers) and Megan Peta Hill (Supernatural, X-Files, The Magicians).

 

What We Need

In order to produce professional theatre we need funding for a variety of things, including: sets, theatre rental, artist fees, marketing and more. As a new company that has been around less than 2 years, it can be difficult to get certain grant funding and therefore have had to rely on donations from our community, fundraising and our own back pockets. We are looking to raise $10,000 for us to achieve this goal.

 

2018/19 Season:

KILL ALL POLITICIANS by Thomas Yungerberg   -  **Closed

Stu and Ben are bored, stoned, and spending another night inexpertly dissecting senatorial vote-trading when a parking ticket sends Stu over the edge. As he plots to rid America of political misbehaviour once and for all, Ben begins to wonder if his friend’s vehemence stems from problems closer to home.

FEATURING LORETTA by George F. Walker  -  **Opens August 6th, 2018

Loretta is the kind of girl you would do anything for. Dave and Michael are in love with her. Dave wants to take her shopping. Michael wants to make her a star! A porn star. What is a woman to do in a man’s world?

PRAIRIE LILY by Ryan Bruce  -  **Opens November, 2018

Written by up and coming playwright, Ryan Bruce, this play will explore the life of a small town, Canadian family in the prairies and their journey through family connection, self-medication and the cultural clash of our widely-diverse country.

 

Risks & Challenges

As a new theatre company that has been incorporated for less than two years, it can be difficult to receive government funding. Because we are trying to build the platform for edgy, hard-hitting contemporary plays in Vancouver, the support from our fellow creatives has been incredible. Our first season was completely funded by ourselves and like-minded artists giving us the building blocks of our society. As our company builds, almost to the point of getting support from various arts councils, we find ourselves needing to reach out to our community to ask for support.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have a passion for live performance but are unable to financially contribute, we are always looking for volunteers to help with upcoming productions and events. Please email us at vagrantplayers@gmail.com for more information.

story:
Lora, an incarcerated woman in solitary confinement reflects on the circumstances that have brought her there. Far more complex than “I committed a crime and am guilty”, the story she unravels is a hapless history… one laced with violence, betrayal, heartbreak, and regret.

 

About the Project:

Caged is a brand new play that, unfortunately, is based on a true story. Not (just) events from my own life, but experiences from the lives of tens of thousands of women around the world.

The narrative deals with some heavy topics: murder, domestic violence, judicial abuse of power, even animal neglect. It doesn't shy away from these things or make light of them, nor does it excuse them or soften them. Instead, it provides a candid, first-person point of view as to how easily anyone's life can veer wildly off-course. People like you and me. Like our sisters, girlfriends, best friends, daughters, and mothers. 

Despite her circumstances, the character of Lora is written not as a sad victim, but as an intelligent woman. A smart observationalist with an off-the-cuff and blunt point of view, who tells it how it is, and who owns her past experiences. The language and story of Caged is all very real, very accessible. And, as previously mentioned, the story is 100% grounded in real-life events.

What We Need & What You Get:

Unfortunately, producing a Fringe show comes with no guarantees. Audiences could love my show and it could sell out, or I could find myself playing to a house of less than ten audience members.

What I'm asking for is help covering a portion of my out of pocket costs. This doesn't cover any of my time in researching, writing or rehearsing the show, only what I am actively spending to bring this show to PEI.

  • $500 - plane fare to PEI
  • $250 - Fringe entry fee
  • $250 - cost of hiring a stage manager
  • $50 - wardrobe
  • $100 - printing costs for flyers and posters
  • $100 - estimated Indiegogo fees

Any money donated here will go toward helping me break even on this production. Should I generate a profit with this show, that money will go toward helping me bring Caged to other venues in other cities, to other folks who need to see the show.

The Impact:

Put simply, theatre is a tool that allows us to create a comfortable and safe space to explore situations where people may feel uncomfortable and unsafe.

My hope with this show is to make a much larger audience aware of the small, private crimes that happen every day between people, the ones that aren't publicized in the news. To make people think about others' lived experience when it seems so drastically different from their own... even if it's not. To help people recognize and unlearn harmful patterns in their own lives. And beyond that, to start a serious discussion about judicial reform, which we so desperately need.

My last Indiegogo campaign resulted in an award-winning 26 minute short film that has now screened at close to ten festivals. I've already proven that I can do a lot with a little... and now I'd like to do something amazing and fantastic with a reasonable amount. Launching this campaign is step one of that plan.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Love the campaign but have no $$? No worries!

  • I love any and all help promoting the show. Whether that's social media shares of this campaign, inviting your relatives in or near PEI to come see the show, or perhaps even connecting me with a media source you know for a blog post or interview.
  • Know a place where I should perform this show? Please message me directly, or hit me up on social media. I'm happy to talk details.
  • Anything else you want to offer - I am grateful!
  • I also have a Patreon where you can follow my work.

story:
#SpecimenTO

JUNE 20-24
The Commons Space, Toronto
587a College St. 

We need your help to put on an amazing performance. 

70 years ago a psychologist became famous for his day-in-the-life study of a seven year-old boy. We're a small group of independent artists who've taken that book and created an experiment in adaptation. Specimen is an unsettling look at maleness and how knowledge gets made: it's weird, funny and not like anything you've ever seen on stage. 

It's also expensive. We're producing a week-long run of performances in June 2018. It may not seem like much, but even a small theatre production takes a big team. We have an incredibly talented group of professionals working on Specimen because they believe it's important. We want to make sure they get paid for their time. 

Having trouble seeing our campaign video? Click here. 

What We Need

$3000 helps pay for our performance space and the technicians who make our beautiful set design work. 

Even just a small contribution helps! And you get in on some of our sweet perks.

Why support Specimen

Folks throw around the word "fact" an awful lot these days. But does anyone actually know what goes into making one? Wait, you can *make* fact?

Specimen is a play is about bias. It would sure be nice if a certain politician could check his own biases at the door. It would sure be nice if we all could. 

By contributing to our campaign, you're helping us bring those questions to our audience while supporting this amazing team of artists, including

Griffin McInnes | Director and Producer

Khadijah Roberts-Abdullah | Producer

Rob Feetham | Performer

Jennah Foster-Catlack | Performer

Aidan Morishita-Miki | Stage Manager

Daniel Bennett | Sound Design

Hans Krause | Projection Design

Will Innes | Graphic Design

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's OK! Help us get the word out. Share on social media and talk to your friends about us! 

FACEBOOK

LANDING PAGE

TICKETS

story:
The Danger:

A Homage to Strange Fruit

The Story

"The idea for The Danger, lived in my head for more than a year, but I didn’t quite know what it was. I knew the title. I knew I wanted to take a deep, soul level look at the Black American experience. I instinctively knew this was not a play that I wanted to approach how I’d approached others. I wanted the words to come from an excavation, an emotional exploration. I wanted them to erupt from the deep sense of outrage and sorrow I was feeling about Eric Garner, Mike Brown, and then there was Lennon Lacy. Lennon was a Black boy of 17 found hung by a belt under suspicious circumstances in Bladenboro NC, just a three hour straight drive from where I’d raised my own Black son. This modern day lynching, the lynchings of the past, and the trend of devaluing and desecrating of Black bodies instilled in me the desire to create something an audience could feel, for it is at the level of emotion that change is generated. Form, I decided, would have to be the way in.

In self-producing The Danger, I’m committing a disruptive revolutionary act. I’m daring to be a Black woman willing to put in the work to tell Black stories sans the support of a major theatrical institution. It is an act that I hope will serve as inspiration to other theatre makers of Color, as I have been inspired by fiercely independent theatre makers before me. We cannot afford to wait for the larger theatrical construct to “get” and thereby choose to support what we do. If our stories are to be told on our terms, we must be willing and brave enough to venture forth with or without that support." -- Stacey Rose, playwright

About The Danger

The Danger, a theatrical symphony in four movements, is the harrowing tale of the legacy of White supremest patriarchy and its effect on a set of disparate souls all lost in the same dilapidated rail road waiting room desperately trying to find their way. "He" and "She" an interracial couple, has stumbled upon this dystopian universe having escaped the dangers of home, only to find themselves part of a larger more sinister danger governed by Gyp, part mad woman/part sage.  Gyp the self proclaimed Goddess of this world, wields her control over the flesh of The Three Mammies: Chastity, Hope, and Cherish who seek to escape from an impending slaughter on their plantation, and The Entertainers: Try and Vic whose sick sense of brotherhood keep them locked in a no win hustle. He and She, spellbound and enlightened by the power of Gyp's magic, succumb to their truth and ultimately accept their part in the cyclical madness of The Station.

The Danger will have a six performance showcase run October 4 - 6 & 11 - 13 at JACK in Brooklyn, NY.

The Team

Written  by Stacey Rose
Directed by  Tiffany Nichole Greene
Music Supervision by  Elijah Caldwell​
Assistant Director Heidi Breeden
Producer: Stacey Rose
Graphics: Danielle Brockington, Marcus Kiser 
Videography: Danielle Brockington
 

What your money will help us do

Without your support this project will not be possible. Period. Here are the things we'll be using the funds we raise for:

Actor Stipends:  

9 Cast members - $500/ea

Total = $4500

Creative Team Stipends: 

Director - $500

Music Supervisor - $500

Costume Designer - $500

Stage Manager - $500

Photographer: $200

Total: = $2200

​Creative Materials

Set - $100

Costumes - $300

Total = $400

Rental & Insurance​

Rehearsal space - $500

Insurance - $300

Total = $800

​Marketing

Online Ads - $200

Total = $200

​Travel/Housing

Travel - $750

Housing - $2500

Total = $3250

Misc. Expenses

SM supplies - $50

Crowd Funding Fees - $550 ( or 4% of total raised)

Petty Cash - $200

Total = $800

Project Total  

Subtotal - $12,150

Contingency (10%) - $1250

Project Total = $13, 365

How else can you help

We understand that not everyone is position to donate. Here are some other ways you can show your support.

SHARE: Share this campaign on social media. If you know someone on the creative team, talk about that! Let people know why it is important to support this project.

HOUSING: If you're based in NYC and can open up your doors for our artistic team or know someone(s) who can, let us know!

SPACE: If you're in NYC and have space where 13 + people can move, rehearse and be fairly loud that would be available 9/17 - 9/30, we could use it!

TRAVEL: If you or someone you know has frequent flier miles burning a hole in your pocket, we'll take them.

VOLUNTEER: We sure could use your help! Are you in NYC and have availability 9/17 - 10/3? Sign up to volunteer here.

IDEAS: If you have additional ways in which you feel you can be of help shoot us an email and let us know!

story:
I'm Jenifer Toksvig, and I'm directing a workshop of a new piece of community musical theatre written by my friend Niall Ashdown.

The story is told around the first world war poems of A.E. Housman, set to music very beautifully by Niall.

We've received a Grants For The Arts grant from Arts Council England for this development process, which is brilliant. It will pay for us to do a two-week R&D workshop on the show.

During that workshop, I'd like to include two kinds of R&D on my own process for making work, and that's what this crowd-funding appeal is all about.

1. Archivist

I'd like to have someone in the room with us whose purpose is to capture the process of the workshop and the final presentations. The Archivist will make process notes and observations on brown paper on a wall, where everyone can see them, and encourage the rest of us to do the same when we want to capture things. The Archivist will also take photos and video of the process, and upload them to social media as we go. The notes, photos, videos, and anything else they capture, will then form part of our evaluation of the workshop, both for ACE and for us as a company.

Having an Archivist present means we can continuously embrace the objective view, not only as part of the making process, but also as part of performing the show. I imagine we will find that their job is part capture and part critic: having someone do this job for two weeks will allow us to explore what the job actually involves, and how best to facilitate it.

2. Responders

I would like to invite a series of creative practitioners into the process for a day each, to spend some time responding to the us and the work we're making, in their own unique medium.

If we achieve our funding goal here, then we'll be able to invite multiple people to join us, and hopefully that will at least be: a painter/illustrator; a poet/writer; a paper/fabric crafter; a fragrance designer; a game maker.

These responses in alternative media will be displayed throughout the process and performances, becoming as much part of the work as any other, and adding an additional way to access the work, for the company and the audience.

Having Responders in the process will reflect back to us that we are all doing exactly that: responding to the work as artists, and also as audience members. Since my goal is ultimately to encourage contact between the audience and the characters, I hope that the artists can act as intermediaries and help to make connections as they work.

IndieGoGo will allow us to keep any monies we raise, so our individual goals go up in £90 / day increments. The more lots of £90 we get, the more days in which we can have an Archivist and a Responder in the room during our two week period. It would be absolutely fantastic if we could have them present all the way through, to really explore what we can achieve.

Any help you can give us, no matter how small, will go towards making more discoveries about 'The Copenhagen Interpretation' method of engaging in the making of work, and involving audiences in the story.

Here's a Tumblr post about all the identities I see being involved in The Copenhagen Interpretation: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/112699354681/copenhagen-identities

Here's one on making invitations to be involved: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/103389171396/inclusivity-invitation

And one on involving the audience in the story: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/96097237076/kyle-asked-me-how-far-can-reality-enter

Here's one on Capture: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/95642991411/archivists-er-capturers

** PERKS **

I wanted to try something new (and a bit risky!) with the perks for this appeal.

My choice of including a crowd-funding process is partly to try using the different levels of donation to indicate levels of audience involvement in the show.

Rather than offering increasingly valuable perks with greater donations, I’m offering increasing involvement with the process: the more you donate to the project, the more you can be involved.

I realise it might seem counter-intuitive to effectively charge someone more for contributing more to the process, but I’m hoping this equates to, say, the difference between watching a potter work, or paying more and doing a pottery workshop yourself.

(You don't have to get involved, though. You can donate any amount as a Supporter. We'll be in touch so you can let us know if you'd like to join us or not.)

Have a look at the perks and let me know what you think!

Many thanks for being involved this much already - it really does help me develop my process for making work, and I’m hugely grateful.
story_txt:
I'm Jenifer Toksvig, and I'm directing a workshop of a new piece of community musical theatre written by my friend Niall Ashdown.


The story is told around the first world war poems of A.E. Housman, set to music very beautifully by Niall.


We've received a Grants For The Arts grant from Arts Council England for this development process, which is brilliant. It will pay for us to do a two-week R&D workshop on the show.


During that workshop, I'd like to include two kinds of R&D on my own process for making work, and that's what this crowd-funding appeal is all about.


1. Archivist


I'd like to have someone in the room with us whose purpose is to capture the process of the workshop and the final presentations. The Archivist will make process notes and observations on brown paper on a wall, where everyone can see them, and encourage the rest of us to do the same when we want to capture things. The Archivist will also take photos and video of the process, and upload them to social media as we go. The notes, photos, videos, and anything else they capture, will then form part of our evaluation of the workshop, both for ACE and for us as a company.


Having an Archivist present means we can continuously embrace the objective view, not only as part of the making process, but also as part of performing the show. I imagine we will find that their job is part capture and part critic: having someone do this job for two weeks will allow us to explore what the job actually involves, and how best to facilitate it.


2. Responders


I would like to invite a series of creative practitioners into the process for a day each, to spend some time responding to the us and the work we're making, in their own unique medium.


If we achieve our funding goal here, then we'll be able to invite multiple people to join us, and hopefully that will at least be: a painter/illustrator; a poet/writer; a paper/fabric crafter; a fragrance designer; a game maker.


These responses in alternative media will be displayed throughout the process and performances, becoming as much part of the work as any other, and adding an additional way to access the work, for the company and the audience.


Having Responders in the process will reflect back to us that we are all doing exactly that: responding to the work as artists, and also as audience members. Since my goal is ultimately to encourage contact between the audience and the characters, I hope that the artists can act as intermediaries and help to make connections as they work.


IndieGoGo will allow us to keep any monies we raise, so our individual goals go up in £90 / day increments. The more lots of £90 we get, the more days in which we can have an Archivist and a Responder in the room during our two week period. It would be absolutely fantastic if we could have them present all the way through, to really explore what we can achieve.


Any help you can give us, no matter how small, will go towards making more discoveries about 'The Copenhagen Interpretation' method of engaging in the making of work, and involving audiences in the story.


Here's a Tumblr post about all the identities I see being involved in The Copenhagen Interpretation: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/112699354681/copenhagen-identities
Here's one on making invitations to be involved: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/103389171396/inclusivity-invitation

And one on involving the audience in the story: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/96097237076/kyle-asked-me-how-far-can-reality-enter


Here's one on Capture: http://jenifertoksvig.tumblr.com/post/95642991411/archivists-er-capturers


** PERKS **


I wanted to try something new (and a bit risky!) with the perks for this appeal.


My choice of including a crowd-funding process is partly to try using the different levels of donation to indicate levels of audience involvement in the show.


Rather than offering increasingly valuable perks with greater donations, I’m offering increasing involvement with the process: the more you donate to the project, the more you can be involved.


I realise it might seem counter-intuitive to effectively charge someone more for contributing more to the process, but I’m hoping this equates to, say, the difference between watching a potter work, or paying more and doing a pottery workshop yourself.(You don't have to get involved, though. You can donate any amount as a Supporter. We'll be in touch so you can let us know if you'd like to join us or not.)

Have a look at the perks and let me know what you think!


Many thanks for being involved this much already - it really does help me develop my process for making work, and I’m hugely grateful.

story:
detour dance is a San Francisco-based contemporary dance company that presents works the stage and screen…

… and we are ready to sink our teeth into 2015. Join us?

=== === === === === === === === === ===

What's going on?

1. Tiny Dance Film Festival

We're presenting the 3rd Annual TDFF, a festival that celebrates short dance films by artist throughout the globe. This year, we're screening 20 experimental, humorous, and poignant films that feature artists from Germany, Israel, Australia, the Bay Area and more.

This festival brings together inspiring filmmakers and artists who are at the forefront of a groundbreaking genre, while celebrating this rich and diverse community - TDFF Audience Member, 2014

Mark your calendars: April 24-25, 2015 @ Ninth Street Independent Film Center in San Francisco.

2. East Coast TOUR!

We have our first ever tour, showing our newest work in New York City! It's an amazing opportunity to be able to take our work on the road, and to collaborate with our East Coast brethren.

Mark your calendars: May 27-31, 2015 @ IRT Theater in Manhattan.

3. Beckon

We’ll be making our new dance theater piece, called "Beckon". It's our foray into the verbal and non-verbal ways we attract people through catcalling and cruising, and how these interactions exhibit power dynamics and privilege.

Mark your calendars: "Beckon" will premiere December 4-13, 2015 @ NOHspace Theater in San Francisco.

=== === === === === === === === === ===

Where will your money go?

Your donation will support ALL of our activities this year, most importantly to compensate our dancers and artistic collaborators, as well as the rental costs for rehearsal space and the theater.

Whether you have $10 or $10,000, your donation will support the quality, ground-breaking art and artists in 2015.

For more information, visit www.detourdance.com

THANK YOU for your generosity.

Love,

Eric & Kat

story:
Short Summary

Hot on the heels of their smash hit touring production of AS YOU LIKE IT, the newly-minted Rogue Ensemble Theater Company is set to tackle Shakespeare's most violent tragedy, TITUS ANDRONICUS. Adapted by Rogue Ensemble Artistic Director Christine Reisig and directed by Joey Nasta, this new socially-distant production reimagines the Bard's bloodiest tale as a macabre, ghostly requiem on the horror of revenge.

Performed at the steps of General Ulysses S. Grant's tomb, TITUS channels a corrupt, crumbling republic haunted by the ghosts of its failed caretakers. As the violent demon of revenge wreaks havoc in Rome, characters slowly forget themselves, changing from face to face until the carnage leaves little to be recognized.

With Your Contribution We Will...

  • Compensate our actors!
  • Cover production expenses
  • Create special effects-blood, guts, etc.
  • Market our show to reach a broader audience
  • Provide protective gear to actors and audience (face masks, hand sanitizer, etc.)

The Impact

Now, more than ever, we believe that arts are essential! Theater in a traditional sense will not return to New York City until late 2021. Our company actively works to create safe, socially distanced theater. 

Our first production of the season, a touring pop up production of As You Like It, was able to engage with the public of New York. For many of our patrons we were the first Shakespeare they'd ever seen. For most it was the first live performance they had seen since March. The response from the community was overwhelmingly positive.

By supporting Titus you are keeping the arts alive in the midst of this pandemic.

Risks & Challenges

We understand that we are living in unprecedented times. We are dedicated to staying up to date with the most recent CDC requirements. To protect our audience and actors the following measures have been put in place: 

  • Actors maintain at least 6 feet distance or wear facial coverings.
  • Performers remain more than 6 feet away from the audience at all times.
  • Audience seating will be arranged to allow proper social distancing. 

Buy tickets now!

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/titus-andronicus-t...

story:
KATY HAGELIN dance project is a contemporary ballet dance company in the Seattle area and we are fundraising for EXPOSURE 2017. Our goal is to raise $13,000 and we could use any support in this campaign -even if it is only a few dollars! We could use even  $2 or $5 donation!

Our mission is to enrich people's lives through the language of dance. We believe in speaking to audiences of all backgrounds and we want people to -not only enjoy the show, but also to understand and comprehend the message and stories. Some modern dance is not easy to grasp, but our company strives to really connect with our audience; we want people to go away excited and with hope for change in their own lives. Our dances are meant to be compelling and tell stories that invoke a passion that the choreographers want to share. These messages are ones of hope for life and community. Sometimes we perform for underprivileged audiences as well (like nursing-homes, hospitals and prisons) but if we can't to go them, we offer discounts for students and others who would not normally be able to afford a dance show. KHDP also has a mission to contribute to the dance world and the arts by working with the dancers and choreographers themselves and creating relationships with the dance community.

Donating to KHDP will not only help us cover our costs, but you will be contributing to the outreach ministry of KHDP Company and its dedicated members. Our mission is bigger than simply dancing -although we will surely be dancing!

KATY HAGELIN dance project Co. will present EXPOSURE 2017, an evening presenting contemporary ballet and modern dance pieces by four choreographers: Megan Becker, Victoria Gutierrez, Wade Walthall -restaged by Rachel Gonsalves and Katy Hagelin. 3 pieces will be world premiers and 2 will be reptertoire.

EXPOSURE will be presented on September 8th, 9th and 10th 2017 at 8:00pm each evening at Everett PUD Auditorium. It is a contemporary ballet and modern dance show where four choreographers and ten company dancers will present work exploring imbalances within society and offer ideas, hope and empowerment for change. The goal is to not only "expose" truth and hope about what we examine, but we also desire to place ourselves within our community and become "exposed" ourselves -revealing what is inside our own hearts desires and struggles as human beings. We want our audiences to leave the show informed and encouraged to continue to making positive changes in the world around them. We feel as artists, it is important to expose what our culture is dealing with in regards to this current day and age. It is one of our goals to translate truths and make present history more understandable.

$13,000 is our goal and the breakdown involves costs such as:

Theatre $2500, Dancer stipends $5K-$7K, Stage Managers/other technicians $500+, Marketing $300-$500, Insurance $350-$400, Costumes/shoes $700+, Rehearsal space $500+, Other misc: Ticket stubs, Tape, Supplies, Rent Projector, Flowers/gifts, and much more.. that adds up!

Our tickets sales usually only produce around 2,000$ as attendance is not in the hundreds. A good sized audience for KHDP would be between 50-100, although we would want and encourage hundreds. If we market well, we may be able to cover the costs of the theatre with the ticket sales. We don't expect that we can raise all of our money on our campaign here, but we hope to raise possibly 10K at least in donations, so that our ticket sales cover the rest. Any extra will probably honestly not even be "extra" but will go as a stipend to some of our workers (like videographer, costume designer/taylor, stage manager, music editor and more) who have already donated their time to us.

Please let us know if you have any questions regarding costs! You can also visit our website at www.katyhagelindanceproject.org!

 

Even if you are able to give $2 or $5, that would be such a huge contribution! Anything can help!

We appreciate your support so much and would love to also see you at the show.

 

-Directors Katy Hagelin, Megan Becker and our dedicated KHDP Company Members

story:
We're Keeping Live Theatre Alive!

Due to the on-going nature of the COVID-19 pandemic crisis here in the United States, an entire segment of the economy - entertainment - has been largely shut down since March, and is showing no signs of being able to open back up safely in the near future (probably not until sometime in 2021). Theaters and have had to close and renaissance faires and festivals have been forced to not open, leaving actors, musicians, and variety performers of all stripes needing to find other sources of income and to file for unemployment.

That's where the Social Distancing Players come in.

The Social Distancing Players was conceived by Dan Kostelec - also known as your friendly, neighbourhood Shakespeare at renaissance festivals and schools around the country - as a way to provide some small level of income and performance outlet to these performers hit hardest by the pandemic and shutdown, and to bring online entertainment back to our fans who miss seeing us in person.

The performances are adapted for online performance and audiences from the stage versions of plays put up at renaissance festivals by Dan Kostelec in his one-man, audience-interactive show, Shakespeare Approves! Obviously, performing an in-person show with lots of audience interaction is not really possible now, so we're doing it the next best way: over Zoom and with professional actors mixed with patrons!

The Hamlet X-mas Special! is the SIXTH performance of The Social Distancing Players since the quarantines began back in March, with a new show going up every three-to-four weeks (we've also performed 12th Night & the 3 Bears!, Romeo & Juliet: The Flying Implement of Doom Edition!, Julius Caesar: Beware the Ides of March of the Penguins!, A Midsummer Night's Dream: A Gaye Olde Tyme!, and Macbeth: Death by Fluffy Kittens!), and will be providing semi-quasi-gainful employment to six professional actors, and opportunities for several patrons to join us in the show!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise at least $1,300.00 for this performance, which will cover the costs for each actor, raising at least $100 for them (and hopefully more), which can go towards their monthly bills. Some of this money will be put aside to go towards future productions and also pay for the costs of keeping this going.

 

What do you get?

A part in the show! And also much more!

If you're familiar with Shakespeare's live, in-person ren faire show, you know that he uses the audience members as the cast, the set, even as some of the props. So keeping with that tradition, if you are able to donate to this cause, the first 5 people to donate $50 or more will get to be in the show (all roles are first-come, first served). Yeah, it sounds like pay-to-play, because it is. But if you can afford it, I guarantee that you'll have a marvelous time!

Roles Available

  • Sally, Hamlet's younger sister
  • Polonius, father to Ophelia & Laertes
  • The Little Red-Headed Girl
  • Shermy
  • #10
  • #12
  • #13
  • A perfectly ordinary Blue Box

But wait — there’s more!

Let’s say you have some cash but can’t afford to go up to $50. For $10 you can get a "seat at the show"! You'll have the best seat in the house - your house! - but can join the actors "backstage" before and after the show in our private Zoom meeting, and interact with the actors and your fellow audience members in a private chat. Plus, you're seeing the show 45 seconds before the folks on Facebook and YouTube!

Well, for $30 you can get a copy of the performance script signed by the author (the guy who plays  Shakespeare, not Shakespeare himself - that guy's dead. Probably).

And if you’re feeling particularly generous and want to donate $100 - well, you get some goodies! You get the signed performance script, a part in the show (if you desire, and if they haven’t been snatched up yet — all roles are first-come, first served), AND a personalized sonnet commissioned JUST FOR YOU (a $20 value).

The Impact

You will directly be helping professional entertainers keep "professional" as part of their job title, by helping us to pay our bills, buy our groceries (when we dare to venture outside during this social distancing period), and not sink deeper into poverty or credit card debt.

You're helping to extend hope and build morale for our fellow members of humanity by giving them a much-needed distraction during this crisis, a sense that a return-to-normal is not just possible but inevitable.

You're keeping live theatre alive.
 

Other Ways You Can Help


Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Share this campaign with your friends, family, even enemies!

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you. I love you - you love me - there is mutual, glorious affection!

story:
About us

After relocating from Los Angeles in the fall of 2017, we found that the Portland dance community was teeming with potential and we were eager to join the erupting scene. As we immersed ourselves further in the community, we noticed many dance and movement based spaces in the city were closing. We also noticed an influx of hungry dancers from across the country. Considering those two pieces of information, we decided the next thing on our agenda would be to open a space welcoming all ages and abilities. 

Floor aims to foster a creative environment that pushes the boundaries of contemporary dance. We strive to enrich Portland’s dance scene by supporting the city’s rapidly growing dance community and will welcome national and international dance artists to create in our space. We will engage and educate the community and make viewing and participating in dance more accessible. Our schedule offers a wide range of styles and technical foundation for all ages, levels and abilities. We will provide consistent performance opportunities to our students, along with local and visiting artists of varying modalities. Floor is a place to discover, nurture and reconnect to the passion of movement and physical expression.

With your contribution, we will be able to bring the Portland dance community a high quality movement facility with the capability of providing space to train, create, and perform. 

 

What We Need

-a floor for FLOOR

Our space needs a floor, of course! This is our largest expense as we will need to cover almost 1500 sqaure feet. 

 -office furniture

We will need basic office furniture: a desk, cubbies, viewing chairs, dressing room dividers, and such. 

-mounted mirrors

At the moment, Raven Jones of WolfBird Dance, has graciously donated a temporary mirror to our space. (thanks, Raven!!) We eventually would like to replace the temporary mirror with mounted mirrors. 

What You Get

We have been incredibly fortunate to have surrounded ourselves with such lovely, supportive,  generous people who have donated beautiful artwork and wellness services. We understand that the demand for funds for artists is large which is why we'd like to offer something extra for your generosity. Be on the lookout for more exciting perks as our campaign continues.
story_txt:
About us
After relocating from Los Angeles in the fall of 2017, we found that the Portland dance community was teeming with potential and we were eager to join the erupting scene. As we immersed ourselves further in the community, we noticed many dance and movement based spaces in the city were closing. We also noticed an influx of hungry dancers from across the country. Considering those two pieces of information, we decided the next thing on our agenda would be to open a space welcoming all ages and abilities. 
Floor aims to foster a creative environment that pushes the boundaries of contemporary dance. We strive to enrich Portland’s dance scene by supporting the city’s rapidly growing dance community and will welcome national and international dance artists to create in our space. We will engage and educate the community and make viewing and participating in dance more accessible. Our schedule offers a wide range of styles and technical foundation for all ages, levels and abilities. We will provide consistent performance opportunities to our students, along with local and visiting artists of varying modalities. Floor is a place to discover, nurture and reconnect to the passion of movement and physical expression.
With your contribution, we will be able to bring the Portland dance community a high quality movement facility with the capability of providing space to train, create, and perform. 
 
What We Need
-a floor for FLOOR
Our space needs a floor, of course! This is our largest expense as we will need to cover almost 1500 sqaure feet. 
 -office furniture
We will need basic office furniture: a desk, cubbies, viewing chairs, dressing room dividers, and such. 
-mounted mirrors
At the moment, Raven Jones of WolfBird Dance, has graciously donated a temporary mirror to our space. (thanks, Raven!!) We eventually would like to replace the temporary mirror with mounted mirrors. 

What You Get
We have been incredibly fortunate to have surrounded ourselves with such lovely, supportive,  generous people who have donated beautiful artwork and wellness services. We understand that the demand for funds for artists is large which is why we'd like to offer something extra for your generosity. Be on the lookout for more exciting perks as our campaign continues.

story:
About Us

The Regular Theatre is a non-profit theatre ensemble, founded in 2017 by friends and students then attending Xavier University. We strive to create opportunities for local artists and new friends to work on engaging and relevant projects that speak to a diverse audience of regular people.

 

The Season

This season, our goal is to challenge both our audiences and ourselves by producing work that is complex, thoughtful, and daring. As young artists, we believe that we can bring a unique perspective to our audiences.

This season's productions include:

Edward Albee's The Zoo Story, directed by Hannah Sgambellone, starring Micah Price and Sam Martini

Rajiv Joseph's Gruesome Playground Injuries, directed by Kyle Daniels

Maxim Vinogradov's A Night of Stars With Tennessee Williams, a regional premiere directed by Ellie Conniff

Arthur Miller's The Crucible, directed by Hannah Sgambellone

 

Our Goal

The Regular Theatre seeks to create work that broadens the scope of the Cincinnati theatre scene, as well as makes the arts accessible for a diverse audience. We pride ourselves on being a community-based organization that has found success in past productions through the collaboration of many fellow artists, friends, sponsors, and patrons. What we do is not possible without the support of our community.

With this year's season, our goal is to raise $3000 to cover the cost of productions, from obtaining rights to building sets, as well as being to pay our actors, designers, and other collaborators for all of the hard work they do. No contribution is too small, and any contribution is greatly appreciated.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute monetarily, no worries! Just spread the word about the season and our campaign. Word-of-mouth goes a long way!

Feel free to email us at regulartheatre@outlook.com with questions, concerns, or to learn other ways that you can be a part of the Regular Theatre Community.

 

We appreciate your interest in our company and your commitment to the arts!

story:
About the Show

Drunk, disturbed, and existentially challenged, John Faustus returns from the future with a distinct need to apologize to someone... anyone... maybe even you...

An Apology for the Course and Outcome of Certain Events Delivered by Doctor John Faustus on This His Final Evening premiered in 1999 at Theater Oobleck in Chicago. It was revived 10 years later in 2009 to rave reviews and numerous awards, including 10 Best Plays of 2009 (Time Out Chicago) and Best of Fringe (Chicago Tribune.) 

Unseen in New York since its brief appearance in the 2001 NY Fringe Festival, this multi-venue site-specific production celebrates the 20th anniversary of this maddeningly profound play.

Cast

John Faustus: Geoffrey Hellauer Geiger

Mephistopheles: Rachel Weekley

 

Creative Team

Director: Robert Malbrough

Lighting Designer: Mike Schulz

Artwork: Anna Lyles

Producer: Zeynep Akca

 

About the author

Mickle Maher's plays have appeared Off-Broadway and around the world, and have been supported by grants from the NEA, the Rockefeller MAP fund, and Creative Capital. They includeThe Hunchback Variations, The Strangerer, Spirits to Enforce, and It is Magic (Theater Oobleck), Cyrano (translator) and The Cabinet (Redmoon Theater), and Lady Madeline (Steppenwolf). He is a cofounder of Chicago's Theater Oobleck, and has taught playwriting and related subjects at the University of Chicago, Columbia College, and Northwestern University. He recently wrote the book and lyrics for Small Ball a new musical about basketball commissioned by the Catastrophic Theatre and Daryl Morey, the General Manager of the Houston Rockets. His plays are published by Hope and Nonthings.

 

What We Need

We need to raise a total of $7,100, to fund the entire project.

Here's where your money is going: 

                 Creative Team & Actors: $1,500

                 Rehearsal Space: $600

                 Performance Space: $3,000

                 Production Costs: $1,550

                 Marketing Costs: $400

                 IndieGoGo Fees: $250

This production would not be possible without your generosity. 

 

What You Get

Not only will your donation bring this show to life, we have some great donation perks as well!

Perks Include

Personalized thanks

Posters 

Tasty beverages

Pages of infernal scribbling

And more!

Check out the full list of perks to the right!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, please share our campaign and help us get the word out!

One of the best ways to get attention is by word of mouth! 

You can also follow us on Facebook!

story:
fabe Dance -Drugs Can't Buy premiere 

 

My name is Mallory Fabian and I am the Artistic Director of fabe Dance. fabe is nearing the end of our second year with our 3rd evening length work Drugs Can’t Buy premiering at Highways Performance Space on October 11 & 12. In two years fabe has performed in 7 dance festivals, taught masterclasses, workshops, have performed in over 10 venues in Los Angeles, and we're just getting started! 

 

Get to know fabe Dance! 

With fabe, I want to help change the way audience members witness dance. I am most interested in work that creates a space for a performer to be seen as extraordinarily human. My goal is to achieve real and raw emotion on stage that comes from pushing through exhaustion and emotional turmoil in a meditative state. My work is feminine conscious, explores dry humor, and is generationally specific. The performers are real and present, just as audience members are, inherently aware and thinking through every movement, otherwise the work is flat and artificial.

Drugs Can’t Buy is a new, dark, and deeply personal dance-theatre work exploring what love can do to someone. 

I am looking to raise funds for the extremely talented collaborators working on this project with me. These collaborators, designers, performers, my support system have been working very hard on this project for months and they deserve to get paid a lot more than anyone can provide them. 

Making work in Los Angeles is hard, exciting, and I will continue to bring my audience fresh, fun, thought provoking, unimaginative work. I am dedicated to my practice as an art maker and dancer and I cannot do it without your support. If you decide to fund this project not only will you be supporting my collaborators, you will be contributing to keeping art alive in Los Angeles. 

 We would not survive without your continued support. Thank you so much for everything you've already done and continue to do. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

With this campaign we are asking you to help us raise $5,500 to support the creation and performance of Drugs Can’t Buy. This campaign isn’t anywhere near the amount it will take to put on this show. Along with artist compensation for the rest of this project, not including what has already been paid, plus scenic design elements, costumes, technical elements, administrative support, etc, we budgeted for this show to cost over $20,000. I am very dedicated to bringing a world into the theatre the second the audience walks through the door. I’m from Las Vegas... so I’ve definitely seen and have been inspired by what shows there do. We are interested in creating that world but it takes funds beyond my support to achieve. Your donations will directly help the artists working on this show and making that world for you possible. 

We want to give you some fun things for your contributions! No donation is too small. For just $1 you can get fabe to do a 30 second jam sesh in one of our rehearsals in honor of your donation. For just a little more we will post videos of us improvising on our story to say thank you to you. You can get a sneak peak of a music track we are using for our show with a little background on why we’re using it for $50. You can potentially get a print that was drawn by Sam Maurer in the making of our newest film “altered/seen”. Some donations even come with a gift bag of many treats. For $1000 Tom E Kelley will create a small replica of a music box we will be using in the show! 

We want you to have all of these things as a tiny gesture for what you make possible. We cannot thank you enough! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us out by sharing our campaign on your social media. Word of mouth is a powerful tool in building audience engagement. You may know someone that can help us reach our goal and you probably don’t even know it! 

You can also support fabe Dance by purchasing tickets to our show! 

To purchase tickets for the Friday performance click here!

To purchase tickets for the Saturday performance click here! 

 

Performers & Collaborators! 

Choreography & Direction: Mallory Fabian

Executive Director: Darby Kelley 

Executive Assistant: Sara Hartless 

Lighting Design: Darius Gangei 

Prop Maker + Set Design: Tom E Kelley 

Performers: Paige Amicon, Sara Hartless, Darby Kelley, Caileigh Knapp, Clementine Gamson Levy, Sam McReynolds, Nikki Nistal, Tin Nguyen, Shane Raiford,  Brance William Souza, Taylor Unwin

Understudy: Darby Epperson  

 

fabe Dance is fiscally sponsored by Rosanna Gamson/World Wide. 

Drugs Can't Buy is made possible with the Show Box LA residency 19-20.
