story:
You're invited to the Vancouver premiere of

A Kid Like Jake!

 

My name is Stefania Indelicato and I am the Founder and Artistic Director at dream of passion productions : an actor-run, award-winning, independent production company based in Vancouver, BC whose mission is to produce works that speak to the contemporary human condition.

Along with my co-producing partner, Mark Sutherland, and the rest of our team, we are asking for your help with our next project, A Kid Like Jake by Daniel Pearle, opening on April 23, 2020 at the PAL Studio Theatre in Vancouver.

About the Play: A Kid Like Jake by Daniel Pearle 

A Kid Like Jake is about a mother and father trying to do right by their 4-year-old son, Jake, who from an early age shows signs of gender-variant behaviour that becomes highlighted during the process of applying to private schools in New York. Although this play is about Jake, we never actually meet him onstage. Instead, we hear the way Jake is described by his teachers, and experienced by his parents, and from this it becomes clear that Jake doesn’t fit into the gender binaries that are the constructs of the worlds his parents grew up in.

Our Team

Fay Nass - Director 

Brent Hirose - "Greg"

Stefania Indelicato - "Alex"

Beverley Elliott - "Judy"

Lindsay Nelson  - " Nurse" 

Sara Vickruck - Sound Designer

Jonathan Kim - Lighting Designer 

Bruce Forster & Emily Dotson - Set Designers

Stefania Indelicato & Mark Sutherland - Producers - dream of passion productions 

Why this play is important

Queer stories told through the lens of the parents and extended community of a gender-creative child are rare. So at a time when transgender rights and issues are making headlines in the news, this play can help to shoulder the burden of explanation, education, and relationship reconstruction between the queer community and their families. We see the theatrical setting as an ideal place of congregation for the LGBTQ2S+ community, and their allies. It can be a place of exploration and healing: a safe place to begin to confront one’s own relationship to their gender, their self, their partner(s), and their children, in a way that places the responsibility on the ally to ask themselves the hard questions, and seek answers. 

Our venue, the PAL Studio Theatre, is located on the 8th floor of the Performing Arts Lodges (PAL Vancouver), a unique social housing and theatre complex providing aging performing artists and those with disabilities the space and community they need to stay creative and engaged. Rental of this space plus $1 from each ticket sold goes to PAL and helps subsidize the living costs for their residents.

Our Personal Connection
For Stefania, who grew up in a traditional Italian family with a brother who would later come out as gay, and Mark, who is a gay male, the story of A Kid Like Jake resonated on many levels - primarily how the “coming-out” process can affect the parent-child relationship. While parents are always trying their best to do the right thing by protecting their children from a world that can be cruel towards people who don’t appear to be normal, their actions and choices may not be the right thing for that child. As with our experiences, the characters of A Kid Like Jake are forced to examine their beliefs and values while being constrained by the system for which they have been cultured. The intersection of these themes within the context of A Kid Like Jake is powerful, beautiful and at times devastating. This play has the potential to spark dialogue between audience members, their families and communities in the hope of helping us to love each other unconditionally.

The impact of your contribution

As an independent actor-run theatre company, the reality of producing in today's artistic climate calls on producers to take on a significant amount of financial risk. With this risk comes the potential for immeasurable artistic rewards, and a great impact on the health of the community we are serving. As an independent company that functions in the vein of a not-for-profit organization, we have the freedom to choose the kind of work that we would like to produce, but the avenues by which we might obtain funding are slightly out of reach. As a young company, we are still working towards not-for-profit status, and as such, we are dependent upon friends, family, colleagues, and referrals, for the majority of our fundraising. 

Where is your contribution is going

To give you an idea of our expenses (without putting you through the process of reading a spreadsheet), we are responsible for all costs associated with: the venue; staffing the venue; insurance for the venue; the licensing of the play; the licensing of the bar; paying our artists and creative team something; marketing; publicity; advertising; rehearsal space; printing fees, etc. The larger companies in town have entire departments devoted to all of these jobs. As a small independent company, you basically have to do it all. 

Given the content and potential emotional impact of the play on individual audience members, your contribution will support information and other opportunities for our patrons to further engage with the material through post-show talkback sessions with relevant speakers and experts in the field of transgender studies.

Our Community Partners:

At dream of passion productions, we are committed to fostering and creating opportunities for women, and marginalized groups, and are focused on cultivating a diversity of voices in our team and community partners. 

We are so grateful to have partnered with a number of organizations whose values and goals around inclusivity, acceptance, and equity, are in alignment with our own.

We humbly thank the following partners for their support and generosity:  

pflag - Vancouver 

the frank theatre

Vancouver Acting School 

The Queer Arts Festival 

Pi Theatre 

QMUNITY 

Gillespie's Fine Spirits

Almiro Studios

Words from our partners:

"We were compelled to participate in this endeavour to support artistic risk-taking, incite creative collaboration and experimentation with the aim of harnessing the visceral power of the arts to inspire recognition, respect, and visibility of people who transgress gender and sexual norms."

- SD Holman, Artistic Director, Queer Arts Festival

"Gender non-conformity is an issue that has gained a lot of traction since A Kid Like Jake debuted in 2013, but there's still a lot of work to do around normalization of gender identify [...] The play offers a great opportunity for people to examine their own biases and positions on the topic without being strident or prescriptive"

- Richard Wolfe, Artistic and Producing Director, Pi Theatre

How to Participate in this Campaign

The most obvious way that you can contribute is to do so financially, in a way that is within your means and that you can feel good about. 

If a financial contribution isn't possible for you at this time, then sharing is caring! People tend to contribute to causes that mean something to them, and causes that mean something to their friends and colleagues. If you aren't able to donate right now, you can still help us in big ways by sharing! 

  • Share our campaign on your social media platforms.
  • Text or email your friends directly and share what we are doing with them.
  • Make a good old-fashioned phone call and tell your friends about our campaign!

To stay up-to-date - follow us on social media:

 @dreamofpassionproductions

 @dreamofpassionproductions

@dreamofpassions

Visit the Facebook Event Page for A Kid Like Jake 

https://www.facebook.com/events/437998140329293/

To give you an idea of our expenses (without putting you through the process of reading a spreadsheet), we are responsible for all costs associated with: the venue; staffing the venue; insurance for the venue; the licensing of the play; the licensing of the bar; paying our artists and creative team something; marketing; publicity; advertising; rehearsal space; printing fees, etc. The larger companies in town have entire departments devoted to all of these jobs. As a small independent company, you basically have to do it all. 
Given the content and potential emotional impact of the play on individual audience members, your contribution will support information and other opportunities for our patrons to further engage with the material through post-show talkback sessions with relevant speakers and experts in the field of transgender studies.
Our Community Partners:
At dream of passion productions, we are committed to fostering and creating opportunities for women, and marginalized groups, and are focused on cultivating a diversity of voices in our team and community partners. 
We are so grateful to have partnered with a number of organizations whose values and goals around inclusivity, acceptance, and equity, are in alignment with our own.
We humbly thank the following partners for their support and generosity:  
pflag - Vancouver 
the frank theatre
Vancouver Acting School 
The Queer Arts Festival 
Pi Theatre 
QMUNITY 
Gillespie's Fine Spirits
Almiro Studios

Words from our partners:
"We were compelled to participate in this endeavour to support artistic risk-taking, incite creative collaboration and experimentation with the aim of harnessing the visceral power of the arts to inspire recognition, respect, and visibility of people who transgress gender and sexual norms."
- SD Holman, Artistic Director, Queer Arts Festival
"Gender non-conformity is an issue that has gained a lot of traction since A Kid Like Jake debuted in 2013, but there's still a lot of work to do around normalization of gender identify [...] The play offers a great opportunity for people to examine their own biases and positions on the topic without being strident or prescriptive"
- Richard Wolfe, Artistic and Producing Director, Pi Theatre
How to Participate in this Campaign
The most obvious way that you can contribute is to do so financially, in a way that is within your means and that you can feel good about. 
If a financial contribution isn't possible for you at this time, then sharing is caring! People tend to contribute to causes that mean something to them, and causes that mean something to their friends and colleagues. If you aren't able to donate right now, you can still help us in big ways by sharing! 

Share our campaign on your social media platforms.
Text or email your friends directly and share what we are doing with them.
Make a good old-fashioned phone call and tell your friends about our campaign!

To stay up-to-date - follow us on social media:
 @dreamofpassionproductions
 @dreamofpassionproductions
@dreamofpassions
Visit the Facebook Event Page for A Kid Like Jake 
https://www.facebook.com/events/437998140329293/

story:
Short Summary!

Something For The Buoys: A New Musical Comedy! Has had two sold out staged readings and is now ready to be produced! With book, music and Lyrics by Eli Pasic, this parody of nautical musical comedies of the 1930s is guaranteed to entertain!

SYNOPSIS
A starry-eyed sailor named Jimmy feels lonely and wants nothing more than to find his true love. Accompanied by Larry, his womanizing best pal, he sneaks ashore and enters the wonderful world of New York City. Of course, Jimmy immediately stumbles upon his true love. But between a big-time Broadway offer and a cranky captain with an Alka- Seltzer addiction, will Jimmy sail into the sun and live happily ever after before the final curtain? Who knows!

A bit about us:

ELI PASIC is a playwright, screenwriter, and book writer/composer-lyricist of musical comedies. He studied piano and composition at Berklee College Of Music and was mentored by Broadway orchestrator Larry Blank as well as Broadway conductor Eric Stern. He’s been involved in countless productions as a rehearsal pianist and pit musician, and he’s a ubiquitous performer on the Toronto jazz scene. He recently wrote the book and lyrics to a new musical comedy with composer Henry Krieger (co-author of “Dreamgirls” and “Side Show”), which has been published by Broadway Licensing. If show business fails, he will move to Greece and become a dairy farmer.

ROBERTO SAPIENZA is an actor, musician, director, producer, writer and Co-Founder of Sapling. He graduated from the Randolph College of Performing Arts in 2016 and has been working consistently in theatre since. Some of his recent credits include: Davey in Newsies, Lefou in Beauty and the Beast, Jake Laurents (George Bailey) in It's A Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play and Chef Pisghetti in Curious George and the Golden Meatball. He played Jimmy in the second staged reading of Something For The Buoys. He will also be making his directorial debut this summer in the Toronto Fringe Festival for Tales Of A Cocktail by Breakaway Entertainment. 

BRYAN KLING has been working in theatre and pushing himself as a singer and an actor since his graduation from the Randolph College for Performing Arts in 2014. Since first endeavoring into this industry, Bryan dreamed of one day running a production company of his own. He is absolutely thrilled to present this next step forward for both himself and the industry that has continuously brought him so much joy.

OUR CAMPAIGN!

We started our journey with what we know best — Theatre. Not only is this show close to our hearts, but it is a huge stepping stone towards Saplings future. Our goal, however, is to expand into a hub for all forms of artistry. We can't give away all of our ideas just yet..but trust us when we say our vision is clear and our plans are set. 

To help you understand what your contribution would mean, let us say this. You're not just contributing to one production. Your contribution will be the force that pushes the first snowball down the hill. If we can get this project moving, it will be the launching point for everything else. This project will help us plant our feet firmly into the ground and help us green light all of our plans. We wouldn't be able to express how grateful your contribution to this project would mean..so, we're also offering perks!

Goals and Rewards!

We can't do it alone!

  • To green light the project, we're looking for another $8,000. In our previous "Gofundme" we raised $2220! Which, is absolutely amazing. We've switched platforms, so we can reward our donors!
  • We will have many stages of perks to show our thanks!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds will be used to workshop and further other projects. We're looking to get as many works as possible shown to the public and other producers and investors.

Risks & Challenges!

Theatre, as we know, is a fickle industry. So many contributing factors can lead to a lot of different risks and challenges. Though we've been able to nip some risks in the bud already, we're constantly working hard to make sure we can overcome every single one. Sapling have a team of people dedicated to promote the projects and getting bums in seats. This is one of the largest hurdles for new theatre companies, and this is a huge priority for us.

Passion vs business. There are many companies backed either only by passionate artists or business people. We've managed to find balance. Not only are we passionate and enthusiastic about producing important work, we're also passionate about treating theatre as a business (which it is).

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you can't contribute financially, there's always other ways to help. Share the campaign with friends, family, or anyone you think may want to invest! Talk about it. Mention it in person to people! Ask us how you can help! I promise we'll find something.

story:
__________________________________________________________

A New Model

Woven Theatre was started in 2016 by a trio of young directors yearning to create. Together they put on their first season, producing four projects in the span of three months. Unlike many theatre companies, Woven Theatre strayed away from the standard model involving a board of directors and instead created an Artistic Council. Being founded by three directors, the thought of an Artistic Director didn't seem to make sense. Woven Theatre wanted to be a collection of artists that came together to create and grow. 

 Young artists are hungry. They strive to be everywhere and do everything at once because opportunities are precious, and they fear passing them up. Woven Theatre gives them a chance to create art on nothing but that tenacity. Woven Theatre seeks to provide unique, artistic opportunities for young people to explore and find their artistic identity and tell the stories they are passionate about. 

We love what we do and feel as though we provide unique and authentic perspective for the Nashville Community. No other theatre company in Nashville focuses on the production of New Plays as much as Woven. No other theatre company in Nashville focuses so heavily on the voices and stories of the LGBT+ community. 

A contribution to our campaign goes further than just putting another show on the stage. It ensures we can pay our actors and designers and playwirghts. It ensures that new plays and artistic experiences have a chance to make it in front of audiences. New Plays are one of the most important facets in the theatre. They allow the art form to march on and grow and evolve. 

__________________________________________________________

What We Need & What You Get

We tend to keep our shows small and tight and quick. We are seeking $3,000. That's about what it costs to produce one play for us. The major of everything raised will go straight to paying our people. It will pay:

Actors

Designers

Stage Managers 

Playwrights 

Dramaturgs 

etc.

Basically it helps to employ people. When we started Woven Theatre making sure artists got paid for their work was of the upmost importance. We are proud to say we have continued to do that for 4 years now. 

With $3,000 we can put $1,500 toward each show to cover 1/2 of the cost. This puts us in a safe zone in case ticket sales for a night are down or if we have to cancel a perfromance. 

If we don't reach our goal any funds we receive will first go to paying our people, plain and simple. 

_________________________________________________________

Our Season

UPDATE:

The Loom was hit! We loved presenting these 6 incredible new plays to Nashville. Some of our playwrights joined us from across the country!

Opening our season is our 3rd annual New Works Festival called The Loom. This year we received over 100 new plays and have whittled that down to 6. These plays will be presented as staged readings between September 6th and 8th. Below are the 6 finalist for The Loom. 

Don't Kill the Angels by Claudia Barnett

Frozen Fluid by Fly Jamerson

Paper Hangers by Emily Brauer Rogers

C-Bus by Chris Shaw Swanson

No Safe Refuge by Erica Jo Lloyd

Flight By Patrick Gabridge 

 

Next up in September, we have Initiative by Jacob York. Initiative was presented as part of last years Loom Festival. 

David has cancer. It's aggressive. And terrifying.

He looks at his life and all he sees are holes; the moments he won't be able to have, if this cancer is successful in its malign task. He sees one way out: Dungeons and Dragons.

Dave has a circle of friends that still play, and as he thinks back on the moments they've experienced in game, he doesn't remember sitting around a table, rolling dice. He remembers every spell cast, every enemy vanquished, and every cataloged item.

So, the new quest: to play through potential “memories” Dave might miss. His three friends, Tyrone, Benny, and Sky, sit down with Dave's girlfriend, Meg (a gaming newbie) and chart out a path to victory. If all goes well, Dave will experience events as important as the birth of his child and as personal as seeing the ocean for the first time.

But. That's if everything goes well. For, in the game, The Shade lurks...

Initiative is about dealing with tragedy thru friendship and storytelling.  

UPDATE!

Initiative better than we could have ever imagined. We played to 2 sold out houses and many more that we packed! 

 

 

In October we will open the World Premiere of Tall Tales by A.D. Timms. 

 

Tall Tales is about Noah returning to his Alabama hometown after being away at college. Soon after, people start to turn up dead. Is there a murderer, or does this town have a history that Noah doesn’t know about? Tall Tales is a supernatural queer horror play about being othered in the Deep South and the feeling of being watched by something just beyond the treeline.

UPDATE

Tall Tales opened to a packed house and closed a successful first weekend with 2 more to go!

We will also be adding a production in Novememer as well as a reading of Torera by Monet Hurst-Mendoza. 

__________________________________________________________

The Perks!

$1-The Needle

Thanks so much!

$5-The Thread

Your name in the program 

$15-The Weft 

Your name in the program

A ticket to any one night

$25-The Reed

Your name in the program

A ticket to any one night 

A show poster

$50-The Shuttle 

Your name in the program

A ticket to any one night 

A signed show poster

$100-The Spinning Wheel

Your name in the program

2 tickets to a night of your choosing 

A signed show poster

$250-The Weaver

Your name in the program

A voucher for 1 season ticket

A signed show poster

A festival pass to The Loom

$500-The Loom

Listed in the program as a sponsor of The Loom

Vouchers for 2 season tickets

A signed show poster

2 festival passes to The Loom

$1000-The Alpaca

Listed in the program as a 2019 Season Sponsor

Vouchers for 2 season tickets

A signed show poster

2 festival passes to The Loom

A meet and greet with the cast and crew after a performance of your choice 

$2000-The Merino

Listed in the program as a 2019 Season Sponsor

Vouchers for 2 season tickets

A signed show poster

2 festival passes to The Loom

A meet and greet with the cast and crew after a performance of your choice 

A invitation to an open rehearsal 

$3000-The Cashmere

Listed in the program as a 2019 Season Sponsor

Vouchers for 2 season tickets

A signed show poster

2 festival passes to The Loom

A meet and greet with the cast and crew after a performance of your choice 

A invitation to an open rehearsal 

Option for a exclusive performance for any show on our season (must be arranged in advance)

__________________________________________________________

Why it Matters

As company we have been producing plays for 4 years. As individuals we have been making theatre for a decade or more a piece. It's who we are. It's what we do. And honestly we've gotten pretty good at it. You can check out our website woventheatre.org or our facebook page and see some of what we've done.  

With all that being said it doesn't mean we don't need help to get there! Every person who works with us in any compacity gets us closer to our final product. Maybe it's someone letting us borrow a truck to pick something up or volunteering to help sell tickets or coming to a show. Everything gets us closer. Basically, everyone is important in the creation of art. 

As stated above almost every dime will go to paying our people. From the beginning making sure we can compensate our people has been of the upmost importance. If we had the chance to perform in the best theatre in town but we couldn't pay our actors and designers and team members, we wouldn't do it. 

__________________________________________________________

Risks & Challenges

Putting together live performances is hard and new plays present their own unique challenges. As a company we produce at least one World Premiere every year. Last year, including our New Works Festival, we presented 8 brand new plays. This season proves to be almost the same, with 6 Plays slotted for our New Works festival and 2 brand new, fully staged plays.

New works are risky from the start. Since they have never been produced there is no name recognition to pull people into the door. It's also a scary and vulnerable time for the playwright and actors. This is often the first time the playwrights have ever seen their play staged and for actors they are in many ways originating the roles. Much of what happens in the first production solidifies many aspects and stays with the play going forward. 

These new works we do could go on to be the next off Broadway hit, or Broadway hit. They could become staples of colleges and regional theaters. This play could help launch a writers career and they could become the next Arthur Miller. Anything is possible. 

We are a company that embraces hazard and danger when it comes to creating theatre. We are not new to the adversity it takes to run a small theatre company and produce new plays and take on the subject matter we do. As a company we have made a stand and pledge to embrace the voices and stories of the LGBTQ+ community and hire people from the community. Many of us that currently run and have run the company are a part of the LGBTQ+ community and representing it's people and culture has become near and dear to our hearts. 

As a community we must champion and advocate for new plays and new artistic experiences. Theatre is a living, breathing, and ever evolving art form. We must continue to create new pieces or the art form will stagnate and slowly die.

__________________________________________________________

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate right now we totally understand. However, you can still help. If you like who we are and what we do share this around. Share it on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat anywhere! The more people that see it the more likely we to reach our goal. Thanks for taking the time to read this far! We hope you'll support us and if you're in Nashville during the shows come by and see us!

story:
What is this? 

In case you are confused, this is a campaign to raise funds for our World Premiere production of "Salutations, I'm Creative Dave by Creative Dave" by Jake Brasch at the Alchemical Theatre Laboratory May 13-17 in Lower Manhattan. Yes, Jake Brasch wrote this play. No, he is not a robot. (At least we don't think he is?)

Why these people? Why this play?

This is a good question. The answer to this question is simple: Good People. Good play.

What is this play about? 

This is a stupidly hilarious play about an artistic robot and his family. It is written from the wonky perspective of a jerry-rigged housekeeping robot. Part family drama, part screwball comedy, part existentialist meltdown, Creative Dave's play will make you laugh, cry, and reexamine your feelings about technology, human beings, and the creative spirit.

Who's are these people doing this play? 

We are a fierce crew of young professionals who are determined to turbo charge our blossoming careers with a self-produced, fully-staged production of this new wack-a-doo family comedy. 

This is a momentous undertaking. Some would say, "It's too crazy!" But we're champions. We each feel that we are perfectly suited for our roles on this project. We believe in this bad boy. An investment in this play is an investment in us. 

Our cast includes Madeline Barr, Molly Collier, Hudson Rhotenberry, Tomas Virgadula, and Tucker Worley. Our Assistant Director is Tyler Kion.

What makes this campaign different than other campaigns?

Check out our video. Check out this fundraising pitch. It's bold. It's risky. It's mad different. It's irreverent. It's not too self-serious. It's talking about prescient social themes in a whole new way. It's bold. It's daring. It's everything you want from fresh voices putting up a new play. You have the opportunity to support this work from the ground up. We're ambitious as hell and if you support us now, we'll see to it that you are thanked ad nauseam when we're famous.

Where do your monies go? 

Theatre is mad life-changing, but theatre is mad pricey. We need props, costumes, set pieces, rehearsal space, performance space, posters, programs and lots more! Plus, we want to pay our brilliant actors and designers. 

What else can I do to help?

If you don't have monies to throw at us, no problem, we're also poor!  You can help out by volunteering your time, energy, and passion! Shout about our play from your local rooftop. Tell your entire social media following that we are excellent humans making a bomb-dot-com play. Or just bring all of your teenage nieces and nephews to the show in May!  Buy tickets at creativedave.eventbrite.com.

story:
The Bardic Bastards Present:

POCKETMON! A PARODY MUSICAL
Book by Brandon Nicholas Pfeltz
Music and Lyrics by Michael Perrie Jr. and Brandon Nicholas Pfeltz
Produced by The Bardic Bastards

Premiering June 2019
Hollywood Fringe Festival

Grab ahold of your Pocketballs! The Bardic Bastards return to the Hollywood Fringe after the success of their critically derided production “The Midnight Menagerie” with Pocketmon! an adult parody musical.

Hilariously funny and heartwarmingly nostalgic, Pocketmon is a 90 minute special journey into the dark and zany world of Soot Snag’em as he attempts to battle his way to the RobLo League. Supported by his fiercely loyal friends and facing off against the homicidal Team Sprocket, he’ll learn that it takes more than a strong Pocketmon to defeat the Special Three and 
earn the title of Pocketmon master.

Due to strong language and mature situations, Pocketmon is recommended for audiences over the age of 16.

Listen to the songs here: Pocketmon Soundcloud

Who We Are:
The Bardic Bastards are a Los Angeles based theatre company specializing in the cutting edge, whimsically dark and magically misanthropic. Members consist of Brandon Nicholas Pfeltz, Katy Wicker, Kaitlin Ruby, Douglas Krantz, Christopher Lemieux, and Michael Callas.

The Goal:
To produce an outrageous and original one-act dark comedy in the Hollywood Fringe Festival.

How To Help:
Empty the entirety of your bank account into the campaign fundraiser, and then move to Los Angeles to work for the production as an unpaid intern. Or, put us up in a Broadway theatre. But really though, every single penny counts. We truly mean that. Beyond that, your faith in us is even more important. If you can't donate, spread the word! Help blast out the campaign on social media, tell your friends, kidnap your family, and force them to listen to you read the script out loud to them. Help us to support original theatre in Los Angeles. We really want to create something special, and the only way that we can do it is with your help. 

Funding:
In the interest of full transparency, all funds spent will be documented through an easy to read spreadsheet and provided to each backer upon request. Below is a list of what we plan to use the money for.

-Rehearsal Space Booking
-Music Transposition
-Payment to Crew
-Insurance
-Set Materials/Construction
-Costumes
-Marketing
-IndieGoGo Reward Fulfillment
-Props
-Printing
-Future Productions

Future:
In addition to using this money to fund Pocketmon, we'll be using it to create a full season of shows moving forward, ensuring that we will be able to, fingers crossed, be able to sustain future production through ticket sales alone instead of crowdfunding.

Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQ!

story:
****If you would like to receive a perk, please be sure to click on "Get This Perk." If you accidentally donate without selecting a perk, and you would like to receive the associated perk, email us to let us know: info@seoulshakespeare.com.****

 

Hello to our supporters around the globe! We hope you'll watch the video above, but we've included a transcript here as well:

 

Hi, I’m Lauren Ash-Morgan, and I’m the artistic director of Seoul Shakespeare Company. After three comedies, it’s time for us to tackle what many consider to be Shakespeare’s greatest tragedy: King Lear.

 

Introduction to Seoul Shakespeare Company, and Updates for This Year

 

Every year since 2011, Seoul Shakespeare Company has put on a mainstage production in the spring, self-funding our shows with the help of donations and ticket sales. We serve several main communities in Seoul: audience members in the English-speaking foreign community, Korean audience members who want to experience Shakespeare in the original language with Korean surtitles, students from universities and international schools, and theatre artists in the local English-speaking community. One of our primary goals is to produce theatre of a calibre that helps local theatre artists develop their craft to a high standard, and in the last four years, we’ve been especially focusing on training and developing our casts. Talented people have been able to spend time in our company, and use that experience to further their career goals in theatre in their home countries. Alumni from our company have gone on to start their own theatre companies, go to graduate school programs in theatre, teach at university, work as actors and stage managers, and teach Shakespeare to young people. At the same time we have cultivated a core resident company of actors who have worked together consistently and developed the skills and relationships of an experienced, resident company.

 

This year, for the first time, we have also been branching out internationally, connecting with top Shakespeare practitioners from around the world, in order to train and pass on training methods to our Seoul community, connect Seoul Shakespeare Company with other Shakespeare companies around the world, and develop personal connections with other Shakespeare artists. This winter, Charles Jeong, Michael Downey, and I represented Seoul Shakespeare Company at the Shakespeare Theatre Association’s annual conference, and last summer, Michael and I trained and performed in Prague Shakespeare Company’s Summer Shakespeare Intensive, studying with some of the world’s top Shakespeare practitioners. We’ve been taking the skills that we developed there, and in our own research, and applying them to our Seoul theatre community, through workshops for the public and rehearsal techniques with our King Lear cast. As we engage more with the global Shakespeare community, we hope to form stronger bridges between Seoul Shakespeare Company and the wider Shakespeare world.

 

This is my fifth and final year as artistic director of Seoul Shakespeare Company. In these recent years, with Michael Downey as stage director and myself as artistic director, producer and designer, we’ve accomplished everything that we set out to do, and it’s time for Michael and me to use the skills that we’ve developed here and begin working on the next stage of our careers, forming our own small theatre company that can travel with us, while leaving behind a strong Seoul Shakespeare Company for the Seoul community, and hopefully, if we’re successful in our endeavors, opening up opportunities for others through our work, furthering the legacy of Seoul Shakespeare Company, and paving the way for others’ success as well as our own. In order to start preparing for that, it’s important that we allow time for a smooth transition of Seoul Shakespeare Company to its new leadership, so although Michael and I will still be around for a while, we’ll be transitioning away from Seoul Shakespeare Company after this year’s production in order to allow our new artistic director and team to take on their new roles. 

 

Why King Lear this year? 

I’ve been acting in this company for eight years, and for my final production as artistic director, rather than appearing onstage, I’m directing. Michael Downey, who has been directing our productions for the last four years, and who in earlier years played Macbeth, Prospero, and Titus Andronicus, will be playing King Lear, with a wonderful cast of experienced Seoul Shakespeare Company members and very talented newcomers.

 

King Lear is considered by many to be Shakespeare’s greatest play, and the most challenging play for a company to put on, and so it seems a fitting finale for Michael’s and my chapter of Seoul Shakespeare Company’s history.

 

This play contains a wide variety of fascinating and challenging roles. It was written for a group of actors who were mature in their craft and had been working together in Shakespeare’s acting company for many years. It’s been said that this play requires a company of actors who have worked together on Shakespeare’s plays for a long time, and this year, we have such a company.

 

In the last four years, Michael and I have really transformed this company, by developing actor training methods, nurturing talented people with a variety of levels of experience, insisting on a degree of excellence that satisfies both the actors and the audience so that both come back from year to year, and taking inspiration from the aesthetics, techniques, and pragmatism of Shakespeare’s Globe in London, including energetic pacing, continuous action without blackouts, minimal sets and props, effective use of music, attention to the text as the center of the play and mining the text for its possibilities, and creating a feeling of ensemble.

 

As a result of those four years, we now have a core ensemble of actors who have been working together since our very popular first production in this style, Much Ado About Nothing, in 2016. We have all grown phenomenally through the work that we’ve done in this company, and, like Shakespeare’s original company of actors, for whom these plays were written, each actor contributes their own unique strengths to this group, perfectly complementing each other. To that core of actors, for this production, as in past years, we have added a wonderful group of new actors, some of whom had worked with us in the past and are coming back, and some of whom are new to our company. They all bring wonderfully unique qualities to this amazing ensemble cast.

 

How are you approaching the play?

Many people think of King Lear as a grim, very dark, very philosophical play, but in the hands of actors who are familiar with embodying Shakespeare’s work, it’s actually striking how entertaining this play is. It’s a brilliant piece of theatre, rich with feeling and intense connections between people: love and the need for love, fear, and hatred that results from feeling unloved and afraid. This play is also about the nature of suffering alone versus sharing one’s suffering with others, and the ability of others to help alleviate one’s pain.

 

It’s also about how separation and non communication can breed fear and paranoia, and deepen feelings of enmity between people. In the Folio version of the play, on which our production is based, we don’t get a weak, feeble king; there is an emphasis through the revisions between the Quarto and Folio versions of the play on the fact that Lear’s daughters actually fear him, and that their fear is what motivates their viciousness towards him. 

 

At its heart, the play is about a king discovering his humanity. In the highly religious Jacobean era in which this play was written, the king was considered to be near-divine, and in King Lear we have a king who believes that he can talk to the gods, that he has a direct line of communication with them, and in the storm scene he begins to realize that he isn’t divine, that the gods aren’t listening to him, or maybe don’t exist, and that he’s just a man. And that breaks him, and makes him empathize with other people’s suffering for the first time. It’s not about a weak old king whose mind goes because of the physical shock of one night in a storm. It’s about a once-powerful king realizing that he’s just a man.

 

I’ve had the general concept for this production for a number of years. I’ve trained for many years in Korean traditional music and dance (gugak), and a lot of my artistic instincts are influenced by that background. Each year I’ve included subtle references to Korean traditional music and dance in the design of our productions, through costuming, sound design, or choreography, but we’ve never approached any of our productions in a way that highlights the fact that our home is in Korea, and that everyone involved in the production lives in a hybrid cultural world. One of the reasons that I was initially drawn to King Lear is its sensibility that feels a lot like the Korean concept of han and lends itself well to the rough, earthy, cathartic  sounds of gugak. The play also has an ancient, timeless quality, and a purposeful disorientation from any particular historical period, taking place in a completely made up mythical period in Britain’s ancient history, supposedly Bronze Age, but having many features of later periods, and it has a sense of both the barbaric and the opulent. In the design of our production, I’m taking advantage of the built-in weirdness of that setting by using a combination of different styles of dress, influenced by both Korean and European historical styles, with music that features the sounds of the Korean traditional instruments geomungo and gayageum.

 

All of Michael’s and my productions have included a beginning that helps to build the world of the play, either through music or through an opening scene. In this production, we’re including a beginning and ending that make use of the fact that we are in Korea, in the 21st century, and that will help us to dive into the world of King Lear and then re-emerge from that world, having shared an experience together. 

 

Our annual crowdfunding campaign

While ticket sales make up the majority of our budget, each year a significant portion of our budget comes from our annual crowdfunding campaign. This is a chance to show your support for what we are doing, help us continue to do this work in the future, and this year in particular, to give our next artistic director a strong foundation on which to build the next chapter of our company’s history.

 

And of course, if you’re in Korea, we hope you’ll come see King Lear!

 

Lauren Ash-Morgan

Artistic Director, Seoul Shakespeare Company

 

---------------------------------

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't give directly to our production, you can help us by sharing our campaign through social media, and, if you're in Korea, coming to our show!  

 

Korean Bank Transfer Option

If you have a Korean bank account, you can contribute via bank transfer.  Your contribution won't show up in our Indiegogo total, but we can still send you the perks listed above.  Send us an email to let us know that you've contributed, and whether you would like to receive the associated perks, and we'll add you to our list of donors.  Here is a link to our bank information: https://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/make-a-... 

 

 


Show page for King Lear: https://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/king-le... 

Ticket Reservation Form: https://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/ticket-...

Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/2231884110463342/

 

Seoul Shakespeare Company Home Page: https://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/

Seoul Shakespeare Company Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/seoulshakespeare/

Join our email list to receive announcements directly to your inbox:  http://eepurl.com/bQZM9v

 

Seoul Shakespeare Company Email: 

info@seoulshakespeare.com

 

Email for questions about ticketing:

sscticketing@gmail.com 

 

 

CAST

Earl of Kent: Jason Cutler

Earl of Gloucester: Martin Boswell

Edmond: Louis Groves

King Lear: Michael Downey

Gonerill: Wendy Moore

Regan: Jennifer Waescher

Cordelia: Maria Fernanda Silva

Duke of Albany: Jeffrey Wagner

Duke of Cornwall: Daniel Kennedy

Duke of Burgundy/Knight 2/Servant to Cornwall/Captain: Joshua Cate

Oswald/King of France: Stewart Gray

Edgar/Hospital Nurse: Charles Jeong

Knight: Claudia Tumba

Fool/Herald: Chris Zaczek

Curan: Amanda Conkey

Hospital Nurse/Servant to Gonerill/Soldier to Cordelia: Jiwoon Ha

 

CREW

Director: Lauren Ash-Morgan

SSC Artistic Director & Producer: Lauren Ash-Morgan

Stage Manager: Kathryn Dunn

Assistant Stage Managers: Makrenna Sterdan, Coral Kim, Inseo Yeo

Fight choreographer: Jason Cutler

Costume Design/Construction: Lauren Ash-Morgan

Surtitles Translator: Charles Jeong

Sound Design: Lauren Ash-Morgan

Blood FX: Amanda Conkey

Interpreter/Translator: Charles Jeong

Venue Coordinator: Charles Jeong

Surtitles English Transcription: Jamie Horan

Poster concept: Lauren Ash-Morgan

Graphic Design: Charles Jeong

Props painting, drawing, and calligraphy: Charles Jeong
